text:
Title: Paying for Rubbish: Does It Work?

In many places, families do not pay directly for the rubbish they throw away. They pay through local taxes, but a family that throws away a lot of rubbish pays the same as a family that throws away a little. This can be a problem because the more rubbish there is, the more it costs to collect and dispose of it.

One idea is to charge families for each bag of rubbish they produce. This might make people throw away less and recycle more. In some American towns, people have to buy stickers for their rubbish bags. Only bags with stickers are collected.

In Charlottesville, Virginia, people started paying 80 cents for each bag in 1992. The number of bags went down by 37%, but people just put more rubbish in each bag. The weight of rubbish only went down by 14%. Some people even dumped rubbish illegally to avoid paying.

Recycling did go up by 15%, but many people were already recycling before the charges started. In other studies, a 10% increase in sticker prices only reduced rubbish by 0.3%.

Charging for rubbish might not be a bad idea, but it is not simple. Other things like income and education also affect how much rubbish people throw away. Richer towns throw away more rubbish and have less time to recycle. So, while charging for rubbish can help, it is not the only solution.

Theodore Zeldin talks about how our work life might change. Do you feel respected and appreciated at work? Just having a successful career is not enough anymore. Many people feel their jobs are not valued or understood. Even famous people can feel unhappy. Loving your job used to be special, but now you need to think about how your job affects you as a person, your mind, and your relationships. This is important. No matter how good you are at your job, if it makes you boring or too busy to learn new things or be creative, then money and status won't make you happy. 

I am trying to find out how work can help us grow as people, not just be a way to make money. Work should help us discover new talents and meet different people. But this doesn't mean getting rid of unemployment is the only goal. As people get more educated, they want jobs that are interesting and make life better. Work should be like a piece of art, with a happy person at the center.

Even jobs like doctors, accountants, and architects are not as appealing as they used to be. Doctors are stressed, accountants worry about ethics, and architects can't always be creative. Middle managers are losing confidence. Companies are getting smaller, and new ideas like giving more decision power to employees haven't worked well. In Britain, only 8% of employees feel their values match their company's values.

I am looking at different jobs to see how they affect people. I have studied what people can do in different cultures and how courage is made. I am now focusing on finding more satisfying ways to work. Many experts work on making companies last longer and earn more money, but we also need to think about what kind of people we want to be and who we want to work with. How many of us feel truly alive at work? How many of us feel like we are stuck in our jobs, working not to become better people, but because we have no other choice?

Take hotel workers, for example. Many smart and lively people work in hotels for low pay and long hours. Hotels haven't changed much since the old days. They are not just places to sleep; they are like small United Nations where people from all over the world meet. Hotel staff are often from different countries and want to learn new things, but they don't really connect with guests. Hotels could be cultural centers, helping guests meet new people. Hotel owners could use the skills of their staff better, instead of giving them only simple tasks. If they understood their staff's dreams, they could offer more services. But accountants often say hotels should focus on one main thing to make more money. It's time to think about work from a human angle, not just a financial one.

For me, work is about relationships. People want jobs that let them be independent and choose their colleagues and customers. This means they need to talk to people from different backgrounds. Communication is important, but real conversation is more than just talking. It's about understanding each other and creating respect. Every time you have a meaningful conversation, the world changes a little bit.

**Broadcasting: The Social Shaping of a Technology**

The word 'broadcasting' originally meant spreading seeds by hand over a large area. This idea is not just about farming; it also represents the hope of modern times. It is about growing and sharing information widely, like a good harvest. Broadcasting needs a central place to start from, like a bucket of seeds, to spread information.

When new technology allowed us to send words and pictures electronically, it was organized in a way that fit this farming idea. Even though television is similar to two-way communication tools like the telephone, it was always seen as a one-way, mass medium. This means sending information from one central place to many homes, which matched the way modern societies worked.

There were some experiments with different ways of using television. For example, in the 1930s, people in Britain tried using two-way television, like a video phone. Magazines showed how to build TV transmitters and receivers, and many people experimented with this. But big companies set standards that made it hard for these small experiments to continue.

In the early 1930s, television was mostly watched in public places, like theaters, in the USA and other countries. In Britain and Germany, people often watched TV in public settings. The idea of two-way or community television was not very successful, and TV became more about watching at home.

As people started to have more money and better living standards from the 1920s, they wanted homes with entertainment. This made it possible for many people in Western countries to have TVs at home. Broadcasting became a way for governments to share important information with everyone and create a sense of community.

Broadcasting was important for democracy because it helped people access information needed to participate in society. However, as technology changes, the idea of broadcasting might also change. The term might only describe a certain way of using technology during a specific time in history.

**Clutter**  
Sometimes it feels like no matter how many things you have, you never feel safe. It's normal to want a home that meets your needs, but sometimes wanting more things can get out of control. Modern ads are made to make us feel insecure. They tell us that if we don't have certain things, we are not good enough. To see how much ads affect you, try not to look at any billboards next time you walk down the street. These expensive ads try to make us buy things in very convincing ways without us noticing. We see them everywhere - on TV, radio, newspapers, magazines, posters, t-shirts, the internet - all telling us to buy more.

**Caves**  
Scientists and researchers around the world have spent many years studying caves. They look at how caves are formed, how water moves in them, and the life inside them. Caves are a small but interesting part of nature. They make us curious and we want to learn more about them. Because of this, a lot of research has been done on caves. In some places, caves have been important to how people live. However, visiting caves can be difficult, so not only scientists study them. Many people who like to explore caves for fun also study them. This means there is a mix of professional and amateur cave studies.

**Weather Watch**  
A long time ago, people watched the weather using only their senses. This was the start of meteorology, the study of weather. Since the 17th century, it has become a very technical science. Now, satellites and electronic tools give us weather information quickly. Computers solve difficult math problems faster than humans can. Meteorology uses many long words that are hard to understand for most people. But simple weather knowledge is still important. Human experience helps turn computer data into weather forecasts. People can still notice unusual things about the weather that help professionals understand it better.

**Music and Theatre**

Not long ago, I thought opera was mainly about theatre. But after working at a national opera house, I learned that music is the most important part of opera. In theatre, the words and the actors are the focus. The actors and the audience usually speak the same language. In music performances, like concerts or operas, many people, like me, might not know much about music. Some might feel embarrassed about this, but most are amazed by the performers' skills. Watching a great musician is like watching athletes; we see how much better they are than us.

Theatre audiences have different expectations. They might not understand an actor's skill and often think they could do it too. They are not usually impressed by long speeches, though they often ask actors, "How do you remember all those lines?" This doesn't mean theatre audiences are less demanding. In fact, many people go to both theatre and music performances. In theatre, audiences and performers meet on more equal terms.

Can music learn from theatre? I think so. Live music is full of emotion and can be very theatrical. But music performances often feel formal, with strict dress codes and a focus on conductors and soloists. This can make the difference between performers and listeners feel too big. Sometimes, audiences clap at the wrong times, which can interrupt the performance.

Many people are working to make music more accessible and to break down barriers. I remember a special event, Jonathan Dove's community opera "In Search of Angels," which moved from place to place in a cathedral and into the town. It was a great musical experience and changed the lives of many in the audience, who also took part in the performance.

I wish music had more of the risk and excitement that theatre can have. Sometimes, using unusual places for performances can surprise both performers and audiences. It might not be comfortable, but theatre audiences are used to following artists to different places. Most plays are performed in a traditional way, like concerts. But I believe music performances can change. I love both theatre and music and want more people to enjoy them as much as I do.

**Sand**  
I think sand is amazing because it can become useful things like glass and concrete. But I don't like sand when it is just sand. For me, it is a problem between the car park and the sea. Sand blows in your face, gets in your food, and hides important things like car keys and coins. When you are wet, sand sticks to you and is hard to remove, even with a lot of water. But when you step on a towel, get in a car, or walk on a clean carpet, sand falls off you. For days, you find sand on the floor when you take off your shoes and socks. Sand stays with you for a long time. I don't like sand.

**Lock and Key**  
People have always wanted a safe home. Long ago, they used a beam to lock the door. Now, we have electronic locks with many combinations. But people still like using a key. Some companies tried using smart cards to open doors, but people prefer keys at home. One company made a new electronic lock but also included a real metal key because people like it.

**Modern Art**  
I was worried about visiting the new Tate Modern gallery because I don't understand modern art. I like some things, like furry art, neon lights, and big photos. Maybe if I knew more, I would have more opinions. But art is not about understanding; it's about feeling. This idea is nice, but it doesn't work for me. The new gallery helps visitors understand art better. They have labels that explain the art and what it means. These labels helped me understand the art better.

**Every Picture Tells a Story**

When books are made into movies, a lot of the story is cut or changed. This can be hard for the writer, but it can also help them see new things. When I worked on a movie script, I noticed that I could remove a lot of the talking and details from the book, but still keep the main idea. This doesn't mean the book's details were not needed. It's about how each type of story, book or movie, needs different things to help the audience understand. In books, we often see repeated details about characters or who is speaking, which helps us understand better. In plays, the talking is more like real life, sometimes with extra words that don't add much meaning, just to show people are talking.

**Watching Movies**

When we watch movies, we can feel like we are part of the movie world. It's like escaping from real life for a while. But when the movie ends and the lights come on, we return to the real world. Some people used to think movies were just for fun and not real art. They liked watching them but didn't think they were important.

**The Film Studios**

The Leiper Film Company studios were a mix of many different buildings. It was hard to find your way around because there were many small rooms that looked the same. There were three main entrances, but only one led to where you wanted to go. It was confusing for new people, but the people who worked there knew their way. Together, they made movies that brought excitement and adventure to people.

**Film-makers**

Many people want to make movies. There are many books and courses on how to write scripts and make films. Some competitions give out cameras like the one Robert Rodriguez used to make his movie El Mariachi, which cost $7,000 and made him famous. He became successful very quickly. In the past, filmmakers took more time to learn their skills. They worked in different jobs like editing or writing before making their own movies. Now, without big studios to help, new filmmakers have to be more independent.

In those days, many council houses were on the west side of the city. They were in rows and looked old and dirty, made of orange bricks or white stucco. In the summer, chemicals from a factory two miles away made the air smell bad, like sulphur. In the morning, you could see paperboys making faces because of the smell as they delivered newspapers.

I don't remember much from my early life. But I do remember sitting near a window and looking at the houses as they disappeared into the distance. I also remember faces I can't name, my mother ironing towels in a house that might not have been ours, and snow falling on a big mansion at Earlham.

My mother is in many of my early memories. She was small, precise, and often angry, but I never knew why. Even as a child, I noticed she was different. She was the most alone person I knew, even in a room full of people. She liked things to be proper, which was unusual in our area. She would clean a lot and tell me to 'behave properly'. This meant not going into neighbors' gardens, sitting quietly with hands folded, and listening to her favorite radio shows. There were many rules to follow.

My mother had some friends, even though she liked being alone. There was Mrs. Buddery, who loved the Royal Family, Mrs. Winall, who didn't talk much, and Mrs. Laband, who was more lively. They often talked about their problems, like bad legs and the cold weather. I felt like I was part of their complaints about ungrateful children.

Growing up in West Earlham was predictable. Until age five, I stayed at home. I remember playing on a rug while my mother sat in a chair. After turning five, I went to Avenue Road infants school. Some kids had mothers with bikes to take them, but my mother let other children take me.

I remember summer holidays when I saw the world outside West Earlham. There was an old man next door who told stories about the Merchant Navy. Once, I went to a charity event where a woman gave out lemonade and talked about a junior charity called the League of Pity. My mother didn't like it and said they just wanted money.

My mother didn't trust politicians and thought they were greedy. She didn't have much kindness, but she cared about my education. Sometimes, she took me to the Norwich Castle Museum. We looked at paintings, and she even made a joke once about a Roman soldier painting, saying, "I wouldn't like to meet him on a dark night!"

**Philadelphia Avenue**

I walked down Philadelphia Avenue on the side with odd numbers. It was getting dark, and the air was thick and wet. It felt like I was walking quietly and secretly. I knew this side of the street very well. Our neighbors were the Matzes and the Pritchards. There was Han Kieffer's grocery store, and the houses of the Kring and Potts families, where my first friends, all girls, lived. I didn't know everyone by name, but each house was special to me. I remembered the little paths in the cement that took rain from the roofs to the street. I used to skate or ride my scooter over them. As the street went downhill, the houses got smaller, and the front yards were tiny. Over the years, things changed: wooden porches were replaced with iron ones. Some houses became stores, and some stores became homes again. I wondered how people lived in those spaces that used to be shops.

**Bachelor Fads**

Rick Gilbert is a furniture designer. He lives in a flat that used to be a curtain warehouse. The flat has big brick walls and huge doors. Rick didn't want an open space because it was hard to relax or work when everything was in one big room. So, he used a big plastic sheet to make a hallway and hide the office. This way, the kitchen is in the middle, and he can use it for cooking or making coffee. To make the flat feel warm, he used light wood for the floors and added furniture from his parents or markets.

**Bruce Chatwin**

Bruce Chatwin was a writer who loved to travel. His life was full of secrets and stories. His first book, "In Patagonia," came out in 1977. It was a travel book that changed how people wrote about travel. The book was exciting and full of imagination. Chatwin sometimes changed facts to make the stories better. He believed that through travel, you could find amazing stories from the past.

**Swimming**

One summer, it was raining hard, and I ran to the pool behind my house. I swam in the rain, watching each raindrop hit the water. The rain got heavier, and it felt like the pool was rising to meet the sky. In the summer of 1996, I thought about swimming across Britain. I wanted to follow the rain to the sea and escape the routine of swimming back and forth in a pool. Walking, cycling, and swimming help us feel free and explore places that are still wild and mysterious. A swimming journey would let me see parts of the world that are still full of mystery.

Text: 'CRYING Charles Darwin thought that crying did not have a clear purpose in evolution. He was probably wrong. Scientists now say crying is important for social reasons. Psychiatrist John Bowlby said crying helps mothers and children become close. Many people think children cry because they feel helpless. But why adults cry is harder to understand. The sound of crying is less important than what it shows. In early human groups, crying might have helped people trust each other and feel connected. Tears can also happen for other reasons. We might cry to show we care about people who suffer. Sometimes, we cry without wanting to, like when we hear beautiful music or speeches. We might cry during a sad movie, especially when we are with others. Crying seems to have a social purpose, but scientists are still studying it.'

**The Heat is On**

We all know about global warming, but how much warmer will the Earth get, and how will it change our lives? Many people have an idea of what global warming is, but we are not sure about what will happen because of it. A warmer climate will probably change the weather everywhere in the world. Since the air is connected to everything on Earth, changes in climate will affect plants, animals, water, and soil. Humans use these natural resources to grow food, build cities, and support billions of people. So, any changes to these resources are important.

The problem is knowing how the world will change and what is causing these changes. In the last 100 years, human actions have increased some gases in the air, which are linked to global temperature. These gases are likely affecting the climate now and will continue to do so. We know that greenhouse gases and global temperatures have changed together over the past 40,000 years, showing they are related. Evidence shows that the Earth's surface has warmed by about 0.6°C in the last century. Most scientists think this is not natural and is partly due to human pollution.

Scientists use computer programs called general circulation models (GCMs) to predict what will happen with higher global temperatures. These programs use physics and chemistry to study temperature, pressure, and other climate factors. However, they are not perfect and are expensive to use. We do not fully understand all climate processes, but we know the climate system is complex. Despite these challenges, most people agree that climate change will happen faster than before.

GCMs suggest that by the year 2100, the average global temperature will rise by 1°C to 3.5°C. The sea level will rise by 15-95 cm, and rainfall patterns will change. Scientists also expect more extreme weather, like heatwaves, floods, and droughts. These changes will affect the environment and humans. Climate change can change where forests and grasslands are, the species they have, and their benefits to humans. This includes food, water, and where people live. Some effects might be bad, but not all. Some changes could be good. For example, in Australia, warmer temperatures have helped wheat grow better since 1952.

However, many future effects of climate warming are not good. Small climate changes can affect water availability, especially in dry areas. The Mediterranean Basin is one example, where less rain has been seen in some parts. Rainfall is happening more in autumn and winter, and less in spring. Another problem is changes to ice. This will affect glaciers, sea ice, and wildlife. The Arctic ice might melt completely, which could help marine transport but also increase iceberg dangers.

The most visible effect of global warming might be rising sea levels. Warmer water takes up more space, and melting ice adds more water to the oceans. Many people live near coasts, so rising sea levels could cause serious problems. Cities like London, New York, and Tokyo could face flooding. Many people could lose their homes and become environmental refugees. Small island countries could disappear if the worst happens, which would be devastating for their people and culture.

Text: 'Mission to Mars Wanted: a middle-aged, married couple for a 501-day trip to Mars and back. Applicants must be strong and healthy, both physically and emotionally. This is the type of people needed for the first trip to Mars if millionaire Dennis Tito's plans work out. He wants to send a capsule on 5 January 2018. The capsule will take the crew to about 160 km above Mars. The spacecraft will use Mars's gravity to come back to Earth without using more fuel. Saving fuel is important because the next chance to go to Mars after 2018 is in 2031. It is a big challenge, but people are working hard to create new technology. If they succeed, the spacecraft might make it. Even if it doesn't, the work will help future space missions.'

**Aesthetics**

Sometimes, the way we think about art makes it hard to understand. Art is often seen as just a building, book, painting, or statue, separate from our experiences. But real art is about what it does to us when we experience it. Some art is so admired that it becomes hard to see it in new ways. When art becomes "classic," it can feel separate from the people and times that created it and from how it affects us today.

Art can seem like it's in a special world, away from other human activities. People who study art need to connect art with everyday life. Just like mountains are part of the earth, art is part of our experiences. To understand art, we might need to look away from it for a while and think about everyday experiences that we don't usually see as art.

We can enjoy flowers without knowing about plants, but to understand them, we need to learn about soil, air, water, and sunlight. The same goes for art. We should start with simple experiences that catch our attention and make us happy.

Today, many people enjoy things like movies, jazz, and comics without thinking of them as art. When art is only in museums, people find joy in everyday things around them. Some people think art is separate from daily life, but the best times for art are when it is connected to what we do every day.

**Observing Lions**

People often think of lions as amazing hunters. They imagine lions working together like a team to catch their food. In the evening, lions quietly move and surround their prey. Lions seem to be very social animals, working together for a common goal, which is to get their next meal. But after many years of watching lions in the wild, we have a different view. We started our research in 1978 to find out why lions hunt together, take care of their cubs, and scare away other animals with loud roars. If an animal's success is measured by how many of its young survive, then working together might not always be good. If an animal is too kind, others might take advantage of it. So, why do lions work together? We thought we would find the answer in two to three years. But lions are very good at doing nothing. It took us many different research methods to learn about their behavior. Wild lions can live up to 18 years, so we are only now starting to understand them.

**Pop Music Review**

Bedrock's third album was very important for the band. The album, called "New Life," changed rock music in the country for the next ten years. The old style of serious music with loud guitars was replaced by a lighter, more fun style. The album mixed social topics with fun sounds like fairground organs and brass bands. It had humor and irony, and the singers did not hide their accents. Bedrock showed they were good at collecting different styles and writing songs. They sang about things like sunbathing and Sunday afternoons. The album's real strength was in its deep, sad songs like "So Low" and "To the Brink." "New Life" had 16 great songs with no bad ones, which is rare for long CDs.

**Extract from an Autobiography**

As a child, I loved stories about "The Sibyl," wise women from ancient times. My mother told me a story about one Sibyl. She offered nine books to the King of Rome for 300 gold pieces. He said no, so she burned three books and offered the rest for the same price. He refused again, and she burned three more. He finally bought the last three for 300 gold pieces. I learned a lesson from this story about sales and life. I was often a lonely child. When I asked to play with other kids, they sometimes said no. My mother told me to do something so fun that other kids would want to join me. It worked, and I never forgot that lesson. When I got the chance to write a travel book, I wanted to find something interesting to me. I don't like traveling much, so I sent my editor a list of places I didn't want to go. I like to visit ruins because I enjoy thinking about the past.

**What Becomes of Your Manuscript?**

When you send your manuscript to a publisher, it usually goes into a big pile called the "slush pile." A junior editor or an experienced person who works part-time will look at it. They want to find something new and exciting. If they like your novel, they will give it to a senior editor. Then, it will be discussed in a meeting. The editor must explain why your novel is good and if it can sell well. They also want to know if you, as an author, can be successful in the long term. Publishers often want to meet new authors before making a deal.

**Advertising Challenges in the Early 1990s**

If you worked in advertising in the early 1990s, it was a tough time. The economy was bad, and the recession was worse than expected. In Britain, in 1991, the economy shrank, interest rates were high, people spent less money, many lost their jobs, and many homes were taken back by banks. Every business was affected, especially car and building companies, which lost 30% of their business. Many people and companies in different countries suffered.

Advertising people were not the only ones losing jobs, but those who kept their jobs felt a lot of pressure. They had to help companies make money with smaller budgets. They were told to do more with less money. At the same time, marketing became more important. Companies started to focus on making products that customers wanted, not just what was easy to make. This change made marketing more respected but also more challenging.

Marketing was seen as a solution to many problems, and a lot of money was spent on advertising. But in the 1990s, the advertising industry faced its worst time in many years. The bad economy made companies look closely at how much they spent on advertising. They wanted to know if it was worth the money. Many companies were not sure what they were getting back from their advertising spending.

Advertising was under more scrutiny than ever. Companies wanted better strategies, creativity, and media placement. They wanted the best people working hard for them. This meant advertising people had to do more with less, just like their clients.

Other challenges made advertising difficult. The recession made people worry about costs and taking risks. There were also changes in the population, more power for retailers, changing consumer needs, more sponsorships, stricter advertising laws, and the challenge of advertising in other countries.

These issues made companies think about how to make advertising work better. But finding help was hard. Companies and advertising agencies were busy dealing with these problems and did not share their secrets. Conferences and seminars gave some help, but books on advertising were not very useful. They often made advertising seem better than it was, which did not help people responsible for advertising in companies.

**The Lure of the Kitchen**

When I was at university, I decided I wanted to be a chef. This was not a common choice among my friends. Cooking was not a popular job. Being a chef is hard work: long hours, lots of pressure, and not much money. But I didn't care. I was not happy at university. The work was difficult, and the social life was not fun. Being a chef seemed like a good change. It felt more real and honest than my life at college. I also loved the idea of cooking. I first felt this when I ate at a famous restaurant in London. The meal was amazing. I remember the starter very well. After eating, I wanted to thank the chef. I felt happy for days. After that, I wanted to learn how to cook like that. I started to prepare for a career in cooking. My history degree felt unimportant. I learned about cooking by reading cookbooks, visiting markets, and making big meals.

**The Swimming Instructor**

The school's swimming teacher was a small, strong man with tattoos. He used to be a drill sergeant. I asked him to teach me how to dive. He told me to sit on the pool's edge, put my hands above my head, and roll forward. I practiced this for an hour. Next time, he had me stand and dive from the edge. He was very strict. Every time I came up from the water, he told me what I did wrong: 'Don't look down, look up!' 'Keep your legs straight.' 'Point your toes!' The next week, I went to the high diving board. It looked very high. I was scared but tried to be brave. I moved my arms like he taught me, looked up, and jumped. For a moment, I felt like I was flying. When I hit the water, my dive was not good. The instructor was not happy, but I felt great. I thought, 'This is what it means to be free like a bird.'

**The Traveller**

For people who like a comfortable bed and running water, travelers seem strange. These are people who like the unknown. They climb dangerous mountains, sail alone in small boats, and eat insects if needed. They live with the unknown every day. It is easy to think of them as odd, like hermits or writers. They live in a world different from ours. We can ignore them and go back to our safe lives with microwaves and phones, happy that our risks are small, like crossing a busy street.

**Sailing**

Jonathan Raban is afraid of the sea, but he spends a lot of time on it. He is not the best sailor, but he is good. He sails because he likes to write about it. Sailing gives him stories to tell. His boat has a device that shows his exact location. He likes this device, but he thinks other sea tools are not good. He believes the compass changed how people connect with the sea. Before the compass, sailors watched the waves and felt the sea. Now, they just follow the compass. The sea is now just a space to cross. Because of autopilots, sailors do not need to steer all the time. This gives Raban time to watch the waves closely.

**Holiday Reading**

Summer gives us two great joys: leaving home and reading books. These joys are connected. Books help us feel more at home in the world. We can see our own experiences in stories from long ago or far away. In books, we find our own thoughts and feelings. Authors can describe things we feel but cannot say. They write clearly about things we find confusing. This is amazing, especially if the book is from a different place or time. We feel thankful to these writers for helping us understand ourselves.

Reading and traveling help us escape our daily routine. When we are in a new place, we notice everything. The same happens when we read a great book. It helps us see things we ignored before. We start to notice the sky, people's faces, or feelings we didn't know we had.

**Author's Note**

These travel stories were first in the Observer newspaper over seven years. I made some small changes, but not many. I fixed a few mistakes. For example, in a story about China, I thought the Hong Kong dollar would stay strong, but it fell later. I didn't change the story to predict this because it was written at that time. Like other travelers, I was there, not knowing what would happen next.

Traveling by plane lets people see the world, even if they know little about it. I believe travelers notice things. Even a postcard can have a purpose.

**Ecotourism**

The word 'ecotourism' is often misused. It started in the 1980s when people became more aware of the environment. Tour operators saw that travelers wanted to travel without harming nature. Now, 'ecotourism' can mean many things, like living with remote tribes or a short boat trip. It includes cultural interaction, nature, wildlife, or adventure. The original idea was to help people make good choices, but without clear rules, travelers can get confused.

**Transylvanian Journey**

I lost my notebook from my trip to Transylvania for 50 years. I found it again by luck. It helped me remember that time, but I didn't write much then. I stayed in friendly homes for weeks and stopped writing. I thought there was nothing to write about. When I moved, I wrote only short notes. I worried about the order of events when writing this book, but then I decided it didn't matter. I let the story tell itself.

**Fashion**

Fashion is not just a modern thing. It did not start only in the 1800s and 1900s with big businesses. Fashion, which means style and design, has been around for a long time. Historians say fashion began to grow in the 1500s and 1600s when people started trading more. As societies grew bigger and more complex, people found new ways to make different clothes and accessories. This made the meanings of clothes more complex too. Today, it is hard to say exactly what any piece of clothing means. For example, a man's suit can mean different things to different people and in different situations.

**Writer**

People often think that all writers are rich and famous because of stories about publishers fighting over new books. But for most writers, life is not like that. Many writers have other jobs during the day and write in the evenings. This way, they have a steady job even if their book does not become a hit. Some writers, like me, do different small jobs to make money. We might teach, run workshops, or write articles. I once heard about a writing job at a chocolate factory, but I never got it. Still, by doing part-time jobs and with help from friends, I manage to write my novels.

**Sudden Fame**

Our small shows around the country started to sell out, and we needed more security to handle the many excited fans. We had to use secret ways to enter the places we played to avoid being surrounded by fans. On nights when we were not performing, it was hard to go out without being followed by fans. In just a few days, we became famous. Our fans watched everything we did, and our managers took care of all our needs. Even though I was always shy, I started to feel strangely confident. But I was still not used to being famous.

**Music - The Future Ahead**

Technology is changing how we live, work, and have fun. Susan Hallam talks about how this affects music in Britain. In the late 20th century, people had more ways to listen to music, like radio, TV, records, tapes, CDs, and videos. But, there were fewer live music shows and jobs for musicians. Music is important for many reasons. Big events in the country always have music. For people, music is part of many activities. A world without music is hard to imagine. The question is not if there will be music in the future, but what kind of music it will be. Also, will people still want to learn to play instruments? I think they will. The music industry makes a lot of money in Britain. Musical skills are important for many jobs, especially in media. Playing an instrument can also help people learn other skills. In the USA, research shows that music can help with thinking skills. In Europe, studies show that group music lessons can help children with social skills and focus. Playing an instrument might also help people learn good study habits and be organized. Because of these reasons, people will still want to learn instruments.

In the future, music might change in two ways. First, people will listen to many different types of music. New styles will mix different kinds of music. Second, technology will help people make and play music. This will make it easier for people to create music, but there might be less need for live performances. More people of all ages might want to make music together in their communities. This will show the music traditions of each community.

To prepare for this future, music teaching needs to change. More people should be able to learn different instruments throughout their lives. Music lessons and tests will need to change to stay important for more people. Musicians will need to learn new skills to teach and inspire people of all ages. They will need to work with big groups and learn communication and management skills. This is a big change from how things are now. It will also mean showing the public how good music teaching is. We need to make music more important in our lives. Music is very important, but people often forget this. Everyone in the music world needs to work together to change this.

**The Actor's Craft**

Sometimes people make fun of actors. This happens because actors often talk about their work in interviews. They should be like the dancer Pavlova, who said, "If I could tell you, I wouldn't dance it." But instead, actors often use big words or talk about gossip. Paul Scofield, a famous actor, said that acting is interesting only when you do it, not when you talk about it. Each play is new, and actors learn from the characters and the writer. When a play ends, actors feel empty until the next one starts. Talking about acting can feel empty too.

**A Review of Hamlet**

Adrian Lester plays Hamlet as a young man between boyhood and manhood. His performance is simple and confident. He understands the text well and controls his body and mind. Lester plays a young man who is a bit angry but also funny and lovable. His acting is very good, even if it looks simple. When you watch him, you see how he uses his body to show his character. This makes you think about what acting really is. Is it copying real life or creating something new? This is an important question in theatre.

**One Director's Approach to Rehearsal**

This director starts rehearsals with a method called "dropping in." The stage manager shows the script on a screen. Actors listen quietly when others speak. When it's their turn, they read the line, think about what it means, and then speak. For example, if the line is "Queuing all night, the rain, do you remember?" they breathe, imagine the scene, and then speak. The director says not to plan too much. Just be open and trust that something will happen.

**The Perfect Theatre**

The perfect theatre makes you feel like you matter. Going to the theatre is special, and the staff should feel that too. The theatre should connect the actors and the audience. Everyone should be able to see and hear well. The size of the theatre is important. It should fit the human voice and body. Some old theatres did this well. They feel like they have history, like old church steps. You can't please everyone with a play. People don't always know what they want to see. When you go to the theatre, you want to see something surprising. Otherwise, you could just stay home.

**Paul Simon and Rock and Roll**

In the 1950s, rock and roll was very popular with young people. But it also changed the lives of older people and the middle class. It helped create new rock stars. These new stars listened to rock and roll and knew it would be important for their future. Paul Simon, like many young people in the US, heard this exciting music on Alan Freed's radio show, Moondog Rock'n'Roll Party. This show was very important for young people who wanted to be rock stars. Just like John Lennon in Liverpool, who listened to Radio Luxembourg, Paul Simon loved the music from Freed's show. He wanted to stop just listening and start making his own music.

**Snow Adventure**

There was no clear path, but I thought I could walk safely if I was careful. The wind was strong and pushed me down as I slipped on the ice. Suddenly, the snow under me broke, and I fell into a hole about four feet deep. The snow had covered a gap between two rocks, and I fell through the thin layer. I climbed out, feeling scared and thinking about what I would do if the hole was deeper. I sat against a pine tree sticking out of the snow to think about my situation. In one hour, I had only walked half a mile. I knew I had to change my plan.

**Qualitative Research**

There are many books that help researchers with qualitative research. These books talk a lot about how to collect data, but not much about how to analyze it. Many people find data analysis confusing. So, we asked different social scientists to talk about how they analyze data. We wanted to share ideas and understanding about this process, not just make a guidebook. This means making hidden steps more clear. This sounds easy, but it is not. We let our contributors show their work in different ways, like personal stories or more formal writing.

**Screen Learning**

A few days ago, I saw my six-year-old eating noodles in a funny way. He was pulling them up with his teeth and trying to look fierce. "I'm a little dinosaur," he said. He was acting like a scene from a TV show. I asked him what he remembered about dinosaurs, but he didn't remember much. Many people are excited about learning on the internet and computers, but is learning from a screen good? One writer tried an interactive program with his son. The father read the words, but the son played with the pictures. The father thought, "If he spent ten minutes with a book, he might have learned something." TV, like my son and his noodles show, gives ideas but not always facts. Research says learning happens best when talking with teachers or parents. New technology can help teach children, but schools are still important.

**Hollywood**

By 1918, most of the world's film-making moved to Hollywood. Local people didn't like it at first, but they accepted it because it was successful. Success in Hollywood means making money at the box office. Hollywood knows a good film when it sees one: it might make a star, but it must make money. In less than 100 years, Hollywood grew from a small village to a famous town like New York, Rome, or Paris. A century ago, you could walk through orange groves to the village store. Now, it is still like a village with one main topic: films. People talk about how much money films make, who is dating whom, and who is working on which project. Successful people often try to live somewhere else but work in Hollywood. It is the place where everyone in show-business wants to be.

**Photography**

Photography was invented in the 1800s by artists. They wanted to keep a lasting picture of what they saw. They used light, lenses, and chemicals to make images that were more real and detailed than paintings. Some artists were worried because photography was so different. Critics said photography was not art because it used machines. But photographers knew they had found a new way to show the world. They used cameras like other artists use brushes and pencils to show nature and people.

**Book Illustration**

In the past, every children's book had illustrations. This was also true for many novels for older readers. Children's publishing was busy, but it often had low budgets. This meant some work was not very good, but the best artists always did their best. The black-and-white illustrations from this time are a mix of good and bad work. They are interesting for research or just looking. The best works will be shown again, either in new books or exhibitions. Some publishers might make new editions of classic children's book illustrations from this time.

**Blogging: Sharing with the World**

Some time ago, a website talked about the dangers of telling everyone online where you are. The website's message was clear: when you say, "Hey, I'm at this place," you are also telling everyone, including people you might not want to meet. This shows that sharing too much online can be risky. The internet lets us share everything about our lives with many people, which can be exciting. We might think we can become rich or famous. So, we start sharing our secrets, photos, and stories online. But soon, we realize it can be dangerous and confusing.

This might sound sad, but don't worry. There is a way to understand this new world. A long time ago, some people started sharing their lives online. They learned about the problems and dangers before social media existed. These people, called bloggers, have already experienced what we are going through now. We can learn from their stories.

In January 1994, a 19-year-old student named Justin Hall started sharing his life on the internet. Back then, the internet was mostly used by students and scientists. Hall saw it as a chance to share his life. He wrote about his life and shared photos and art. In 1996, he started a daily blog, and many people read it. Hall shared everything, and nothing was off-limits. It was like art, but one day, his blog disappeared. He posted a video called "Dark Night" and explained that he had fallen in love. He was told, "either the blog goes, or I do." He learned that sharing too much online can make people not trust you. He stopped blogging, but the problem of sharing too much online is still here.

In 2002, Heather Armstrong had a blog called Dooce. She wrote about her job, and one day, someone at work shared her blog with her bosses. She lost her job because of it. This shows that we often say things online that we wouldn't say in person. Our online lives are connected to our real lives, and pretending they are separate can lead to big mistakes.

Armstrong's story ended well. She stopped blogging for a while but later started again, writing about her family. Now, she is a successful "mommy blogger," and her blog helps support her family. She learned that just because we can say anything online doesn't mean we should.

**Enough Sleep?**

Many people today feel tired all the time. In busy and rich countries, people often cannot sleep well and feel worried. In the USA, 40 million people have serious sleep problems. In Britain, some popular books talk about people who cannot sleep or about places where sleep is studied. 

People are very interested in sleep. They want to know about sleep patterns, why we need sleep, and what happens when we cannot sleep. A sleep expert says, "People need more sleep. They sleep less when they are busy and wake up early to avoid traffic." 

A sleep researcher did an experiment. He let people sleep up to 14 hours a night for a month. It took them three weeks to sleep about eight hours a night. This shows they needed more sleep than they were getting.

In Europe, a university in the English Midlands studies sleep. They look at how tiredness affects sailors, how noise affects sleep, and how dangerous it is to drive when tired. They find people to study by advertising in student newspapers. These people are paid and asked to change their sleep patterns. Dr. Louise Reyner says some people worry because they put electrodes on their heads, but they only study physical things.

In a dark room, there is a car simulator. People come at 2 pm, when they are naturally sleepy, after a short or no sleep. They drive while answering questions. The road looks endless, the sun is bright, and the air is warm. Many say they will not fall asleep, but they do. Dr. Reyner has a video of one person trying not to sleep. At first, he is awake, but then he starts to blink and nod off. The car goes off the road. Coffee can help. Dr. Reyner says two cups can make you a safe driver for a short time. She suggests using tablets, energy drinks, and caffeinated gum, especially for people who work at night.

We know some things about sleep. Humans sleep in cycles like other animals. When we sleep, we go through four stages, from light to deep sleep. We dream in the lightest sleep, and the brain stops the body from moving to prevent injuries. Scientists think women sleep half an hour longer than men, and older people need less sleep, but they do not know why.

In the past, people had different sleep patterns. A history professor found that between 1500 and 1850 in Britain, people went to bed at nine or ten, woke up after midnight, stayed awake for an hour, and then slept again. This time was used for thinking, remembering dreams, or even stealing. Poor people liked this quiet time because they were free from work. By the 17th century, with more light, rich people started sleeping like we do now. The industrial revolution made people work longer hours, changing sleep patterns for everyone.

In some places outside Europe and America, the old sleep pattern was common until recently. In some non-western societies, there are no strict bedtimes. People sleep for a few hours, wake up, and then sleep again. Continuous sleep is not possible because of noise, watching fires, and looking out for danger. It seems people everywhere need more sleep.

I was wearing very expensive cowboy boots, standing on rocks in the Arizona desert. I had a full cowboy outfit, but I knew I wasn't a real cowboy. I flew in from Denver early in the morning and thought I might look like a cowboy. But when I saw a real cowboy at the Phoenix airport, I knew I didn't fit in. He wore a dirty shirt and carried a bag, and he looked at my new boots and walked away.

I used to be a racing driver, and I loved it. But I don't race anymore. I wondered what I should do now. I thought I could talk about races on TV, but many other drivers wanted to do that too. I also tried to sell classic cars, but it didn't work out.

Being an "ex" racing driver is hard. People don't want to hear about how I almost became a world champion. Even if I was a champion, people would only listen for a short time. I miss racing cars, the speed, and the excitement. I miss being famous and having people want my autograph.

Now, I have a lot of free time. I looked at the sky and saw some birds in a cactus. They seemed to tell me to leave them alone. I realized I had a lot to learn about life outside of racing.

**Vancouver**

In the last ten years, many people from all over the world have moved to Vancouver, in western Canada. In the evening, people like to walk on the city streets. If you walk with them, you will hear many different languages. People come to Vancouver because it has a mild climate, beautiful views of the ocean and mountains, a clean and safe environment, and good schools and jobs. Some people complain about the new buildings, but the new people and tourists have helped the city grow. Vancouver was once called 'Terminal City' because it was a gateway to other places. Now, it is more of a gateway than ever.

**Putting Pen to Paper**

Journalists, like me, are usually not good at writing letters. Some say it's because we don't like writing for free, but I don't think that's true. It's more likely because we try hard to make our writing have a big impact, so writing a simple letter is difficult for us. Real artists, who don't think about the effect of their words, don't have this problem. I think a real artist knows how to use words well. When Shakespeare wrote his famous lines, he probably didn't think about why they were so good, but they showed he was a great writer.

**Supermarket Opening**

In the past, opening a new supermarket in Britain was a big event. A soap star, a disc jockey, or a minor royal would come to cut the ribbon. Now, new supermarkets open so often that famous people are not needed. Why pay a celebrity when anyone can open it for free? Last week, people waiting to enter a new Superbuy didn't care who opened it, as long as they were first in line. The first five men would get a bottle of aftershave, and the first five women would get flowers. This news spread quickly, making those at the front feel happy and those at the back feel jealous.

**Citizen Kane**

The film "Citizen Kane" came out in 1941. There was a lot of talk about it before it was released because people were worried about William Randolph Hearst, who the film was said to be about. Even though the reviews were very good, the film did not make much money at first. It was television that made it popular again. "Citizen Kane" is a film that has inspired many people to become filmmakers. This is surprising because it was Orson Welles's first film. Welles said the film was successful because he did not know what he could or could not do, so he just did what he wanted. He had a great team, including cameraman Gregg Toland, screenwriter Herman J. Mankiewicz, and special-effects expert Linwood Dunn. Welles and Mankiewicz decided to make a film about a newspaper owner who was like Hearst. Welles thought this was a great chance for him to be both the director and the actor, so he worked very hard on it.

**Dermot and Carmel**

Dermot thought Carmel was acting a bit strange that morning. He told her twice that he might be late and might stop at the golf club on his way home. He needed to talk to someone, and the golf club was the best place for it. Carmel nodded her head but seemed like she didn't really hear or understand. Dermot asked her if she would be okay and what she planned to do that day. Carmel smiled and said it was funny he asked because she had nothing to do, so she planned to walk downtown and look at the shops. She thought it was almost wrong to just spend the day doing nothing. Dermot smiled back and said she deserved to enjoy herself. He also said if he was late, he wouldn't need anything to eat, so she shouldn't worry about making dinner. Carmel said that was fine.

**Title Race**

A recent study showed that job titles can cause jealousy and problems at work. A survey by a big recruitment company found that 90% of employers and 70% of employees agree that job titles can create divisions among workers. Surprisingly, the survey found that 70% of office workers would rather have a better job title than a pay raise. This shows that people care a lot about their job titles. In today's world, nobody wants to be seen as less important. The job titles being discussed focus on skills (like specialist or coordinator) but are really just nicer ways to say the same thing.

I was in Vienna to take photos. Taking photos was not just my job; it was a big part of my life. I loved how light looked on things and how one photo could show the feeling of a place or a person. I always hoped to take the perfect photo. As long as I had film in my camera, I kept looking for that moment. 

Once, I took a photo of smoke from a burning oil well, and it became very famous. It was on the cover of many newspapers and magazines. After that, I decided to work for myself. But things didn't go as well as I hoped. The mid-1990s were not as successful as I thought they would be. That's why I was in Vienna, not somewhere more exciting. But I was still taking photos and getting paid for it, which was good.

I got the Vienna job by chance. I had taken photos of London for a book called "Four Cities in Four Seasons." The book also included Paris, Rome, and Vienna. The Austrian photographer, Rudi Schussner, left the job in Vienna, so they asked me to do it. The Austrian publishers liked my work, and I was available, unlike the other photographers. I was happy to go because things at home were not good.

They put me in a hotel in the center of Vienna. I had been to Vienna before with my wife, but it was a busy and hot trip. This time, in January, it was cold and different. I knew I would enjoy it and take great photos. 

On the first day, I didn't take any photos. I rode the trams around the city to feel its mood. The weather was cold and the city was beautiful. I wanted to make this Vienna my own, not like the other photographer's work. I waited for the right moment to take photos.

The next morning, I went out early. It had snowed, and the city was quiet and white. I wanted to take a photo of the cathedral, but it was hard to fit it all in one picture. Still, I knew it could be magical. Photography has always felt magical to me. Even when you know how it works, it still feels mysterious. That's why what happened that morning in Vienna didn't really surprise me.

**Kinetic Art Exhibition**

Something amazing has happened at London's Hayward Gallery. It has changed from a serious place to one full of wonder. This change is not because of a big, expensive show, but because of a special exhibition about kinetic art. Kinetic art is art that moves or shows movement. This exhibition looks at the history of kinetic art over the last 60 years. It shows that making art that moves has been important, even if not many people noticed it before. The exhibition has many paintings, drawings, documents, and films about kinetic art. Guy Brett, who has studied this art for a long time, put it all together. There are not many explanations, so visitors can enjoy discovering things on their own.

**David Hockney**

David Hockney's art is liked by many people, even those who usually do not care about art. People might like his work because it is easy to understand or because it shows fun and relaxing things. Some people might like Hockney because he is a fun person and good for news stories. Some critics think Hockney is not a great artist. But maybe he seems less important because he is very popular, not because his work is bad. Hockney knows he is not a great artist and thinks only time will tell how important his work is.

**Window-shopping - An Art Exhibition**

I have seen many art exhibitions, some good and some not so good. Sometimes exhibitions try to show a common idea among artists, but it does not always work. I wanted to make a different kind of show. With seven artists, I used a space in an empty warehouse. The show was called 'Window-shopping.' It was a collection of different artworks that were only connected because they were all art. For example, Sam Cole's knitted cats moved around on a toy train track. Matthew Crawley broke a video camera, and it flickered on a screen. These works were very different, but they worked well together. I did not try to make a big statement about art, but I think art is something personal where artists decide what they want to do.

**Art History**

Some people who like paintings do not want to analyze them because they think it will ruin their enjoyment. Some art historians focus more on theory than on the pleasure of looking at art. This is like thinking that knowing how a dish is made will make it taste less good. But knowing more about art can make it more enjoyable. Our enjoyment of art is also influenced by the society we live in. While enjoying art is important, thinking about it does not have to take away from the experience.

**Metals**

A long time ago, people in the Stone Age might have been interested in metals because they wanted to look nice. Imagine sitting by a river, waiting to catch a fish, and finding a shiny yellow stone. This stone was gold. It was not like other stones; it was soft and pretty. People liked it very much. Gold became important to them. Copper was another metal they found, maybe by accident. When they saw how useful copper tools were, they looked for more copper. They learned how to take copper from rocks. This is how metalworking started and helped people live better lives.

**St Ives**

We walked down a narrow, stone street with our bags. The wind was very strong, and the waves were cold and big. No one was outside, and all the houses by the water were closed up tight. We saw the weather get worse as we arrived in St Ives on a small train. The sky was dark and grey. Visiting Cornwall in the winter without a car did not seem like a good idea anymore. I told my friend we would have nice walks by the sea and warm evenings by the fire.

**Computer Modelling**

Studying the past is hard because it is gone. The people who lived in good and bad times are not here anymore. We do not know why they moved or stayed in places. Archaeology gives us some ideas, but we cannot test them. We cannot see the past again. But maybe we can. With computer modelling, we can make old landscapes and put digital people in them. These digital people act a bit like real people. We can change things like rain or the number of people and see how they react.

**Vervet Monkeys**

Cheney and Seyfarth studied vervet monkeys. One day, the leader male monkey saw a new male monkey near their trees. The new monkey wanted to join the group. If he joined, the leader might lose his position. The leader monkey had a clever idea to keep the new monkey away. When the new monkey tried to come closer, the leader made a loud call that means a leopard is near. The new monkey got scared and went back to his trees. This happened many times. But then, the leader made a mistake. He made the leopard call while he was walking calmly on the ground. 

**What Cats Catch**

In a village in England, people counted what their cats caught. In one year, 70 cats caught over 1,000 animals. An American professor thought that if all cats in Britain caught the same, they would catch 100 million birds and small animals each year. But this is not true because most cats live in towns and catch less. The important question is if the number of animals caught is too much. The answer seems to be no. In winter, people feed birds, and there are many places for birds to live. The survey showed that cats catch many animals, but they are not destroying the bird population in Britain.

**Buffalo's Day**

Buffaloes are very important to marsh people. Every morning, buffaloes leave their sleeping place slowly and make loud noises. They go to the reed beds in the water. They stand at the edge, making noises about how tired they are. Then, the leader buffalo goes into the water, and the others follow. They move slowly and seem very tired, but they swim to the reeds. They spend the day there, eating green plants.

**PICASSO, Pablo**

In 1940, Picasso painted fish while he was in a fishing town called Royan. The painting shows a fish seller's table with a crab and some fish. The fish look like they are still alive. The painting is hard to understand because Picasso used flat shapes and soft colors. It looks calm, like an underwater world. But there is also a feeling of danger. The fish and crab look like they might fight. The sharp shapes in the painting make it feel tense.

**Photography**

For the last 150 years, photography has been used to capture all parts of human life. In this short time, photography has grown to show us moments in time and space. It lets us see quick moments and both big and small things. Photography has shown us pictures from faraway places on Earth and even from space. It also shows us the complex and difficult parts of modern life. Photography is a very important way to show what it means to be human.

But, using pictures to record events is much older. The first pictures go back to about 35,000 years ago. We do not know exactly why early people made cave paintings. They might show real hunting events, be used for magic to help with hunting, be religious symbols, or just to make places look nicer. Pictures are a big part of human culture.

People have always asked if pictures show the truth and what their role in society is. Many people believe that "seeing is believing," so pictures have always been important. When photography was invented in the 1800s, it was thought to give a true picture of the world. The camera was seen as a tool that works like the human eye, giving a fixed image that looks like what we see. This made photography a big achievement in culture, creating images that artists worked hard to make by hand.

Some people thought everyone could understand photos, like a "universal language." In 1933, photographer August Sander said even people far away could understand a photo of the sky. But as global communication grew, we need to ask if photos can be understood the same way by everyone. Is photography like language, shaped by culture? Do we take photos for granted and not see how they show reality?

Photography is seen as giving clear evidence, making it seem like a simple way to communicate. It is common for someone to show a photo and say, "this is my grandson." Since its invention in 1839, photography and how people use it have changed a lot. Photos have moved from being just memories to historical documents. They show us about the people and society that made them.

I want to show that the camera is not just a quiet recorder of events. Photography can help bring social and political change. For example, the Italian Renaissance in the 1400s changed how people saw the world with new ways of showing perspective. Photography has helped create the media culture we have today and shows the tough realities of the world.

**How to Write Poetry**

Writing poetry can be tricky. It's like walking through a dangerous area where you have to be careful. There are no strict rules, but you need to read a lot, write a lot, and let your imagination be free. Some people need to feel safe to write a poem, while others write when they are sad. Some people write at certain times, and others wait for inspiration. All these ways are okay as long as you are true to yourself. It's important to listen to your inner voice and let it grow.

**The Short Story**

In a short story, you can't have too many characters or long descriptions. Flashbacks should be short and only used if necessary. A character's memory can help move the story forward. Dialogue, or conversation between characters, is very useful. It can show different sides of a story quickly and keep the reader interested. A short story should not have too many words, but it should still have conflict and action. Every word should be important.

**Screenplays**

Writing a screenplay is like playing chess. At first, you might not know what will happen next, but you learn as you go. In chess, you need a long-term plan, not just short moves. The more you play, the more you understand the game. Screenwriting is similar; you need to see the whole story, not just parts of it.

**Looking at Writing**

Speaking is natural for humans, but writing is not. All people speak, but not everyone writes. Writing systems were created by a few advanced societies and improved over time. In the past, many children did not learn to read or write. Even today, some children find it hard. Children naturally learn to speak, but writing is something they have to learn with effort. We need to understand how writing works and how children learn it.

I have never started writing a book with more doubt. I call it a novel because I don't know what else to call it. I don't have much of a story to tell, and I don't end with a death or a marriage. Instead, I leave the reader wondering. This book is about my memories of a man I met only a few times, and I don't know much about what happened to him in between. I could make up things to fill the gaps and make the story clearer, but I don't want to do that. I just want to write what I know. To avoid embarrassing people who are still alive, I have changed the names of the people in this story, and I have made sure no one can recognize them. The man I am writing about is not famous. Maybe he never will be. When he dies, he might not leave any mark on the world, like a stone thrown into a river leaves no mark on the water. If anyone reads my book, it will be because they find it interesting. But maybe the way he lived and his strong and kind character will influence others, and people will realize he was special. Then, people who want to know about his early life might find something useful in my book. I think my book will be helpful to people who want to write about my friend. I don't claim that the conversations I wrote are exactly what was said. I never took notes, but I remember well, and I believe I have written them truthfully. I said earlier that I have not made up anything, but I have added some conversations to make the story more lively. I want people to read my book, and I think it's okay to make it interesting. Smart readers will know where I have added things, and they can choose to ignore them. Another reason I was worried about writing this book is that the people I write about are from another culture. It is hard to really know people from a different country. People are shaped by where they were born, the games they played, the food they ate, and the schools they went to. You can't know these things just by hearing about them; you have to live them. Because of this, it is hard to make people from another country seem real in a book. I have only written about people from my own country before, and if I wrote about others in short stories, it was because you can be brief. You give the reader a general idea and let them imagine the rest. In this book, I don't pretend my characters see themselves as I see them; they are seen through my eyes.

**Poetry Recitals**

In every time in history, the world of literature can seem confusing to people living in it. Over time, we can see patterns and understand which writers are important. Today, there are many different styles of poetry and ideas about what poetry should be. Some poets write poems to be read in books, while others like to perform their poems in front of people. 

This difference is not always clear. In the last twenty years, public poetry readings have become more popular. Small groups in towns have poetry events in local halls or homes. Schools and colleges invite poets to read to students. Arts festivals often have poetry readings by famous poets. 

These events have different effects on poets. For poets who write simple poems to perform, public readings are good. Their poems are easy to understand when heard once. But for poets who work hard to create deep and complex poems, it can be hard for audiences to appreciate their work in a single hearing. These poets might choose to read their simpler poems to connect with the audience quickly.

Listening to poetry is not the same as reading it. Hearing poets read their work can help people understand the poems better. It is good if the audience can read along or know the poems before the reading. 

The main reason for popular poetry readings, sometimes mixed with music, is to make people enjoy poetry. This way, people see poetry as fun and not just for a special group of people.

**Oral History**

Historians are using more oral evidence, but it has problems. When someone tells their story, it is not always a clear picture of the past. During an interview, both the historian and the person talking can affect each other. The historian chooses who to talk to and what to talk about. Even if the historian just listens, their presence can change how the person remembers and talks about the past. The final story is influenced by the historian's position and how they understand history. Historians help create new evidence, so they must be careful. Also, the person talking is not directly connected to the past. Their memories can be mixed with things they heard from other places, like TV. They might remember the past as better than it was or feel upset about things that happened later. Feelings and attitudes can make a story seem true, but they might come from later events, not the past.

**Animal Science**

There are two main ways to study animals: looking at how their bodies work and looking at their behavior. Physiologists study how nerves, muscles, and senses work together to create behavior. People who study the whole animal look at the animal's behavior and what affects it. In this group, psychologists and ethologists are different. Psychologists usually work in labs with animals like rats and pigeons to see how they learn. Ethologists study animals' natural behavior, often in the wild. These two groups are now working more together. Physiologists think their methods are very important. But even if we know how every nerve cell works, we still need to study behavior as a whole. Behavior has its own way of being organized. Describing a bird building a nest by looking at nerve cells is like trying to read a book with a microscope.

**The Social Sciences**

When students start studying social science, they have two jobs. They need to learn about the subject and how to study it. They must know the facts and research in the books and also understand how this knowledge is found and organized. These two parts are connected. We all know about social life from daily life, so social sciences might seem like common sense. But social sciences go beyond common sense. Each social science looks at a different part of social life, uses different study methods, and has its own ideas. These basic ideas help social scientists go beyond everyday understanding and make each subject different.

**Classical Architecture**

In Ancient Greece and Rome, architecture was more than just building. The Roman architect Vitruvius said architecture is about order, arrangement, proportion, symmetry, and distribution. He used some Greek words for these ideas, which came from an earlier Greek source we don't have now. Vitruvius did not include utility and function in his definition, but he did talk about the best ways to build for different uses. At the start, the focus was on beauty and art. Classical architecture has a complex history. Before, there were simple huts in Greece and Italy that did not meet Vitruvius' artistic standards. These simple forms were important and influenced later architecture. Even if a classical temple looks fancy, it is basically a simple, single-room hut.

The two sisters, Lily and Mui, kept Lily's driving a secret from Chen for a while. Lily would drive around the area, going over a small bridge with a bump, which was her only mistake. She finished her drive near the gasworks, where it smelled like sulphur. When Chen found out, he was amused and not upset. He was happy that Lily could drive and started planning a trip with her. They decided to go on a Monday at the start of next month, leaving early and coming back by midday to avoid losing customers. Lily practiced driving in the meantime.

Mui, even though she was worried, bought a road map and got a discount, which impressed Chen. Lily felt a bit hurt that Mui didn't trust her navigation skills. They left home and soon reached the English Channel. Lily drove very well, and even Mui, who was ready to give directions, had to admit it. Lily overtook some slow cars with great skill, and Chen even clapped for her.

They arrived at a seaside town and parked in a street with empty parking spaces. Lily wasn't sure about the road signs, so she paid to park to avoid any trouble. She locked the van carefully. Chen joked that no one would want their old van, which annoyed the sisters. Lily and Mui told Chen he was being ungrateful and too proud.

Chen took their son, Man Kee, to see the sea. He decided that Man Kee would have a good education and own many restaurants one day. The sea made Chen feel thoughtful as he planned Man Kee's future. He saw a ship in the distance and used a telescope to look at it. He showed Man Kee the ship and told him it was special, like them, and would take them home one day.

Lily and Mui joined them, and Lily tried to look through the telescope, but it had stopped working. By the time Chen found another coin, the ship was gone, and Lily only saw seagulls.

Title: The Well

I read that if you look from a deep hole, you can see stars during the day. I wanted to try this, so I asked you to help me. You watched as I pulled up the well bucket and climbed in. I asked you to lower me down. I didn't think about how heavy the bucket would be or that you might not be strong enough to hold it. You tried to hold the handle, but I fell into the well. I hit my head and saw strange lights. Later, I realized they looked like stars in cartoons when someone gets hit.

At first, I was confused, then scared, then relieved. I was also angry at you for letting me fall and worried about what Mother would say. You called down to ask if I was okay. I wanted to shout back, but you sounded scared, so I stayed quiet. You ran to get help. I climbed out of the well and hid in the shadows. I heard voices from the castle. Mother and Father came with you and Arthur. Mother was upset, and Father told Arthur to use the winch. You looked shocked.

I felt excited but then saw the wet spots I left on the ground. I was scared they would see them. Father was looking into the well with a flashlight. Mother was screaming, and I felt guilty. I wanted to get back at you, but now I was in trouble. I realized my plan was not smart. I needed a new plan.

I came out of hiding, pretending to be weak. I told them I found a secret tunnel from the well to the moat and crawled out. I thought they believed me until Father asked me to repeat the story.
