This way, they would always have a connection to New Zealand, where their father grew up. They found land about 20 miles north of Auckland, in a place called Rangitoupuni. The land wasn't very good, but it was okay for planting trees.

Jonathon loved the idea because he was interested in land. He had worked in Australia on sheep farms and liked farming jobs. He started planting trees in 1968, and by 1972, he and his siblings had planted trees on all 70 acres.

In 1968, it rained a lot in New Zealand. Even though it was wet and cold, Jonathon remembers it as a happy time. Every morning, he got ready to plant trees, even though his clothes were wet from the day before. He worked with an experienced tree-planter, which helped him learn.

Planting trees was hard work. He carried a bag full of trees and had to plant them in straight lines. He enjoyed the physical work and got very fit. After a while, he got used to the rhythm of planting: taking a tree from the bag, digging a hole, putting the tree in, and moving on.

While planting, he had time to think about life and nature. These thoughts became important to him later. He has visited New Zealand four times since then and watched the trees grow. He feels a strong connection to the land and worries when he hears about bad weather in New Zealand.

In 1984, he took time off from teaching to go back to New Zealand alone. He stayed in a small cabin on the tree farm and wrote his first book, "Seeing Green." He wrote in the mornings, pruned trees in the afternoons, and did research in the evenings. He feels a strong bond with that place, as it connects him to the earth.

**Bringing Up Badgers**

"What now?" I thought when a helper handed me a cardboard box. My husband Derek and I have an open farm in Somerset, where we care for orphaned animals. Inside the box, I found three small grey badger cubs, each about eight inches long. Their fur was soft like velvet, and they had milky-colored eyes. I had never seen badger cubs before. Most are born between January and March and stay underground. If they lose their mother, they often die from hunger.

These cubs were found by builders who accidentally dug into their home. The mother was dead, and the cubs were still with her. They were healthy but cold and crying. After cleaning them, I put them by the stove in our kitchen to keep warm. There were two females, Primrose and Bluebell, and a male, Willow. I fed them with a syringe and used a warm cloth to clean them, like their mother would. This helped them go to the bathroom. For the first few days, I fed them every four hours. Soon, they started drinking from a bottle and moving around a bit.

Three weeks later, Willow seemed tired but was still eating. The next morning, I found him dead. The vet said he had a lung infection. When feeding animals, it's important not to let them drink too fast, or liquid can go into their lungs. This happened to Willow, and he got sick.

I was sad but continued caring for the others. Then, a local farmer brought me another male cub, also named Willow. He was cold and hungry, and his mother had left him. Willow II was hard to feed. I had to move the bottle around to get him to drink. Eventually, he learned to eat sausages, and then other foods.

By five months, the cubs were eating cereals, meat, vegetables, fruit, nuts, cheese, eggs, and seeds. Badgers usually eat earthworms, beetles, bugs, and small animals. My badgers were lucky because the summer was hot, and finding earthworms was hard.

By August, the cubs became more active at night. We often walked through the orchard, and they played and chased each other. They even included us in their games. I learned to avoid their playful bites, but Derek sometimes got caught.

During our walks, I saw other badgers in our field. Badgers are very territorial and can be aggressive to others. We were warned they might harm our cubs, so we made their pen more secure.

The local press took pictures of us with the badgers, and we started a project to build a home for them on the farm. With help, we designed a sett with tunnels and a viewing area. The badgers explored it and eventually moved in. The cost was high, but a local bus company and other businesses helped.

Now, the badgers have their own home. I don't walk with them as much because they are active late at night. Primrose has joined another group, but Bluebell and Willow II still come to say hello before going off into the night. This is their home now, and they are happy here.

Text: 'Looking for True North - and the Man Behind Halley's Comet Dr. Toby Clark, a researcher at the British Geological Survey, wants to follow Sir Edmund Halley's journey to study compass changes. Anjana Ahuja reports. Astronomer Sir Edmund Halley (1656-1742) is famous for the comet named after him. But one of his important achievements was to study 'compass variations' during his sea trips on the ship Paramore. These variations, now called 'declination', are the angle between magnetic north and true north. Without knowing this, sailors could not correct their compasses and find their way across the oceans. Halley, one of the few people paid to do scientific research at that time, sailed to the Cape Verde Islands to study declination in the Atlantic Ocean. The trip stopped early because of problems with the crew, but Halley tried again. This time, he traveled to Rio de Janeiro, South Georgia, Newfoundland, and back to England. From these trips, Halley published a map in 1701 showing compass variations in the oceans. This map was very useful to sailors for over a hundred years until changes in Earth's magnetic field made it less accurate. Dr. Clark, who loves sailing, wants to celebrate the 300th anniversary of Halley's trip by following the same route. He needs to raise £70,000 before starting, and Sir Vivian Fuchs, who led the first expedition across Antarctica, is helping him. Dr. Clark became interested in Halley while working in Antarctica, where he read about Halley's life. 'Halley had an amazing life,' says Dr. Clark. 'He was a respected scientist and led expeditions. He was not just an astronomer but also did research in geophysics. While he was Astronomer Royal, he mapped the stars and also helped Sir Isaac Newton with his famous book, Principia Mathematica.' Dr. Clark believes that recreating the voyage will give Halley the recognition he deserves. The new expedition, called 'In the Wake of the Paramore', will also have scientific value. They will make the same measurements Halley did, but with better tools. These measurements are important because Earth's magnetic field is always changing. The data will help improve the current model of Earth's magnetic field. 'It is common to measure the size but not the direction of the magnetic field. You need to know true north to measure the direction,' says Dr. Clark. 'On our trip, we can use global positioning satellites to find true north.' The British Geological Survey and the United States Navy will provide instruments. A Danish satellite will also be taking similar measurements around the world. Dr. Clark hopes his measurements will fill any gaps in the satellite's data over the Atlantic Ocean. It is important to remember how significant Halley's journey was. It was the first scientific sea expedition, and Halley was the first civilian made a naval captain to study declination. Does Dr. Clark have the skills to make his journey a success? He spent two years in Antarctica, worked in the geomagnetic group at the British Geological Survey, and has already sailed from Rio de Janeiro to England. He plans to complete the expedition in four stages with four different crews. Does he share Halley's passion? 'I am ready to spend eight months on this, so some might think I'm obsessed. But I wouldn't sail across the Atlantic again without a good reason. Halley and his interesting life have given me a real sense of purpose.'

**POWER DRESSING EVERY SUMMER**

Every summer, peacocks at Whipsnade Wild Animal Park in Bedfordshire show off their beautiful tails to the female peacocks, called hens. This behavior puzzled Charles Darwin, a famous scientist, because he wondered why peacocks have such big, fancy tails in a world where animals need to be strong and fast to survive.

Darwin thought animals change over time through a process called evolution. He believed that animals best suited to their environment survive and have babies. But he was confused about the peacock's tail because it seemed to be a disadvantage. So, he suggested another idea called "sexual selection," where females choose mates based on beauty.

Darwin's friend, Alfred Russel Wallace, had a different idea. He thought that if hens chose peacocks with the best tails, it must mean those peacocks had some hidden quality that helped them survive.

Today, scientists like Marion Petrie are studying peacocks at Whipsnade to find out if hens really choose the males with the best tails and if those males have other good qualities. They have noticed that hens prefer peacocks with more eye-spots on their tails, which means longer tails. But they are still trying to find out if these peacocks are better in other ways, like being healthier.

Another scientist, William Hamilton, suggested that showy male birds might be healthier because they have fewer parasites. But this is hard to test with the peacocks at Whipsnade.

Marion Petrie is also looking at the children of attractive and unattractive peacocks to see if the attractive ones have healthier or faster-growing babies.

Finally, a mathematician named R A Fisher had an idea called "Fisher's Runaway." He thought that if females start choosing males with slightly better tails, over time, this preference could lead to peacocks having very long tails. This idea supports Darwin's thought that females might choose beauty just for beauty's sake.

**THE BOAT OF MY DREAMS**

Tom Cunliffe believes the best boat design should mix old and new ideas. He did this with his boat, 'The Westerman'. This week, the Summer Boat Show in London is full of modern yachts with new technology. Most of these boats are based on designs from 25 years ago. My boat, however, is on a quiet creek on the south coast. It was designed last year, but it looks like it is 100 years old. Some people might think I am a romantic dreamer, but I am not sure about that. My boat uses old boat design ideas, but modern technology helped make it better.

Modern technology is important in boat design and building, but it can sometimes make sailing too easy. Many people go to sea to experience the challenges of sailing. I think it's important for boats to have some comforts, like a stove for warmth and a good place to sleep. But if everything on the boat is automatic, it takes away from the experience. For example, setting and taking down sails should be part of a sailor's life. Also, moving the steering position to the middle of the boat just to have a bigger cabin is not a good idea. A boat should feel like a boat, not a house on water.

I once had a boat called Hirta, which I sailed around Britain for a TV race. The previous owner said it had comfort but no luxury. Hirta had heavy sails and no modern conveniences like electricity or a fridge, but it was the nicest boat I ever sailed. However, old boats need a lot of care. After I hurt my back, I had to sell Hirta. I couldn't find a new boat I liked, so I decided to build one myself.

The Westerman, my new boat, has been great. The designer, Nigel Irens, first drew it on a napkin before using a computer. He also made a model of the boat, like in the old days. We worked together to make the design perfect. The Westerman has crossed the North Atlantic and won many races. It looks timeless and is very comfortable. It was designed as a sailing boat first, without thinking about furniture. This is the traditional way, and it works well. The boat is made of wood treated with a special glue, so it is waterproof like a fiberglass boat but feels like a real wooden boat.

**RETREAT, RELAX, RECHARGE**

Health farms and country house hotels with spa facilities are very popular. We asked five journalists to visit some of these places.

**A. HENLOW GRANGE**

I was happy to visit Henlow Grange for six days because I was tired and needed to relax. My room in the big 18th-century house was very comfortable. On the first day, I did nothing and slept a lot. From the second day, I joined many classes like yoga and body conditioning. The instructors are very good. I felt more flexible as the week went on. They offer many treatments like aromatherapy, seaweed baths, and facials. The staff are friendly and professional. Henlow is planning to add a new swimming pool and a Light Diet Room. You can also ride bicycles or walk in the garden. I felt much better and full of energy after my stay. I want to visit again. This is a great place for a stressed working woman. Save Room 5 for me! - Marcella D'Argy Smith

**B. SHRUBLAND HALL**

Shrubland Hall is a calm and relaxing place. When you arrive, you get a medical check-up. They check your weight and blood pressure. I was called a "patient," which was strange because I am healthy. They found a shoulder problem during my check-up and helped me with it. Each person gets a special diet. I lost weight but felt hungry and got a headache on the second day. My meals included grapefruit, salads, and fruit with yogurt. You can have a massage or water therapy every other day. The extra treatments are not too expensive. - Liz Gregory

**C. CAREYS MANOR**

Careys Manor is not a health farm. It is a nice old manor with log fires and a big lounge. The food is very tasty, but not for people counting calories. There is a gym and a pool to help burn calories. They have a spa bath, steam room, and treatment rooms. There is also a sports injury clinic. I got advice for my shoulder injury. Careys is comfortable and luxurious. You can also explore the countryside around it. - Beverly D'Silva

**D. CLIVEDEN**

Cliveden is a grand country home and a five-star hotel. It offers health and beauty treatments, a gym, saunas, a swimming pool, and more. There are beautiful walks and gardens. The restaurant, Waldo's, has amazing food. I enjoyed a wonderful meal and then used the gym to burn some calories. I also had a facial and an aromatherapy massage. Cliveden has many fitness and beauty options if you want them. - Kay Letch

**E. SPRINGS HYDRO**

The best and worst thing about Springs Hydro is the carrot cake. It is delicious but has many calories. The aromatherapy massage is also great. I felt very relaxed and had a good night's sleep. The place is modern and well-run. There are many therapists and beauty rooms. They offer treatments like manicures, pedicures, and facials. The guests are a mix of people, from football teams to friends and families. I would like to visit once a month. - Eve Cameron

**Natural Talents**

Humans and chimpanzees are very similar. We are more than 98% the same in our genes. This means that the things that make us different from animals are new in our history. Our ability to make art and do other human things comes from a small part of our genes. 

Scientists have found that many things we thought only humans could do, animals can do too. For example, chimpanzees use sticks as tools, and sea otters use rocks to open clams. Monkeys have simple language with different sounds for 'leopard', 'eagle', and 'snake'. 

The main difference between humans and animals might be art. But our ancestors did not make art for a long time. The first clear human art, like cave paintings and statues, appeared about 35,000 years ago with the Cro-Magnons. 

People say human art is different because it is not useful, it is made for beauty, and it is learned, not instinctive. 

1. **Not Useful**: Oscar Wilde said, "All art is quite useless." Human art does not help us survive or have children. Birdsong, for example, helps birds find mates and protect their area. 

2. **Made for Beauty**: Humans make art for pleasure. We do not know if birds enjoy their songs, but they sing mostly during mating season, so it might not be for pleasure.

3. **Learned, Not Instinctive**: Human art styles are learned. People in different places have different art styles, like songs in Tokyo and Paris. Birds, however, are born knowing their songs. 

Human art changes quickly. For example, paintings from the 20th century look different from the Mona Lisa. Experts can often tell when and who painted a picture. But sometimes, they might mistake art by chimpanzees, like Congo and Betsy, for human art. Congo and Betsy were chimpanzees who painted for fun. Their art was shown in a London gallery in 1957, and many paintings were sold. 

These chimpanzee paintings show that the line between human art and animal activities is not always clear. Like human art, the chimpanzee art was not made for a specific purpose but for enjoyment. Some human art, even famous pieces, was also made for personal satisfaction.

Title: A Big Adventure

The Taklamakan Desert in western China is one of the last places on earth that people have not explored. It is also very dangerous. Charles Blackmore crossed it and survived to tell his story. 

There are not many big adventures or heroes left today. In the past, children's stories often had brave explorers with sunburnt skin and eyes looking far into the distance. Today, we don't see many people like that in stories or real life. But then I met Charles Blackmore.

Blackmore led a team across the Taklamakan Desert, one of the last unexplored places on earth. The desert's name means 'once entered you never come out', and local people call it the Desert of Death. He talked about the dangers and excitement of the journey at his home.

The team had four Britons (one was a doctor), an American photographer, four Chinese experts, 30 camels, and six camel handlers. The camel handlers had never worked with camels before; they were actually truck drivers. This mistake could have been very dangerous for the team.

They traveled 1,200 kilometers across the desert. Charles Blackmore wrote a book about their journey. At that time, he was leaving the Army after 14 years. He started the expedition for fun and to learn more about himself. 'I always thought I would stay in the Army. But I wanted to see who I really was outside of it. It was a big risk. My wife, Tina, was worried because nobody had done that route before. We went into it without knowing what to expect. It took us 59 days to cross, and the desert was kind to us.'

The team faced many problems: illness, very hot and cold temperatures, thirst, and losing some of their water. 'But', Blackmore says, 'when we were very tired and the camels had no water for seven days, we found some. We didn't have the desert's famous sandstorms. And we didn't face the very cold weather that could have stopped us. But we had many challenges. The sand got into everything, especially our blisters and wounds. The high dunes were hard to climb for us and the camels, which sometimes fell on us.'

'What kept me going was the need to survive. We had no backup plan. No planes flew over us. Once we were in the desert, we were alone. I knew I was mentally strong, but I was scared about my physical strength. On the first day, we sat at the edge of the desert, and it was so hot we couldn't breathe. I thought, "We have to do it now!" I was very scared.'

Towards the end, he said, 'When you've walked 1,000 kilometers, you don't give up. We were very thin but strong. My body was fit, and my legs were strong. I could walk over anything.'

In the book, Blackmore talks about lying in the desert, looking at the moon, and thinking of his family. He says, 'Inside me, there's someone trying to find peace. When I doubt myself, I think of the desert and how we succeeded. I am proud of that expedition. But my family and our happiness are more important.'

Has Charles Blackmore found peace? 'I miss the challenge and the open spaces. We had a strong purpose. Now, I find it hard to be part of everyday life.'

Susan Harr was feeling overwhelmed by technology, so she decided to unplug her gadgets and enjoy doing things by hand. Many people love technology because it gives us gadgets that make life easier and save time. But Susan started to think that maybe we rely too much on technology. She had a bad experience with her broken word processor, which was expensive to fix. This made her question if gadgets are worth the cost and trouble.

Susan began to let her household gadgets stop working naturally. She wondered if technology really gives us more time or just makes us buy more gadgets. When her sewing machine started making strange noises, she decided to stop using it. Now, she sews by hand and enjoys it. She can take her sewing anywhere and doesn't have to listen to a noisy machine.

There are some gadgets Susan still likes, like the washing machine. But she found joy in getting rid of others, like the color TV. Now, her family spends more time walking the dog, reading, and talking. Susan enjoys sewing by hand, listening to the radio, and watching TV while sewing. She finds it relaxing and satisfying to see her work improve.

Susan realized that doing things by hand slows down life and makes it more enjoyable. She even enjoys washing dishes by hand and daydreaming. Now, she looks around her house and wonders if they really need things like the freezer, microwave, or electric lights. She thinks they could save money by using fewer gadgets.

Charles Hurst is a cabinet-maker who makes beautiful furniture. Joanna Watt visits him at his workshop in East London. When she arrives, Charles seems busy and in a hurry. His workshop is full of half-made furniture and different colored wood. Charles has been making furniture for ten years and is well-known for his work. He always has many orders, even though he does not advertise. People know that if they want good furniture, they should go to him.

Finding a furniture-maker is not hard, but finding one who makes simple and beautiful furniture is rare. Charles says there are not many real cabinet-makers anymore. He is not happy with some modern furniture because it is not well-made. He does not like mass-produced furniture and wants everything to be perfect. This is why he is successful.

Charles is confident in his skills. He says he has a natural ability to make things. He learned his craft by asking questions and learning on his own. Most of his work comes from private clients, and some clients come back many times. He likes clients who know what they want, but sometimes they can be difficult.

Charles respects other good craftsmen and admits there are people better than him. He criticizes those who take too long to make one piece of furniture and those who try to make fashion statements with their work. He believes furniture should be useful, not just for show.

Charles is confident but not pretentious. As Joanna leaves, he humbly says, "After all, I am only making furniture."

Text: 'Three ideas about why we sleep People spend about one-third of their lives sleeping. This means sleep is very important. But, we are not sure exactly why we need sleep. Scientists have three main ideas about this. The first idea is that sleep helps our body stay healthy. When we sleep, our body fixes any problems from the day and makes us ready for the next day. The second idea is that sleep helps us learn. It says that when we sleep, we think about what we learned during the day. Without sleep, we might not learn well. The third idea is about energy. It says we need sleep to get more energy for the next day, like charging a battery.'

**Eccentrics**

An eccentric is a person who acts differently from most people. They do not follow the usual rules of society. This makes us ask, "What is normal?" Many of us have our own little habits. For example, some people love entering newspaper contests, collecting beer mats, or writing letters to newspapers about many topics. Eccentricity is about being unique. 

Inside us, there are two forces. One is called individualism, which means being different. The other is conformity, which means being like everyone else. Most people want to be accepted and loved, so they choose conformity. They want to fit in with others rather than stand out.

People with unusual hobbies or strong opinions often find others like them. They form clubs and have meetings to share their interests. They feel better when they are with others who understand them.

We all feel a pull between being unique and fitting in. Sometimes, we want to show we are different. For example, someone might say, "I say what I think," or "You must take me as you find me." 

Anyone can choose to be more individual. Many successful people have done this. For example, Bob Dylan, a famous American singer, said that when you follow your true feelings and don't give up, you might surprise people. But being different on purpose is not the same as being eccentric.

When a pop singer wears strange clothes to get attention, or a person makes shocking comments to be noticed, they are not eccentric. If they keep doing these things until it becomes normal for them, then they might be eccentric. 

True eccentrics do not try to be different; they just are. They do not care what others think. They do what they do because it is who they are. This makes them different from people who want to impress or escape from society. Eccentrics live their lives without worrying about what others think.

Natural Books

We asked four nature experts to tell us about the wildlife book that influenced them the most.

A. Geoffrey Lean
Choosing the author was easy for me. As an environmental journalist, I have met many important people in this field. Barbara Ward, a small, frail woman, is the most important. She was at the center of environmental issues in post-war Europe. Her book, The Home of Man, is about the fast growth of cities and the need for sustainable development. It is the best book I have read on this topic.

B. Linda Bennett
When I read Signals for Survival by Niko Tinbergen, I can imagine the sounds and smells of a gull colony. This book explains how animals communicate. After reading it, watching a gull colony becomes more interesting. You can see how they interact and recognize families. Niko Tinbergen wanted to share his findings with everyone. He worked with artist Eric Ennion, whose paintings show bird behavior with just a few lines and colors.

C. Lee Durrell
My Family and Other Animals by Gerald Durrell is the book that influenced me the most. It led me to a great husband and a career in conservation. I read it while researching animal sounds in Madagascar. The book made me feel better during tough times. It shows animals and people living together happily. It reminds us that all living things are connected, like a family.

D. Bruce Pearson
I found The Shell Bird Book by James Fisher in my school library in 1966. The book's 48 color plates of birds by Eric Ennion caught my attention. I already liked birdwatching and sketching birds. This book had more to offer, with chapters on bird migration and birds in music, literature, and art. It helped me appreciate birds and nature in a broader way. It showed me that my emotional and creative response to nature is as important as a scientific one. This book opened a new path for me.

**Do Reviews Help Sell Books?**

We talked to five big British publishers to find out if book reviews help sell books. Here is what they said:

**Publisher A**  
Reviews are very important for publishers. When people were asked why they bought a book, most said it was because of reviews. Both authors and publishers feel bad if there are no reviews. But publishers don't mind bad reviews as much because any review can make people curious to read the book. Publishers like reviews that agree with their own thoughts about the book.

**Publisher B**  
Publishers and newspapers both care about book reviews, but they want different things. Newspapers want to entertain their readers, while publishers want their books to be reviewed positively. Book reviews are better now than 40 years ago, but paperbacks still don't get enough attention. Reviews help people know about a book and can increase sales, especially if many reviews are positive.

**Publisher C**  
Reviews are very important for us because we publish books by authors who are not very famous. We don't advertise much, so we need reviews to help sell our books. Good reviews are more valuable than ads because they are seen as honest opinions. Reviews can help a book become popular, but they need to work with other things like word-of-mouth and good marketing.

**Publisher D**  
In the US, a review in the New York Times can make a book very popular. In Britain, it's different. Sometimes, even with great reviews, it takes a long time for people to start reading a writer's work. Some books sell well even without reviews. It's hard to predict what will happen. Non-fiction reviews often talk more about the subject than the book itself.

**Publisher E**  
All publishers and writers want great reviews. But do they sell books? I once published a biography that got great reviews, but it didn't sell well because people felt they knew the book from the reviews. The reviewer's name used to matter more, but now it's more about the review's style and originality that makes people want to buy the book.

Text: 'WEATHERVANE MAKER Making weathervanes is a very old skill, starting in early Egyptian times. Today, Graham Smith keeps this craft alive in his workshop. He is one of the few people in the country who make weathervanes by hand. Graham creates special designs for each customer. 'This way, I can make a unique and personal item,' he says. 'Many of my customers are women buying gifts for their husbands. They want a special gift that shows the man's work or hobbies.' This is different from the usual cockerel design, which is the most common weathervane. Graham's first weathervane was not a cockerel but a witch on a broomstick. He made it as a surprise gift for his wife. Friends liked it and asked him to make weathervanes for them too. 'I saw that I could make many different designs,' he says. Graham decided to focus on making weathervanes. He had worked as a precision engineer for 15 years. Then, he and his wife, Liz, decided to change roles. Liz went to work as an architectural assistant, and Graham stayed home to take care of the children and start the business. That was five years ago, and he is happy with his choice. 'My old job was not artistic, but this is fun and creative,' he says. 'I really like designing.' Graham has made over 100 original designs. He works with great detail and always checks with the customer before cutting the design. Graham also keeps many traditional designs because they are popular too. 'People like handmade things,' Graham says. 'They like to have something a little different.' Graham does not want to expand his business. He wants to keep it as a small craft. 'I have found my place in the market. People love the unique designs, and I enjoy turning a simple shape into something almost real,' he says. 'For many years, weathervanes have helped people know the weather by showing wind direction,' he explains. 'Now, more people are moving to the countryside, and they want something special for their homes. This helps crafts like mine.' Graham is very busy, sending flat-packed weathervanes to customers around the world. American and Danish buyers are especially interested. 'The price,' he says, 'depends on how detailed the design is.' His latest request was for a curly-coated dog. Whatever the occasion, Graham can make a special gift.'

Title: Beginner's Luck

Before it was even published, "The Horse Whisperer" was the most talked-about book of the year. It is the first novel by British writer Nicholas Evans, and it made him a lot of money. Here, he talks about what inspired him and his success.

At the start of the year, things were not going well for Nicholas Evans. He was a screenwriter and producer, but a movie project he was working on suddenly failed. He was worried because he hadn't made any money in two years, and the bank was getting upset with him. Most people would have looked for a job, but Evans decided to do something different. He bought a ticket to America to research his first novel.

The idea for the story came from a farrier (a person who shoes horses) he met in Dartmoor. The farrier told him about a horse that became wild for no reason. Its owners were worried until they found a gypsy who calmed the horse just by talking to it. These people were called "horse whisperers." Evans was fascinated by this story.

He started to learn more about horse whisperers, thinking he would write a movie script. But after his movie project failed, he decided to write a book instead. He traveled across the US, visiting ranches and learning about horses.

During this time, Evans felt alone and worried about his future. He had tried for ten years to succeed in the film industry, but now he was in debt and worried about his family. By August, he had written half of the book and showed it to a friend who was a literary agent. The agent thought it was good and said Evans might get $30,000 for it. Evans needed more money to pay his debts and support his family.

In October, Evans sent the first part of his book and a summary to seven publishers. Soon, his agent told him that someone offered $75,000 for the book. Evans was surprised. In a week, the book was sold for record amounts: $550,000 in the UK and $3.15 million in the US. Hollywood studios also wanted to make a movie from it.

Evans was amazed by the success. He decided not to write the movie script for "The Horse Whisperer" because he didn't want to lose control over his story. He wanted to stay involved but not too closely. The success of his book also brought new interest in his old movie project, but he was not sure if he wanted to continue with it. He thought it might be better to write another novel.

Text: 'Young Masters Bobby Fischer is trying to play chess again, but he is older now. Chess is a game for young people. After 20 years away, Bobby Fischer is playing against Boris Spassky. Bobby won the first game, and it was very good. But Bobby is not the same as he was in 1972. He is 49 years old and not in practice. Boris Spassky is even older. Chess has changed a lot in 20 years. Bobby Fischer made chess popular, and now it is more professional. Today, winning is the most important thing. In chess, you need strong nerves and energy, not just a smart mind. The game is very stressful. Players use a chess clock to make sure they play fast enough. If they don't, they lose the game. Now, games are longer and have no breaks. Young players have an advantage. In the last 30 years, each new world champion is younger than the one before. Eight of the top ten players in the world are under 30. Chess is also different because of computers. Players use computers to study their opponents' games. A small computer can have one million chess games. Before a match, players prepare a lot. The start of a chess game is very important. Being ready for the opening moves can help you win. There are more good chess players now than ever before. Many grandmasters play for small prizes all over the world. To win, you need to be strong in body and mind. A game can last up to eight hours. Players must focus all the time. If they lose focus, they can lose the game. The chess clock makes the game even more tense. At the end of the game, players have only seconds to make moves. They must move fast and press the clock quickly. This is not for people who think slowly. It is a fight where nerves and the will to win are important. Losing is very hard for top players. Winning feels great and helps them recover. But one win is not enough to win a tournament. Chess competitions last 9-11 days, with games every day. There are tournaments all year. World championship matches are even harder. In 1984, Anatoli Karpov and Gary Kasparov played in Moscow. They had to stop because they were too tired. Karpov lost a lot of weight. Can Bobby Fischer win again? He once said, "All I want to do is play chess." This made it strange when he left chess in 1972. But it made him famous. If he came back for money, he will get a lot. If he came back to show he is the best, losing could be very sad for him.'

**Fame and Fortune**

Imogen Edwards-Jones talks to some new British talents, from poets to pop stars, who are becoming famous.

**A. Nick Grosso**

Nick Grosso is in his early 30s and has written three successful plays. He is now turning his first play, "Peaches," into a movie script. He says, "It's a low-budget film, but we don't know how low. It won't be more than £30 million, but it could be as little as £30." Before writing "Peaches," Nick had never seen or read a play. He left school at 16 but returned a year later. After finishing his A-levels, he joined the Young People's Theatre. He says, "I wanted to write for actors. I wanted my writing to be heard, not just read. It was exciting to be with people who thought like me."

**B. Simon Pegg**

Simon Pegg, 28, studied drama at Bristol University. He is now writing a TV comedy series and has just finished a tour with comedy star Steve Coogan. Simon worked hard, even performing in comedy clubs while at university. He realized he preferred comedy over serious acting. He says, "People think comedy is the hardest job, but it's not. If you have courage and good material, making people laugh is wonderful." Simon has worked with the comedy group Funny Business and has a good relationship with Steve Coogan.

**C. Ciaran McMenamin**

Ciaran McMenamin, 24, became famous as the lead in the TV series "The Young Person's Guide To Becoming A Rock Star." He can now choose his roles, which he always wanted. Ciaran started acting in school and joined the Ulster Youth Theatre for four years. He says, "I used acting as an excuse not to do homework, but then I realized I loved it." Now, he enjoys his success but knows fame is not the most important thing. He wants respect for doing good work.

**D. Neil Taylor**

Neil Taylor, 25, is the lead singer of the pop band Matrix. They have a three-album deal with Domino Records. Their single "Chimera" will be released soon. Neil says, "The record company wants a big hit, but I'll be happy if just two people buy it." Neil left school at 16 and worked hard to succeed in music. He almost gave up before meeting Rick Brown and forming Matrix. Neil says, "I've been in some bad bands, but I hope it was all worth it."

**E. Stephen Richards**

Stephen Richards, 27, is a poet and author who has won many awards. He is well-known in the poetry world and is now publishing his first novel, "Hidden," in March. Stephen loved creative writing in school but didn't go to university right away. He later decided to go after getting bored with a job at a theatre. He published his first children's book in 1992. Stephen says, "I don't want to just write without caring about quality."

A. Isabel is an art student who is 31 years old. She likes historical romance stories and is looking for the perfect partner, Mr. Right. Isabel thinks she looks good in jeans but doesn't wear them often because she doesn't want to be seen with the wrong people. She worries about her knees but always stays hopeful. This hope helps her and others in the story. The book is written in a fun and lively way, like an old silent movie.

B. This story is about a local radio station in America. It is told from the view of a smart child named Francis With. He works for WLT Radio, which was started by Roy and Ray Soderbjerg to promote their sandwich shop. The station plays music, shows, and more. The story is set in a small American town and uses humor to show life in the 1940s and 1950s, with old cars and radios.

C. In this story, a professor named Richard Vaisey falls in love with a Russian poet. He talks about it with his wife's first husband. The poet writes bad poetry and wants Richard's help for her brother in prison. The story is interesting because of how the author solves these problems. It is a funny and smart book about relationships.

D. Two women and two men become best friends in London during the 1960s. They stay close for 25 years. One of them, James Hudson, starts a newspaper with his friend Richard Blake. They both loved a woman who died years ago. The story has murder, ambition, love, and jealousy. It is a long book where you can really get to know the characters.

E. This story is about Ian Bedloe, who feels guilty about something he did. To make up for it, he takes care of his brother's three children. Ian is 40 years old and lives alone. The story shows his special relationship with the youngest child, Daphne. It is a warm and funny book with a good mix of sad and happy moments.

**Volunteer Tourism**

Four writers talk about international volunteer work.

**A.** Volunteer tourists often help build homes or schools. They pay a lot of money to do this work. If they gave this money directly to the local community, it could pay for more workers than one volunteer can do. This is true for gap year students who do not need special skills. Some studies question if gap year volunteering is really to help others or to improve the volunteer's career. However, these projects can help volunteers learn to act kindly and help those in need in the future.

**B.** Volunteering can help people understand each other better, solve problems, and join global groups. It can create international friendships. This can be good for both volunteers and the communities they help. But if only rich people from wealthy countries volunteer, it might help them more than the communities. These volunteers might use the experience to advance their careers, while the communities do not get much benefit.

**C.** Sometimes, international volunteering can be seen as charity from rich countries or a way for volunteers to improve themselves. But it can also help share skills and knowledge between volunteers and communities. Volunteering can make people aware of poverty and unfairness in the world and encourage them to fight these issues.

**D.** Volunteer tourism is about helping others. It seems good because it is personal and not controlled by big governments or businesses. But it can also ignore the need for big changes in poor communities. Some people think volunteer tourism is just simple charity. But when it is called sustainable development, it can be misleading. It might not address the real problems of poverty and inequality in the world.

**Sound the Alarm: Stuart Harris Reports**

Many people listen to the radio in the morning and need something to help them wake up. That's why we have clock radios. But how do you choose a good one? Our team, including me, inventor Tom Granger, and broadcaster Paul Bridges, tested five clock radios.

One model has a 'dual alarm function.' I thought it would let you snooze and then wake up again, but it actually lets you set two different wake-up times, like one for weekdays and one for weekends. This model also has a cassette player, which is nice because you can listen to your own tapes. The radio quality is good, but it's big, like a rugby ball. Paul Bridges said he needs space on his bedside table for his keys, wallet, glasses, and phone. He also books a wake-up call just in case the alarm doesn't work.

Another model was the best-looking and the overall winner. Paul Bridges loved it, even though the clock sometimes got stuck at 16:00. It has a nice digital display and a big snooze button. It also has a self-power back-up, so you don't have to reset it if the power goes out. But it was hard to set up.

One model has a built-in lamp, but Tom Granger thought it was poorly made. The lamp is hard to use, and the clock was difficult to set. The radio was also hard to tune, and the buzzer was very loud. This model is popular with young people because of its bright colors.

Another model was easy to set up without reading the instructions. It has a traditional design, but the alarm can be off by 10 minutes. Paul Bridges thought it was too complicated and not very useful.

The simplest and cheapest model was liked by Tom Granger because it was small and easy to use. It has old-fashioned dial tuning, which he found more reliable. The radio quality was okay, and the buzzer worked well, waking me up quickly.

Hedgehogs

A hedgehog is a small animal with sharp spines on its body. Hedgehogs live in many places around the world, but not in America or Australia. All hedgehogs can roll into a tight ball when they are in danger. This helps protect them because their spines stick out. How well this works depends on how many spines the hedgehog has. Some hedgehogs that live in the desert have fewer spines. They are lighter and might try to run away from danger first. They roll into a ball only if they have to. Hedgehogs are mostly active at night and sleep during the day. They sleep under bushes or in holes in the ground. All hedgehogs can hibernate, which means they sleep for a long time in winter. But not all of them do this. If the weather is good, some hedgehogs stay awake all year.

**Great Sports Women on a Winning Streak**

Being good at sports is hard for everyone, but it can be even harder for women. They have to work very hard and give up a lot of their normal life. But many women are doing great things in sports. Here are some stories of British sportswomen who are reaching their goals.

**A. Jill, 27, Skier**

Jill loves skiing. She says it feels great to fly through the air, but it can also be scary. Sometimes the weather is bad, but she keeps going. Skiing takes a lot of time, so she doesn't have much time for friends. There are six men and three women on her team, and they all compete together.

**B. Caroline, 22, Cyclist**

Caroline started cycling two years ago when she borrowed a bike for a charity race. She won the race even though she had never cycled before! Now she is a professional cyclist and trains a lot. She worries people might think she is successful because of her looks, not her skills. Her boyfriend is also a cyclist, so he understands how much time she needs to train.

**C. Annabel, 26, Rower**

Annabel says rowing is hard for girls to start because not many schools offer it. Most girls start rowing when they are older, which makes it harder to compete internationally. Coaches often change, so the team is not very organized. But Annabel loves rowing and staying fit.

**D. Ffyona, 24, Long Distance Walker**

Ffyona dreamed of walking around the world when she was 13. She found Britain too small and safe. Walking across Australia was very hard for her, with long days and little sleep. She had many blisters but still got the record. She needed to finish because her sponsorship money was running out. People often think women might fail, so it's harder for them to get sponsors.

**E. Lisa, 26, Saloon Car Racer**

Lisa says some men have big egos when driving. They don't like it when she does well. Racing is tough, and she doesn't earn much money. Women have been racing for a long time, but they were seen as unusual. Now, more women are racing every year. Lisa loves trying to make the perfect lap.

**F. Alison, 28, Triathlete**

Alison wakes up early to swim three times a week. She also cycles and runs. Sometimes she falls asleep at her desk because she is so tired. Racing is hard, but she enjoys it because it keeps her fit and is social. Men and women often race together, but the media mostly talks about the men's races. The prize money for women is also less, but they are working to change that.

**The Day I Met Picasso**

Richard Cork remembers meeting the famous artist Picasso when he was 18 years old. Richard was traveling around Europe and Morocco in an old van before starting university. He ran out of money and got a job painting boats in Cannes, France. One day, while eating at a restaurant, he saw Picasso, who was 78 years old, having lunch with his wife and friends.

Picasso was a private person, so Richard was surprised to see him. Richard's friend encouraged him to ask Picasso for his autograph. Nervously, Richard went to Picasso and asked him to sign his sketchbook. Picasso kindly signed it and even drew a little picture on the page.

Richard was very happy and started talking to Picasso. Since Picasso didn't speak much English, an American woman at the table helped translate. Richard told Picasso how much he loved art and admired his work.

Richard's friend suggested he draw a portrait of Picasso. Richard went back to Picasso's table and started drawing him. Picasso made funny faces and gestures, making it hard for Richard to draw. But eventually, Picasso sat still, and Richard could finish his drawing.

Picasso then wanted to see the drawing. Richard was shy but showed it to him. Picasso liked it and decided to draw something on the same page. In a few quick strokes, Picasso drew a funny face next to Richard's drawing.

Richard asked Picasso to sign the drawing, but Picasso said he had already signed once. Richard felt very lucky to have met Picasso and to have received his attention. It was a special moment for him.

**Talking Shop: How Stores Make You Buy More**

Have you ever gone into a store and bought more than you planned? Stores use tricks to make you spend more money. Here are some ways they do it:

**A. Freshness Image**
Supermarkets know people like fresh food. They often put fruits and vegetables at the entrance to look fresh. They might also have a bakery inside, so you smell fresh bread. The store might use green colors because green makes people think of fresh things. Most of what they sell, like frozen foods, is not fresh, but the store looks fresh.

**B. Product Placement**
Where products are placed in a store is very important. Supermarkets use computers to know where people pick items the most. They put expensive or fast-selling products there. Shelves at eye level are popular because people see them first. Special offers in big bins attract people who love bargains. Stores also put things that go together, like salad dressings near salads.

**C. Spreading Staples**
Supermarkets put basic items like bread and sugar far from the entrance. This way, you pass other things that might tempt you. Stores put popular items far from the entrance too, so you see other products while looking for them.

**D. Less is More**
Some stores, like Next, show fewer items to look special. They make it seem like their clothes are exclusive, even though they are not. This is because of good store design.

**E. Total Price Temptation**
People care more about the total bill than the price of each item. Supermarkets mix cheap and expensive items. They might sell some things cheap to get you in the store. They buy in large amounts to get discounts from manufacturers.

**F. Price Tags Matter**
In chain stores, people notice prices more. Pricing something at $14.99 instead of $15 makes a difference. It also helps reduce theft because staff have to ring up the sale to give change.

**G. Lighting Tricks**
Stores use lighting carefully. Chain stores use natural light so clothes look the same as outside. Supermarkets use special lights to make fruits and vegetables look better.

**H. Walking Paths**
Stores use different carpets to guide you. One type of carpet is for walking paths, and another is for sales areas. This guides you through the store. Some stores use wood or marble for paths to make you walk onto the carpet in sales areas.

**I. In-Store Promotion**
When you enter a supermarket, you see big pictures of delicious food. This makes you want to buy if you are hungry. In the U.S., some supermarkets use video trolleys. These trolleys show ads for products as you shop. They are for people who buy on impulse and can increase sales by 30%.

Chris Bonnington, a 58-year-old mountaineer, is famous for climbing Mount Everest in 1985. He has also created new climbing paths in Britain and the Alps and has written books like "Quest for Adventure" and "Everest the Hard Way." Robin Knox-Johnston, who is 53, started his sea career in the Merchant Navy. In 1968-9, he was the first person to sail around the world alone in his yacht, Sunhaili. He also set a record by sailing from New York to the Lizard in 10 days. Chris and Robin worked together to sail and climb in Greenland, and they wrote about it in their book "Sea, Ice and Rock."

In 1979, Chris was working on a book about adventure after the war. He called Robin for an interview, and Robin invited him to go sailing. Chris could teach Robin some climbing, and Robin could teach Chris some sailing. It was Chris's first time on a yacht. They sailed and then stopped the boat. Robin's wife and daughter stayed on the boat while Chris and Robin went to the shore to climb. The climb was hard, but Robin did well. Chris showed Robin how to climb down safely, and Robin did it using his own way.

During their trip to Skye, Chris and Robin became good friends. Robin suggested they use their skills together on a trip to Greenland. Chris was impressed by Robin as a leader. Usually, the captain makes all the decisions, but Robin asked everyone for their opinions. Chris found sailing boring and difficult because he likes being on land. Robin, on the other hand, enjoyed fixing things on the boat. Chris sometimes felt he wasn't needed and found it hard to be on a small boat with six people.

When they reached Greenland, Chris led the climbing part of the trip. He was worried about keeping Robin safe while climbing. They tried to climb Greenland's highest mountain, the Cathedral, but it was very hard. They climbed for 24 hours and were very tired. Robin trusted Chris and followed him, even when they had to turn back. Robin was also worried about the boat, but he wanted to try climbing the mountain again.

On the way home, there was a small problem between Chris and Robin. Chris was supposed to take a turn watching the boat at 4 am, but Robin didn't wake him up. Chris thought Robin didn't trust him, but Robin explained that wasn't true. By the end of the Greenland trip, Chris learned that Robin was a kind and sensitive person.

**A History of the Apple**

**Early Apples (8,000 BC)**  
People have been eating apples for a very long time. In ancient times, people in Britain and around Swiss and Italian lakes ate wild apples. These apples were small and not like the ones we eat today. They were called 'windings' in Ancient Britain.

**Apples in Britain (1000 AD)**  
The French learned how to grow fruit from the Romans. They brought this knowledge to Britain, including how to make cider. The Normans, who came after the Romans, introduced new apple types that grew better in Britain. Monks in Britain worked on creating new apple varieties, which are the ancestors of many apples we have today.

**Popular Apples (1200)**  
In the 13th century, some apples became popular in Britain. The Old English Pearmain was a favorite dessert apple, and the Costard was used for cooking. However, during tough times like droughts and the Black Death, fewer apples were grown, and more were imported. In the 16th century, King Henry VIII sent Richard Harris to France to learn more about growing apples. Harris brought back new apple types, including the famous Pippins, and started a modern orchard in Kent.

**Apples Around the World (1750)**  
By the 17th century, apples were so loved in Britain that settlers took them to new places like Canada, Australia, the US, South Africa, and New Zealand. Captain Bligh took apples to Australia, and the Pilgrim Fathers took them to America. In America, Johnny Appleseed was famous for planting apple trees across many states.

**New Apple Varieties (1850)**  
In Iowa, a farmer named Jesse Hiatt found a new apple tree and named the apple 'Hawkey'. It was later called 'Delicious' and became very popular. In Australia, Maria Anne Smith discovered a new green apple, which became known as the 'Granny Smith'. She found the tree growing from discarded fruit and made it famous worldwide.

**Modern Apple Growing (1950)**  
Today, apples are grown all over the world. Most apples come from just a few types, chosen for their looks and ability to travel well, not for taste. This has led to less variety in apples. In the UK, some gardeners keep old apple types alive, but many have been lost in the US. People now want more variety in apples, and it's important to protect different types of apples for the future.

**Explore Worldwide - Small Groups, Big Adventures**

Explore Worldwide is a leader in adventure travel. We offer trips for people who want more than just a beach holiday. Our trips go to new and exciting places with unique plans. Our brochure has over 100 adventures like tours, treks, safaris, and expeditions in more than 60 countries. Most trips last 1-4 weeks.

**Small Groups**

Our groups are small, with about 16 people. This makes it easier to learn about the places we visit. You can get closer to the local culture and people. It's an exciting experience for everyone.

**Different Ways to Travel**

We use many types of transport, often on the same trip. We travel by bus, train, minibus, boat, canoe, camel, and sometimes on foot. Each trip matches the local area.

**Who Travels with Explore?**

Our travelers are interesting people who like new experiences. They come from the UK, Europe, Australia, New Zealand, Canada, and the USA. Our trips are for people who are healthy, fit, and adaptable. Most travelers are between 25 and 55 years old. About half are couples, and the rest travel alone.

**Activities and Interests**

Each trip is unique, so we have 8 categories to describe them. Each category has special highlights. Unique places, local customs, and personal involvement make our trips enjoyable.

**Cultural/Adventure**

Most trips have a strong cultural focus. Some trips focus on local cultures and famous sites. We have trips in places like Egypt, India, China, and Peru. Short walks to unusual sites are often part of our trips.

**Wildlife and Natural History**

Our safaris visit famous parks and let you see animals in their natural homes. In Africa, you can walk in the wild or track gorillas. We camp or stay in hotels and lodges. In the Galapagos Islands, we stay on a small yacht.

**Ethnic Encounters**

Meeting local people is a special part of our trips. We visit tribes like the Tuareg in the Sahara or the Maya in Mexico. We travel in small groups to respect local cultures and the environment.

**Easy/Moderate Hiking**

Many trips include easy walks in the countryside. We stay in hotels or village huts. Your main luggage is transported, and you carry a daypack.

**Major Treks**

We offer a few treks for strong walkers. These are in high mountains like the Himalayas and Andes. We stay with local people or camp. We use support vehicles or animals to carry heavy gear.

**Wilderness Experience**

Exploring remote wilderness areas is exciting. We visit places like the Amazon Rainforest and the Sahara Desert. These trips offer a unique adventure.

**Sailtreks/Seatreks**

These are relaxing holidays. We use local boats in places like Egypt and Turkey. We explore islands in Indonesia and the Galapagos.

**Raft and River Journeys**

River trips can last a few hours to several days. We use inflatables or rafts. No experience is needed, and safety skills are taught. Our river trips offer a special view of jungles and rivers.

Richard Nerurkar is a long-distance runner from Britain. He is one of the best in the 10,000-meter race. Richard visited a training camp in Kenya. This camp is in a place called Nanyuki, near Mount Kenya. Mount Kenya is a tall mountain with ice on top. Richard has been coming to Kenya for three years to train in the high mountains. But he never trained with Kenyan runners before. On his fourth trip, he decided to change this. He ran his first race in Kenya and stayed at the national team training camp. This camp is where the best Kenyan runners get ready for big races. Richard was invited by the coach because he did well in a world race, finishing fifth. Training at high places helps runners because it makes their bodies better at using oxygen. This is one reason why Kenyan runners are so good. Richard's first race in Africa was in Nairobi. It was the first international race in Africa. Many runners finished before him, and most of them were Kenyan. Richard learned that Kenyan runners are successful not just because of the high altitude. They have a simple way of living and training. They enjoy running and competing. At the training camp, Richard saw how the Kenyan runners train. The camp is at St Mark's College, high up on Mount Kenya. The camp is simple, with few comforts. The runners live with college students and share rooms. They train three times a day: an easy run in the morning, interval training in the middle of the day, and a steady run in the afternoon. They run about 40 kilometers each day, except on Sundays when they run 20 kilometers. Life at the camp is simple. They wash their faces and brush their teeth before breakfast. Breakfast is tea, bread, and boiled eggs. Lunch and dinner are similar: ugali (a maize dish), stew, cabbage or spinach, and tea. After running, they go to a stream to wash. Richard learned that Kenyan success is not just about genetics or altitude. It is also about their simple lifestyle, hard training, and love for running. These might be the real reasons why Kenyan runners are so successful.

**Hit and Miss of Mass Marketing**

Advertising is having a hard time. It's not just because of the bad economy. Advertising started to drop in 1989, even before the economy got worse. The problem is bigger and affects the whole world. Advertising hasn't kept up with changes in the economy. Advertisers think about big markets and big media, but now there are many brands and media, and markets are smaller. Big brand campaigns should focus on smaller groups, but they often don't. This is where advertising is going wrong.

Think about your shopping. When you go to a supermarket, you might buy 30 to 50 items. Many of these are not advertised brands. You might buy a few advertised brands from the 15,000 items in the store. In a year, you probably buy only a few hundred brands. For things like cars, you might buy one every three years, and many people get cars from their jobs. You don't buy many clothes, and most are not advertised brands. Even with candy, medicine, and services, you probably don't buy more than 400 different brands a year.

There are 32,500 advertised brands, but most people buy only 400 of them. This means 96% of advertising might be wasted. When you watch TV, count how many ads are for brands you buy or might buy. For most people, it's about 1 in 16 ads. This means 94% of ads might be wasted. People think they don't pay attention to ads, but everyone sees many ads they don't buy from.

Advertising has to reach many people to find the few who will buy. It's a cheap way to talk to many people, even if it's expensive. Smart targeting can help reduce waste, but advertisers can't know exactly who will respond. Even the best direct mail doesn't get a 100% response. This is different from face-to-face selling, where a salesperson might succeed with every customer. If advertisers knew who would respond, they wouldn't need media.

If an advertiser gets one million new customers, that's good. For soap powder, the top brands would be happy with a million new customers. Any campaign that gets 2% of the population is very successful. To succeed, advertising needs to target its message better than before.

Text: 'Solar Survivor Charles Clover visits Britain's most environmentally-friendly home. Southwell in Nottinghamshire has some surprises. One is Southwell Minster, an old cathedral with 'green' men carved by medieval craftsmen. Another is Britain's greenest house, the 'autonomous house', made by Robert and Brenda Vale. The Vales use rainwater for washing and drinking, recycle their waste into garden compost, and heat their house with heat from electrical appliances and their own body heat, along with their three children and two cats, Edison and Faraday. The house looks traditional with a clay tile roof and is 300 yards from the Minster. It matches the town's old buildings and was approved by planners even though it is in a protected area. The house is very quiet because it is super-insulated with special windows. Inside, you must take off your shoes. It is a sunny day, and the conservatory warms the air for the house. Vale opens windows to let in air because the house is very airtight. Even the cats have their own special door. The Vales, who teach architecture, cared about the environment before it was popular. They wrote a book on green architecture in the 1970s. They designed a house with no carbon dioxide emissions and no mains water. They use composting toilets, rainwater tanks, and copper gutters to keep water clean. Water from washing goes into the garden. They don't use a dishwasher because they don't want to use strong detergents. They wanted to show that you can have an environmentally-friendly house without living in the dark. The house looks old-fashioned, but it is modern inside. The Vales pay no water bills and use very little electricity. Soon, they will have solar panels to make even more electricity. The house will use electricity from the mains for cooking, but it will also make extra electricity. They have a small wood stove for very cold days. In winter, the house stays warm because there are no draughts. The house is simple and low-tech, with parts from local builders. It was cheap to build, costing the same as low-cost housing. Big building companies do not like this idea.'

Text: 'The camera never lies Arthur Conan Doyle, who created the Sherlock Holmes stories, thought he was a logical man, like a scientist. But in 1920, when he saw photos of fairies in a garden, he believed they were real proof that fairies existed. He published the photos with an article he wrote, saying fairies were amazing supernatural things. In 1939, the two women who took the photos said they were fake. They had cut out pictures of fairies from a book and put them among flowers. The photos are very pretty. But this simple trick shows that a basic idea about photography, that the camera cannot lie, is not true. Cameras can lie, and they always could. Today, we use computer programs to change our digital photos, and it is not true that photography was ever completely honest. From the start, when cameras began taking pictures of reality, that reality was being changed.'

**Blacksmiths**

Iron has always been important to people, and blacksmiths, who work with iron, have been seen as more than just workers. Before machines were common, blacksmiths were as respected as doctors because they made weapons, armor, and farming tools. They were also seen as artists. In the 1700s, blacksmiths made beautiful ironwork for places like St Paul's Cathedral. The fancy metal designs in French and Belgian buildings were also made by skilled blacksmiths.

By the late 1960s, there were not many blacksmiths left in Britain. Big factories did not need them anymore, and new buildings did not use pretty iron designs. But in the last 10 years, blacksmithing has become popular again because people are more interested in decorative buildings and creative interior design. However, many iron products still look old-fashioned, like 'classical' or 'Victorian-style' gates and balconies. In trendy stores, you often see rusty candlesticks with decorations.

Luckily, there are new ideas, and some events are promoting blacksmithing. One event is an exhibition by the British Artist Blacksmiths Association (BABA) at the Fire & Iron gallery in Leatherhead, Surrey. Alan Dawson, BABA's secretary, says we might be starting a new Iron Age. Power tools now help blacksmiths work more easily, allowing them to create art with metal. About 250 items are in the show, from bookends to a spiral staircase. Prices start at £90 and go much higher. Most money goes to the makers, but some helps promote good ironwork.

Dawson made an eight-foot gate and a lamp with a glass shade for the show. He says his style is like drawing with metal. Many artists love working with iron because it is soft when hot but hard when cold. Susan May, a jeweler, finds it magical. Ann Catrin Evans makes door-knockers and handles inspired by castles in horror films. She likes that steel feels permanent.

Iron has given people visual pleasure and a sense of safety. It will likely be used decoratively for many years, as long as we avoid more rusty candlesticks.

Title: The Day I Stopped Smoking

I thought everyone would be happy when I stopped smoking, but one of my colleagues was very angry. She said, "If it was that easy, why didn't you stop years ago?" I couldn't really explain how I went from smoking a pack a day to not smoking at all in just four hours. It was strange to me too.

I stopped smoking after a session that mixed group therapy and hypnotherapy. This happened two months and three weeks ago. I didn't plan to stop smoking, and I didn't really want to. I didn't like the pressure from people who were against smoking. Also, I was healthy and didn't have any problems like coughing. I even got over colds faster than my friends who lived healthier lives.

On a normal Thursday afternoon, I went to a session called "The Easy Way to Stop Smoking" in Birmingham. I was there to write an article about other people trying to quit smoking. I told them, "I won't try to stop smoking because I'm here to write, not to quit." I thought I was being fair. I enjoyed smoking and it made me happy.

During the session, we were allowed to smoke as much as we wanted. The room was so full of smoke that we had to open the windows. I noticed that when they told us to smoke, I didn't really want to, and neither did the others. The messages about stopping smoking made sense to me. The idea of not smoking started to feel good. It was a secret feeling just for me. Could I do more things if I stopped smoking?

In many ways, it was easy to stop. The desire for nicotine, which felt like hunger, went away after a minute or two. I only felt it for four or five days. I thought working without cigarettes would be hard, but it wasn't a problem at all. I believed I needed cigarettes to meet deadlines, but I was wrong.

Surprisingly, the hardest part was being at home on weekend mornings. I realized smoking was something I did when I was bored. Having a cigarette was like an activity. Yes, I miss smoking, but not too much. Now, I have to get used to doing things without smoking, like eating out, waiting for a plane, checking into a hotel, or during a theater break. These were times when I used to smoke.

Dorothy Hodgkin is the only British woman scientist to win a Nobel Prize, but not many people in Britain know her name. Georgina Ferry, who is writing a book about Hodgkin, thinks she should be famous. Hodgkin was a great scientist who studied crystals and made important discoveries about penicillin, vitamin B12, and insulin. She won the Nobel Prize for Chemistry in 1964.

Hodgkin's life was interesting. She lived through big changes in the 20th century, like the growth of women's education and the spread of science around the world. She also had a family, with three children and a husband who was often away for his work as a historian.

Many people think that scientists' lives are not as exciting as those of artists or writers. This is why there are not many books about scientists. But this is changing. More books now show scientists as real people with personal lives, like Richard Feynman's funny book about his life.

Some scientists, like Richard Dawkins and Steve Jones, are now seen on TV, which helps people see them as normal people. This is important because it can make young people more interested in science.

Understanding science is not harder than reading Shakespeare or learning a new language. It just needs effort. It is important to know about scientists like Dorothy Hodgkin because they have given us a lot of knowledge and discoveries.

Margaret and Her Special Skill

Margaret Wilkins has a special skill. She can find water underground using a forked hazel stick. Many farmers ask for her help when their wells dry up. Margaret and her husband have a business that drills wells. They use machines like drilling rigs and air hammers. But to find water, Margaret only needs her hazel stick. They are successful more than 90% of the time.

This skill is called dowsing. It is like having a 'sixth sense' to find water, minerals, or lost things underground. Some people think it works because everything on Earth vibrates, and water vibrates more. Dowsers, like Margaret, can feel these vibrations. Some say they can even smell water.

Margaret and her husband have been very busy in recent years because of droughts. They have a long waiting list. Most of their customers are farmers with dry wells. Some customers have holiday homes far from water pipes. Others are building golf courses and need water.

Margaret looks for water 50 to 70 meters deep. She makes sure the water is clean and not near any waste. The water is in cracks in hard rock. They also need electricity to pump the water, so the well should be near power lines.

To find water, Margaret starts with a map and a pendulum. She moves the pendulum over the map, and it swings where there is water. Then she walks over the land with her hazel stick. When she is above water, she feels a strange sensation. The stick helps her find the exact spot to drill. Her husband checks the same area. If they agree, they drill. If not, they keep looking.

Margaret's skill is not common, but it is very useful. She calls it an 'intuitive perception of the environment.' This skill helps her family run their well-drilling business successfully.

**We changed lives for a day!**

Have you ever thought about living someone else's life for a day? Maybe you think it would be fun to try something different. We helped four people do this. Read their stories.

**Amanda's Story**

Amanda is 23 years old and has two daughters. She swapped lives with her friend Cindy, who is 30 and works as a waitress in a busy London restaurant.

Amanda had never been in a place like the restaurant before. It was dark, noisy, and full of people. She had to learn how to carry a tray of drinks with one hand. It was hard, and she dropped the drinks on the floor. The other waitresses laughed and said everyone makes mistakes at first.

By 11:30 am, there was a line of people waiting to come in. Amanda was nervous about remembering orders, but everything was done by computer. After a few hours, her feet hurt, and the loud music was hard to get used to. She had to keep saying "Pardon?" because she couldn't hear the customers.

By 5 pm, Amanda was very tired and wanted to rest her feet. She was surprised when a waitress said it was a "quiet" day. Amanda realized waitressing is hard work. She thought it was a job for shy people, but you need to be friendly and calm. She was happy to go back to her children. It seemed easy after waitressing!

**Cindy's Story**

Cindy was nervous but excited to be a "mum" for the day. She thought she could handle Amanda's cheeky daughters, but it was harder than she expected.

After Amanda left for work, Cindy had to dress and feed the girls. She took Sophie to school and Katie to nursery. She thought she would have some free time, but Amanda left a note with chores to do.

Cindy picked up Katie, went shopping, and then picked up Sophie. The girls were full of energy and played loudly. Cindy tried to stay calm, thinking they would get tired, but they didn't. She finally got them to bed by 8 pm, but they kept asking for water to stay up.

Cindy found looking after children very tiring. You don't have time for yourself, and the responsibility is big. But she enjoyed the day.

**Rosemary's Story**

Rosemary is 42 and runs a dairy farm. She swapped with Hilary, a 30-year-old primary school teacher.

On the farm, Rosemary wakes up at 5:30 am, so sleeping until 7 was a treat. She was nervous about what to wear to school. At assembly, she hoped she didn't stand out.

Rosemary helped with a maths class and a nature project. By lunchtime, she was tired but only had five minutes to eat. She attended a meeting and helped with sports trials. After lunch, there was a reading lesson and a French lesson. The children wanted to practice French with her, which was fun.

The hardest part was speaking in front of the class. Teachers have more holidays, but Rosemary prefers farming.

**Hilary's Story**

Hilary arrived at the farm at 8:30 am. Rosemary had already been working for three hours! The farm has 100 cows, 15 calves, and 800 sheep. Rosemary also makes ice cream, yogurt, and cream.

Hilary spent the morning in the ice cream shop, bottling milk and packing ice cream. She wanted to taste the ice cream but didn't.

At lunchtime, Hilary checked the sheep. She helped a sheep that had fallen over. If sheep stay down too long, they can die. After feeding the calves, she started milking the cows. It took two and a half hours, and Rosemary does this twice a day, every day.

Hilary found the day lonely and missed the children. The hardest part of farming is not being able to take time off. Rosemary only gets about three days of holiday a year. Farming seems nice, but it's hard work, and the income is not steady.

A trumpet isn't just for Christmas... It's interesting how many famous musicians come from families without music. Hakan Hardenberger is one of them. He is the only son of parents who don't play music, and he grew up in a small town in southern Sweden. Now, at 30 years old, he is one of the best trumpet players in the world. He plays music from old composers and also new music. When you meet him, he looks young and friendly, just like the sound of his trumpet. 

Recently, he played the Hummel Trumpet Concerto in a big concert hall in London. There was also a TV show about his work and life, filmed in both London and Sweden. Hakan was born near Malmo, and his career started because of a Christmas gift when he was eight. His father, who liked Louis Armstrong, decided to give him a real trumpet, not a toy. Hakan loved it and played all the time. His mother found a trumpet teacher for him, Bo Nilsson, who was a talented musician. Bo saw Hakan's natural talent right away. Hakan is grateful for having such a good teacher from the start. Bo was very passionate about the trumpet and always looked for new ways to play better.

Hakan learned to work with the trumpet's imperfections. He says, "The trumpet is not perfect, but you can learn to work with its flaws." Even as a child, Hakan had a special sound that people could recognize. Unlike John Wallace, another famous trumpet player who started in brass bands, Hakan always wanted to be a solo artist. He admired Maurice Andre, a French trumpeter who also played solo. Hakan bought all his records and looked up to him. His parents supported his dream to become a professional trumpet player.

At 15, Hakan needed to decide where to study. America was too far and dangerous, so he went to Paris at 16 to study with Pierre Thibaud. Thibaud told him that playing in an orchestra is like working in a garden.
