Hakan knew he was good, but it was during a competition in Paris at 17 that he realized he could really connect with people through music. Thibaud suggested he enter the competition for practice. Hakan only prepared for the first round but made it to the final. He didn't win first prize, but he enjoyed playing and noticed that people listened to him, even if he thought he didn't play perfectly.

Hakan is realistic about his talent and doesn't try to explain why he can connect with people through music. He believes that music's power is in its ability to move people.

**A.** The story of Tristan Smith takes place in a made-up country called Efica. It is a special story about human power, history, and humor. The author has created a world with its own history and traditions. The book is funny and shows the author's unique way of seeing things. It is a difficult book to read, but it is worth it.

**B.** Harriet is a middle-class woman with an architect husband and her own business. She would not usually meet Sheila, who is a working-class woman taking care of her father and grandson, Leo. Their lives change when Leo attacks Harriet's son, Joe. After the court case, both boys do not want to talk about it. Leo was a good student and never fought before, and Joe becomes quiet after the attack. Harriet is very worried about her son, and Sheila feels guilty. They meet and become friends. The author is good at showing how people deal with big changes in their lives.

**C.** This book was nominated for the Booker prize. It tells the story of a small island in Scotland and its people over a long time. The story includes important moments in Scottish history. The main character, Throfinn Ragnarson, dreams about these events. He disappears for a while and comes back after World War II, learning to appreciate his ancestors' simple lives.

**D.** After a successful book, the author wrote a sequel with the same gentle humor and observations about family life. Fifteen years after her daughter's death, Aurora Greenway is almost seventy. She has a friend named Rosie Sunlap. Aurora is still charming and kind, and Rosie helps her with her life. By the end of the book, Aurora realizes that time has passed and a new generation is now important. The author shows the sadness in everyday life and how random events can be.

**E.** Six different people are brought together by a rich man named Logan Urquhart to sail around the South Pacific islands on his yacht, the Ardent Spirit. The author uses beautiful language to describe how each person learns about themselves during the trip. They return home with new energy and understanding. The author uses strong images to show themes of memory and awareness, which are both strange and enlightening.

**Take Five Careers**

Rebecca Cripps talks to five women about their jobs. They share the good and bad parts and what a typical day looks like.

**A. The Brain Surgeon**

**Name:** Anne  
**Age:** 34

**Anne's Day:**  
Anne wakes up at 6:30 am, goes to the gym at 7 am, and starts work at 8 am. She begins surgery at 8:30 am. She operates all day on Monday and Wednesday, and sometimes on Friday afternoons. Most surgeries take three hours, but some can last all day. Sometimes, she works for ten hours without eating or taking a break. Deciding when and how to operate can be stressful. She feels good when surgeries are successful, even though some are not. From 10 am to 1 pm, she talks to patients about their operations. She likes this part of her job. Anne leaves work between 6 pm and 8 pm. She is on call some nights and weekends. On holidays, she worries about her patients and dreams about work.

**B. The Senior Designer**

**Name:** Marita  
**Age:** 31

**Marita's Day:**  
Marita wakes up at 7:45 am, leaves home by 8:20 am, and arrives at work by 9:15 am. On Mondays at 10:30 am, her team meets to discuss their projects. Her team includes three senior designers, a company partner, and a junior designer. She spends three to four weeks designing and developing projects. After presenting her ideas to clients, she manages budgets and hires photographers and illustrators. She communicates with many people and ensures everything is done on time. Deadlines can be stressful, and her days are not structured. Lunch is at 1 pm for an hour. She gets home at 7:30 pm or later and finds it hard to relax.

**C. The Chauffeur**

**Name:** Linda  
**Age:** 42

**Linda's Day:**  
Linda usually wakes up at 7 am, but on some days, she gets up between 4:30 am and 5 am to meet flights. She exercises to stay healthy because her job involves a lot of sitting. She eats a big breakfast and snacks during the day. Linda needs to know good restaurants and shops to recommend to clients. Most jobs are booked in advance, so she can plan her routes. Some passengers are rude, but most are nice. She works seven days a week, up to fifteen hours a day, and tries to sleep by 11 pm.

**D. The Landscape Gardener**

**Name:** Tracy  
**Age:** 27

**Tracy's Day:**  
Tracy wakes up at 7 am and starts work at 7:30 am. She and her assistant maintain gardens they designed. They work mostly in private gardens, spending about an hour and a half at each. They have breakfast at a cafe around 11 am. In summer, Tracy works until 10 pm; in winter, until 4:30 pm. Her office is at home, so she checks messages and calls when she returns. She meets clients in the evening to discuss garden designs. Tracy uses old materials to make gardens look old. She finds it hard to relax because she can hear the business phone. She sleeps well because her job is very physical.

**E. The Civil Engineer**

**Name:** Zena  
**Age:** 27

**Zena's Day:**  
Zena arrives at the construction site by 8:30 am. She helps build bridges and a wall to keep cars safe. She checks that workers follow the plan and safety rules. Zena talks to the site team and solves problems. Workers start at 6 am, so she first checks what happened overnight. She handles paperwork and answers design questions. Lunch is usually a quick break between 2 pm and 2:30 pm. She checks the site when workers are on their lunch break. Zena tries to keep a good relationship with the workers. She leaves the site around 6 pm and is always on call.

**Careers: Six People Talk About Their Typical Working Day**

**A. Credit Card Executive**
I wake up at 6 am and get to the office by 7:30 am. I work with customer programs for our credit card users. I help start and manage the Membership Rewards program in Europe. I talk to current card users, find new ones, and work with partner companies. I spend the first 45 minutes planning my day and answering emails. I handle advertising for the membership program, so I meet with marketing staff and advertising agencies to plan and develop strategies. I have meetings most of the day, but I keep my door open for questions. I travel to different markets in Europe once or twice a week. When I'm in London, I leave work between 6:30 pm and 7:00 pm.

**B. Record Company Executive**
I start work at 10:00 am and check the mail, which includes demo tapes, letters, and invoices. The phone starts ringing at 10:30 am with calls from producers and publishers. I have meetings about campaigns or projects for artists. When I listen to demo tapes, I try to be helpful because it's important to the artists. I know if the sound fits our label. After signing a band, we work on the first album, choosing songs and musicians. I share my vision of the album with the company for marketing. I also manage budgets. I leave work at 7:00 pm and often go to concerts, sometimes seeing up to five new groups a night. I might visit an artist in the studio after a concert. I usually get home by 1:00 am and listen to music to relax.

**C. Sales Director**
I wake up at 8:00 am and drive to work, arriving by 9:30 am. I check the mail and diary to see if we have clients visiting. I enjoy showing people around the showroom and selling furniture. We sell antiques and buy from various places. Some items need restoration, so I work with restorers. I read the Antiques Trade Gazette to stay updated and visit museums to compare furniture. I do the accounts once a month and tax returns every three months. I go home at 5:30 pm and take about an hour to relax.

**D. Air Traffic Controller**
I work in shifts. On early shifts, I leave home at 6:00 am and start work at 7:00 am. I take over one of the four control positions in the tower. We work in a team to control aircraft movements. In winter, we handle about 1,000 movements a day, more in summer. Night shifts are quieter, and I can read about new air traffic rules. It's important to be alert, so I take sick leave if needed. The job is stressful, and it takes time to relax after a shift. I hope to become a watch manager and maybe a general manager one day.

**E. Shop Manager**
On early shifts, I leave home by 8:00 am. I start the electronic sales system and make sure someone is at the till. I help customers find and order books. I enjoy serving customers, even if it can be a bit annoying when they bring in reviews. Between 2:00 pm and 4:00 pm, publishers' reps visit, and we discuss new books. I decide how many copies to order. If we feature a new book, I ensure it's delivered on time. The early shift ends at 5:45 pm. I work late shifts twice a week, closing the shop and going home.

**F. Financial Analyst**
I listen to the news at 7:00 am, then take a taxi to work, arriving at 8:45 am. I contact freelance reporters to learn about my region. I assess financial risks for companies abroad and warn clients of potential problems. I provide three services: an online newsflash, a security forecast, and a travel security guide. From 9:15 am to 9:30 am, I meet with editors to discuss stories. My first newsflash is due by 10:00 am, and the second by 11:00 am. I write, edit, and send stories quickly. I travel to Africa three times a year to report on events. I leave work around 6:00 pm, but it's hard to relax, and I'm often awake until 1:00 am.

**Career Power: How to Be a Good Leader at Work**

A. **What Makes a Good Leader?**

A good leader inspires others and helps them change. They show the way forward. Leadership is not about being tall or very smart. Pat Dixon, who wrote a book about men and women at work, says leadership is about making things happen with people who are as excited as you are. Enthusiasm is important. A good leader should speak clearly and with confidence. They should say "I believe" instead of "I think."

B. **Can Anyone Be a Leader?**

John van Maurik, who teaches about leadership, says many people can be leaders, but they don't know it. To become a leader, you need to find and use your hidden talents. We are all born with the ability to lead, but we need the right situation to show it. We often see leaders like Mahatma Gandhi or Richard Branson, but leadership is also important in our own jobs.

C. **Think About Your Bosses**

Think about the best and worst boss you have had. Both might have been good at meeting goals and deadlines. But how did they do it? The best boss motivated and supported you. The worst boss made you feel unimportant and blamed you when things went wrong. The first boss led well; the second just managed badly.

D. **Leaders vs. Managers**

Leaders and managers are different. Managers like to work within set rules. Leaders create new paths. A good manager can keep a company running, but a good leader can change a company for the better.

E. **Improve Your Leadership Skills**

Whether you are the boss or a middle manager, you can learn to be a better leader. Here are some tips:

- Leadership is best when you choose to do it. Find out what you care about and act on it.
- Think of yourself as a leader. Believe in your ability to lead.
- Sometimes you need to lead firmly. Try different styles. If you usually ask others for their views, try taking the lead yourself.
- Set goals and try to beat them. Look at your job and see where being a leader can help you do better.

F. **Keep Learning**

- Leadership takes practice. You need to take risks and learn from mistakes. Learn to delegate, motivate, and organize.
- Your way of leading might not work for everyone. Keep improving your communication skills. You don't have to be liked, but your ideas should be.
- Be visible and easy to reach for those who matter. Remember, you don't have to lead all the time. Know where your help is needed and help others become leaders too.

**Films on Video: Reviews by Nick James**

**A. Abyss**  
Before making Titanic, director James Cameron created this exciting Cold War thriller. It is about oil workers and navy experts trying to save a nuclear submarine deep underwater. The main character, Bud, and his team are brave and funny, reminding us of heroes in old movies. The special effects are amazing, but the story is simple and the dialogue is not very strong.

**B. The Thin Red Line**  
This movie is based on a book about the battle for Guadalcanal. Directed by Andrew Marton, it is a more traditional war movie compared to Terrence Malick's new version. Marton's film focuses on one soldier and his tough sergeant. It has some good moments, like a flashback where the soldier dreams of his wife. This scene is more intense than Malick's softer version.

**C. On Guard**  
This movie is based on a novel from 1875. It is a fun adventure with sword fights. Fabrice Luchini plays a clever villain, and Vincent Perez is a lively hero. Daniel Auteuil is a serious acrobat-turned-swordsman. The movie uses many costume-drama clichés, but it is entertaining and full of energy.

**D. Character**  
Set in early 1900s Rotterdam, this film looks like a museum piece because of its detailed costumes and sets. Jan Decleir plays a strict bailiff named Dreverhaven, who is harsh when evicting people. The story focuses on his difficult relationship with his son, but the film spends too much time on period details.

**E. The Good, the Bad and the Ugly**  
This re-released video shows director Leone's skills well. The sound is very clear, making every noise stand out. The story is intense, and the music by Morricone adds excitement. The main characters, played by Clint Eastwood, Lee van Cleef, and Eli Wallach, are all equally ruthless as they travel through the post-Civil War West.

**F. The Longest Day**  
This war movie features many international stars and thousands of extras. It is a big production with four directors. The early scenes, where soldiers wait for the invasion, are slow. The movie is impressive in size but is better suited for the big screen. Watching it on video makes it less impactful.

**BOOK A**  
"Compelling Evidence" by Steve Martin is a very interesting book. The story is about a lawyer who starts a new job after leaving a big law firm. He has to defend his boss's wife in a murder trial. The trial is exciting, and the ending is surprising. This is a great first book in a popular genre.

**BOOK B**  
"Curtains for the Cardinal" is an exciting story. It is set in the Italian Renaissance and follows Sigismondo, who solves problems for rich people. He deals with politics and murder. The story is a bit complicated and long, but it is still very enjoyable.

**BOOK C**  
"File Under: Deceased" is a new detective story by Sarah Lacey. The main character, Leah Hunter, is a tax inspector. She starts investigating when a man dies near her. Leah is brave and smart, and she is a great character.

**BOOK D**  
"Double Deuce" by Robert B. Parker is about a private investigator named Spenser. He helps his friend Hawk to stop drug dealers in Boston. The book has fast dialogue and some action. It is entertaining and well-written.

**BOOK E**  
"False Prophet" by Faye Kellermann features detectives Pete Decker and Marge Dunn. They investigate a crime at a famous actress's daughter's house. The writing is easy to read, and the story is interesting.

**BOOK F**  
"Blood Red, Snow White" is written by Diane Henry and Nicholas Horrock. It is about a lawyer who helps a woman, but then he becomes a victim. The story has romance, money, and violence, making it a thrilling read.

**BOOK G**  
"Dead for a Ducat" by Simon Shaw is about actor Philip Fletcher. He is part of a movie about Robin Hood, but things go wrong. The book is funny, but not as good as Shaw's other works.

**BOOK H**  
"Fall Down Easy" by Lawrence Gough is a detective story. Canadian police try to catch a smart bank robber who targets female bank workers. The story builds tension well and is better than many other detective books.

Text: Tim Pozzi is 34 years old. He left his good job to go backpacking. He wants to travel in South East Asia for a year. Tim is a bit nervous because he is older now. After university, he traveled for two years in North and South America. He always wanted to travel again, but life got busy. He fell in love, started a career, and bought a flat. But he felt he was giving up his happiness for money. When he quit his job, he felt free. 

Many of Tim's friends are married with children. They have responsibilities, but Tim does not. He is not in a relationship and has no big career plans. He wants to enjoy his freedom. But he is nervous about renting his flat and planning the trip. He is also worried about living simply again and meeting younger backpackers. 

Many people in their late twenties and thirties want to travel. They want to leave their busy lives and see the world. Jennifer Cox from Lonely Planet says people now know they can have adventures if they are brave and organized. 

Danny, a 30-year-old accountant, and his girlfriend Tammy, a 28-year-old teacher, are traveling for a year before settling down. Danny says he is ready to give up job security for the trip. Matt, who left the Army, traveled for a year to change his way of thinking. 

Today, more people work on short-term contracts. Some companies let people take breaks from work to travel. Dan Hiscocks from Travellerseye says many people in their thirties think about their lives and want change. Travel helps them think about what they really want. 

Jennifer Cox says people now want a balanced life, not just to pay bills. Ben, a 32-year-old, is going to Central America. He is not running away; he is looking for something new. He is a bit scared to leave his routine, but he wants to try. 

Tim feels the same. He is excited about the next year. He wants to enjoy life and see what happens. Many people like Tim want to travel and find new adventures.

Georgina McGuiness took a long break from her job in journalism. She felt she didn't know much about new technology. Here, she tells how she changed her home into a good place to work. Two Christmases ago, she turned 37 and realized she needed to restart her career in journalism. Her skills were old, from the 1980s, when people used typewriters. She thought no one would hire her to work on a computer. Many jobs wanted people who knew desktop publishing, but she didn't. She felt she had a better chance of teaching nuclear physics than using a computer to design a page. She was not good with technology; even simple things like calculators confused her. She didn't know how to use the timer on the video player. She knew she needed to learn quickly.

Then, she entered a competition in a local newspaper and won a computer package for her family. They got a laptop for her husband and a personal computer for everyone. They started learning about new things like the Internet and surfing the web. They talked to people around the world online. The children stopped watching TV, and Georgina set up a small office in the kitchen. She had a phone, a fax machine, a CD-ROM, and a modem to connect to the Internet. She could work from home and still take her children to school. The children were good with computers because they learned at school. Georgina was scared she might lose her work by pressing the wrong button, but she learned the basics. It was easy and made sense. She learned more every day.

Now, she writes two articles a month for a magazine. She feels happy because she can work and be with her family. The computer helps her stay organized. She uses spreadsheets to track money and has ready-made invoices and letterheads. The Internet helps her research stories and talk to other journalists. But working from home can be lonely. There are also distractions, like house chores, and the children sometimes argue over who uses the computer. Many people now buy computers for learning and fun. In her neighborhood, people work from home instead of traveling to the city. 

A report says the typical computer user is 38 years old and well-educated. Most have a personal computer, and many have a CD-ROM, laser printer, and modem. Georgina feels she is doing well. She hopes to send articles to newspapers in Melbourne or even start her own magazine from home. The possibilities are endless.

**The Tartan Museum**

The Tartan Museum is in Edinburgh, Scotland. It has new, modern buildings that look different from the old city around it. Sally Varlow visited the museum before it opened to see if the inside was as interesting as the outside.

The museum is easy to find because of its big, yellow sandstone tower and unique shape. People had different opinions about the building. Some loved it, calling it a "masterpiece," while others were not sure or did not like it at all.

Inside the museum, there are many stories about Scotland's history. The museum shows important objects like Mary Queen of Scots' jewels and silver from Holyrood chapel. The museum does not just focus on national pride but tells many different stories.

Dr. David Clarke, who is in charge of the exhibitions, wants the museum to be fun and interesting for everyone, not just experts. He believes in showing the truth about history, so there are no fake scenes or made-up stories. The museum uses explanation panels, captions, and some computers to tell the stories.

When you enter the museum, you see many different rooms with pale walls and big display cases. There is a lot of natural light, and you can take your time to look at everything.

The museum also has a Discovery Centre for children, thanks to a group of 9- to 12-year-olds from Scotland. They wanted to ride through the displays, but instead, they got a special hands-on area for kids.

On the top floor, there is a Twentieth Century gallery. It shows objects that people in Scotland think are important, like an electric guitar, televisions, and toys. This part of the museum will change every three years.

Dr. Clarke believes that objects help us understand the past better than anything else. The modern building looks great from the inside, but some people wonder if it fits well with the old city around it.

Text: 'The end of print newspapers might take a long time. Change can be scary for some people, but it can also be exciting. Transition means moving from the present to the future. For newspapers, moving to the online world is not easy. Many people think it will happen because print newspaper sales are going down, and visits to their websites are going up. For example, The Daily Telegraph and The Guardian have fewer print sales, but more people visit their websites. However, the situation is not the same everywhere. In some places, like Asia, print sales are still growing. News magazines are also doing well, with a 5.4% increase in sales. Books are another example. E-readers like Kindle are popular, but physical book sales are almost the same as before. People still like both screens and paper. Many young people still read newspapers. In the UK, newspaper sales have dropped, but in Germany and France, the drop is smaller. This shows that the situation is different in each country. In the US, online ads are not making as much money as before, so newspapers are charging for online access. Many newspapers offer a deal with both print and online access. Print is still important for selling online subscriptions. Print ads make more money than online ads. This is a problem for newspapers because running both print and online editions is hard and expensive. But print still helps newspapers stay well-known.'

**Photographing People**

Taking pictures of people is very interesting. Photos with people in them are usually more exciting than those without. But, taking good pictures of people can be hard. You need to think about how people move and show their feelings. Sometimes, the camera can make people act differently.

**A. Grouping People**

When taking pictures of groups, don't make them stand in straight lines. Ask them to stand at different angles or levels. Some can sit or kneel in front so you can see all faces. You can also take the picture from a higher place.

**B. Posing for Pictures**

People often feel stiff in front of a camera. Help them relax by finding a comfortable position. They can fold their hands or put them in their pockets.

**C. The Right Approach**

Don't pretend you are not taking a picture. This can make people feel tense. Most people will agree to have their picture taken. They might feel shy at first, but they usually like it. You might need to guide them a bit. Make sure they are not looking away from the camera.

**D. Eye Contact**

A picture is more powerful if the person looks at the camera. Ask them to look into the lens. They don't have to smile. Remind them to look just before you take the picture. You can also say something funny to get a real reaction.

**E. Candid Concentration**

Instead of looking at the camera, the person can focus on something else in the picture. This can make the picture feel more natural. It looks like you are watching them without them knowing.

**F. Expressions and Gestures**

Expressions and gestures show a lot about a person. A laughing child makes us smile, while a sad face makes us feel sad too. Look for familiar expressions like winks, anger, or thumbs-up. They are easy to understand.

**G. Situation Interest**

A background can add more information to a picture. Make sure the background is not too busy. Focus on the person. Use a wide-angle lens to make the person look bigger compared to the background.

**H. Interaction**

When people are talking, joking, or working together, you can take great pictures. Look for eye contact or physical contact, like a handshake. Show how one person reacts to another.

**I. People and Places**

Many pictures are taken on holidays to show where people visited. Use a wide-angle lens to include the background. Ask people to stand close to the camera. This way, you can see both the people and the place.

**J. To Pose or Not to Pose?**

Decide why you want to take the picture. If you want to remember someone, ask them to pose with a nice background. Family pictures can be more fun if they are not posed. Candid pictures of real moments are more lively and memorable.

**Under Sarah's Spell**

Sarah Janson is an artist who makes trompe-l'oeil paintings. These paintings trick the eye and look very real. Joanna Watt interviews her.

Sarah Janson does not usually sign her paintings unless someone asks her to. She believes the art is more important than the artist. Sarah is very humble and sometimes acts like her paintings make themselves. She does not like to talk about herself and feels shy about being photographed.

Sarah has been a trompe-l'oeil artist for sixteen years. She studied drawing for two years at art school, got a degree in graphic illustration, and worked at a publishing house. But she did not enjoy illustration. She then worked with a decorator named Jim Smart, who asked her to make a trompe-l'oeil painting. She loved it and decided to start her own business.

Sarah's skills in observing and focusing on details help her in trompe-l'oeil art. She says you cannot learn trompe-l'oeil from someone else; it is about observing life. She believes she is still learning and says, "If you think you know everything, you should stop."

Sarah is honest about her weaknesses. She says she cannot paint bread well and struggles with math. When she had to paint a big ceiling, she felt confused and thought, "Who do you think you are, Michelangelo?"

Sarah sometimes talks about herself in the third person, saying, "I didn't do it, she did." Her work is very good, and she has many important projects. Her paintings often look like parts of buildings. For example, she painted a dining room to look like a Venetian palace and a corridor that seems to lead to more rooms.

Trompe-l'oeil art must trick you and keep your interest. Sarah believes it should also be personal for the client. She enjoys working with clients and getting ideas from them. Many clients become her friends because she spends a lot of time with them while working.

Sarah appreciates her clients and says she is thankful for those who let her paint on their walls. She is always busy because people like her work, even though she does not like to talk about her talent. She says, "I don't like to shout about myself. Like my work, I am quiet. You get bored with things that shout." But you could never get bored with Sarah or her art. Her work deserves more attention.

**Emotional Intelligence - The Key to Success**

**A** The way we work is changing. We are not only judged by how smart we are or our skills, but also by how we handle ourselves and others. This is important for getting jobs and promotions. These new skills can show who will do well and who might not. They are important for future jobs too. These skills are not about doing well in exams. They are about social skills and personal qualities like being able to start things, understand others, adapt, and persuade. These are called emotional intelligence.

**B** Today, job security is not guaranteed, so personal qualities are important at work. Emotional intelligence is a new name for skills like understanding and managing our own and others' feelings. It includes self-awareness, self-control, motivation, empathy, and good social skills. It is not just about being nice. Sometimes it means telling the truth even if it is hard. It is about managing feelings well so people can work together towards a goal.

**C** Many businesses now see emotional intelligence as important for managers. The more complex the job, the more these skills matter. People with good emotional intelligence can work better with others. In jobs that need teamwork and focus on customers, these skills are very important for doing well.

**D** Unlike IQ, which stays the same, emotional intelligence can grow as we learn from life. We can get better at handling emotions, motivating ourselves, and understanding others. This growth is called maturity. We can learn emotional intelligence skills, which are important when jobs are not stable. Emotional intelligence is not a magic solution for companies, but it helps everything work better.

Text: 'Should the media make money from content they don't own? Digital cameras and camera phones make it easy to take pictures of important events. Social media has changed how people share these pictures. Now, news often appears first on social media. Some journalists use these pictures from social media when events happen quickly. But sometimes, they use these pictures without asking for permission. There are rules that say it's okay to use pictures without permission in special cases or if the public needs to know. However, people still argue about whether this is right. Research shows that about one in ten people would take pictures or videos of a news event. This means that pictures from regular people are important for the media. But, to keep a good relationship with the public, the media should make sure people get credit and ask for permission before using their work.'

**Ancient Chinese Medicine in the West**

**Acupuncture: An Old Practice**

Acupuncture is a part of ancient Chinese medicine and is about 2,000 years old. It includes using herbs, massage, diet, and exercise. Acupuncture is mainly known in the West for helping with pain. Some doctors, midwives, and physiotherapists use it to help people feel less pain.

**How Does It Work?**

In traditional Chinese medicine, being healthy means your mind, body, and spirit are balanced. Energy, called Qi (pronounced "chee"), moves through the body along paths called meridians. There are twelve main meridians, each connected to an organ. If Qi is blocked or weak, you might feel sick or weak. An acupuncturist checks your wrist pulse, looks at your tongue, and asks about your health and habits to find where Qi is not balanced. They use thin needles on the skin to help Qi flow better. Sometimes, they use heat or pressure on certain points.

**Acupuncture Points**

There are over 300 points on the main meridians where needles can be placed. These points might not be near where you feel pain. People often feel a dull ache or tingling when the needle is used. This feeling means the needle has reached the Qi.

**Scientific View**

Even if they don't believe in traditional Chinese ideas, some doctors think acupuncture can help with pain. They say it might work by blocking pain signals to the brain or by releasing natural painkillers in the body.

**Types of Pain Treated**

People with long-term pain often try acupuncture. It is used for back pain, sports injuries, arthritis, headaches, and pain after surgery. Acupuncturists also say it can help with menstrual pain, facial nerve pain, and pain in very sick people.

**Modern Use**

Acupuncture has been used in China for over 2,000 years. In the 1950s, it started being used instead of anesthesia during surgery. This showed some doctors outside China that acupuncture could be more than just a mental effect. In China, it is used in many surgeries, sometimes with electrical stimulation or drugs. It is said to reduce pain without the side effects of regular anesthesia.

**Effectiveness**

It is hard to test acupuncture in clinical trials, but some studies show that 50 to 80 percent of people find it helps with long-term pain. Acupuncturists say it usually takes six or seven visits to feel real relief, but some improvement can be felt after two or three visits.

**Different Views on Pain**

Western and Chinese medicine see pain differently. Acupuncturists look at the whole person, not just the symptoms. They try to find out what makes the pain worse, like cold, heat, or dampness. This helps them decide how to treat the pain.

**Choosing an Acupuncturist**

Some medical professionals are trained in traditional acupuncture, while others use scientific methods. Traditional acupuncturists believe their way can lead to a longer-lasting cure. It is important to choose a good acupuncturist who will refer you to a doctor if needed.

P.D. James is a famous crime writer. Her full name is Phyllis Dorothy James. She seems very calm and confident, like a school headmistress, but she is actually shy. Her famous detective character, Adam Dalgliesh, is a bit like her. He likes to solve crimes alone, and she likes to write alone too. She needs privacy to write.

P.D. James is very popular, and her books are read by many people around the world. She has written 12 detective novels. She likes reading books by her friend Ruth Rendell, who also writes under the name Barbara Vine. She enjoys books by women writers like Iris Murdoch and Anita Brookner, but also likes male authors like Graham Greene.

P.D. James became successful later in life. She was 42 when her first book, "Cover Her Face," was published. She was born in Oxford and grew up in Cambridge. She met her husband, Connor Bantry White, in Cambridge. He was a doctor who became very sick after World War II. She had to work hard to support him and their two daughters, Clare and Jane. Her husband's parents helped take care of the children.

She worked for the National Health Service and later for the Home Office. She worked in the Police Department and the Criminal Law section. She saw many dead bodies while working in forensic science, but she was more interested in writing stories than in death itself. She always wanted to be a writer and liked detective stories.

Writing detective stories helped her become a better writer. She believes that solving a crime in a story shows that life is important, even if the person is not very nice. She thinks nobody really likes violence.

Title: Handwriting Can Show Who You Are

In some countries, when you apply for a job, you might need to give a sample of your handwriting. Your handwriting can help decide if you are right for the job. This is called handwriting analysis or graphology. Many people believe it is a real science. They say it can show if someone has certain illnesses like heart disease or cancer. It can also show how a person feels or if they have emotional problems.

Handwriting analysis is used to help people choose jobs and during job interviews. Many big companies use graphologists to look at the handwriting of people who want important jobs. But many doctors and psychiatrists do not believe in graphology.

Patricia Marne, a graphologist for over 20 years, thinks doctors should take it seriously. She says handwriting can show a person's social class, intelligence, and even if they are honest or not. She believes it can also show if someone might commit a crime. Criminals often have messy handwriting. They might write like children or go over letters many times.

Ms. Marne says handwriting can show if someone is under a lot of stress or if they might become violent. It can even show if someone might think about suicide. Health problems like heart and lung issues can also appear in handwriting. If handwriting changes a lot over time, it might mean something serious is happening.

Handwriting can also show other things about a person. If letters are connected like 'threads,' the person might be clever but tricky. Writing in all capital letters might mean someone is hiding their true self. Light writing can show sensitivity. Original handwriting can show confidence and artistic talent. Small signatures might mean someone feels shy or not good enough. Circles over the 'i' can mean the person wants attention. Crossing the 't' heavily can show someone is not tolerant.

Ms. Marne says it takes six years to learn how to analyze handwriting well. She thinks more research is needed to make graphology a real science. She believes it is more accurate than psychoanalysis because it can show a person's history without asking questions.

However, some psychiatrists do not agree. They say handwriting is just about education and artistic skill, not about personality or health.

Text: 'Is your office working well? Fresh air and good chairs are important for a happy, healthy team, says a new survey. We visited four different offices to see how healthy and happy they are. Our expert team included a building health consultant, an ergonomist (who studies people's working conditions), and an occupational psychologist. Here are their opinions.

Office A: Advertising Agency
Building Health Consultant: This office is very simple. There is no central heating or mechanical ventilation, and the windows open to the street. The team of seven people seems happy and has few complaints. They adjust to the seasons by opening doors and roof panels or using electric heaters, like at home. This might be why they are happy: they have created a homely work environment without outside rules.

Ergonomist: The furniture is mixed and does not match. Some of it causes bad sitting positions. Chairs are old, most can't be adjusted, and many are broken. But the team has different tasks, like office work, meeting clients, and giving presentations. This variety helps prevent tiredness and boredom.

Occupational Psychologist: The staff enjoys the variety of work and the flexible office space. They think the office is 'just the right size'—small enough to know what others are doing, but big enough to work alone. The office is attractive and fun, showing both efficiency and creativity.

Office B: News Service
Building Health Consultant: The office is not very exciting but comfortable. The air quality is good, helped by a No Smoking policy.

Ergonomist: The company has used an ergonomist before. Chairs, lighting, and computer equipment are good. Space is good, but the layout could be better. The office is impersonal with grey, bare walls.

Occupational Psychologist: Walls are bare except for year planners and a poster about maternity rights. Most staff have been there for over five years, and relationships are okay. The office could be better if desks were arranged to share information more easily. Success stories or project information could be shown on the walls.

Office C: Bank
Building Health Consultant: People have mixed feelings about this office. It feels like being in a glass case. Even with smokers and non-smokers in a small space, the air is not stale. You can't smell cigarettes even when close to a smoker.

Ergonomist: The office is very standard and not inspiring. Desks are just okay. Not all chairs meet requirements, but this is the user's choice. Computer screens are on small desks with lowered keyboard shelves, which is not good for modern equipment.

Occupational Psychologist: Staff support each other and have good technology. Many communication awards are displayed. The wood-colored panels and brown carpet make it look a bit dull. The office is busy.

Office D: Newspaper
Building Health Consultant: It's hard to say anything good about this office. The air-conditioning is poor, causing big temperature changes. The space is cluttered, and desks are too small. The office is dusty, and the roof collects dust, which falls on people below.

Ergonomist: The furniture looks like it belongs in a workshop, not a high-tech office. Most chairs are not good for keyboard users, especially shorter people. Many chairs are old, can't be adjusted, and have armrests that keep users too far from the desk.

Occupational Psychologist: Old brown chairs, dirty carpets, dust everywhere. The office needs cleaning and better air conditioning because there are many smokers. Few people were talking when we visited; everyone seemed stressed by deadlines. The company should encourage teamwork.'

**Chewing Gum Culture**

Chewing gum is popular and people in America chew 12 million pieces every day. It has less than ten calories per piece and is considered a food, so it must follow the rules of the American Food and Drug Administration. Today, most gum is made from synthetic materials with added pine resins and softeners to keep the flavor and make it feel nice to chew.

A long time ago, the ancient Greeks chewed a gum-like resin from the bark of the mastic tree, which grows in Greece and Turkey. Greek women liked mastic gum to clean their teeth and make their breath smell nice. In America, early settlers learned from the Native Americans in New England to chew resin from spruce trees. In the early 1800s, people in the eastern United States could buy spruce gum, making it the first commercial chewing gum in the country.

Modern chewing gum started in the late 1860s with chicle, a milky substance from the sapodilla tree in Central America. This gum was smoother and more elastic, leading to a new industry. However, growing sapodilla trees for chicle has not been successful. As the gum market grew, synthetic alternatives were created. Today, the few remaining chicle gatherers, called chicleros, have a tough and dangerous job. They walk long distances in hot, humid forests to collect chicle. They face dangers like poisonous snakes and insects. The chicle fly is especially bad because it lays eggs in the chicleros' ears and nose. Chicleros climb trees with just a rope and an axe to collect the sap, which they carry to a camp to boil and make into bricks. Life at the camp is hard, with simple food and local alcohol.

Even though their work is difficult, chicleros worry about losing their jobs. The United States used to import 7,000 tonnes of chicle each year from Central America, but last year only 200 tonnes were collected in Mexico's Yucatan peninsula. As gum sales have increased, manufacturers use synthetic materials to save money and meet demand.

Gum producers are finding new ways to sell their products. They say gum helps you relax, gives you energy, and reduces stress. During both world wars, soldiers were given gum. Gum is also said to reduce tooth decay by increasing saliva, which helps protect teeth. Research continues to find new textures and flavors. Glycerine and vegetable oils are used to mix the gum base. Most new flavors are artificial, but some still need natural help. In America, 137 square kilometers of land is used to grow mint for the two most popular chewing gums in the world.

**Remote Hotels**

**A. India - Ghanerao Hotel, Rajasthan**  
Ghanerao Hotel is in a small village near the Aravalli Hills. The village is known for its craftsmen. The hotel combines English calm with Indian style. The Ghanerao family has lived here for 400 years. Now, Sajjan Singh and his wife welcome guests. The hotel is simple, with hot water brought in buckets, but this makes it special.

**B. New Zealand - Hermitage Hotel, Mount Cook**  
The Hermitage Hotel is on New Zealand's South Island. I found it by accident while climbing. We climbed a glacier and walked down to find this hotel. It is in beautiful, wild countryside. After a tiring climb, it was amazing to find such luxury, with someone playing piano music.

**C. Mauritius - Beachcomber Paradis Hotel**  
The Paradis Hotel is on a quiet peninsula in southwest Mauritius. The road to the hotel passes empty beaches. The hotel is big, with free watersports. You can find peace on nine kilometers of private beach. Swim a little into the ocean, and the hotel is hidden by palm trees. In the evening, the beach feels far from everything.

**D. St Lucia - Ladera Hotel**  
The Ladera Hotel in St Lucia has a stunning view. It is quiet and high up, with rooms open to the sea view between the Pitons mountains. The style is colonial, with wooden furniture and beds with netting.

**E. Turkey - The Splendid Hotel, Istanbul**  
This hotel is on Buyukada in the Princes Islands, a quiet escape from Istanbul. The islands are an hour by boat and have no cars, only horse carriages. The hotel is a wooden building, painted white with red domes. It looks like an old hotel from the French Riviera. It is a bit old now but still charming.

**F. France - Chateau d'Etoges, Epernay**  
In the village of Etoges, in Champagne, is a beautiful old chateau. It has a moat with swans. The chateau has 20 different rooms, some with four-poster beds. One room even has a billiard table. There are special weekend offers with breakfast, dinner, and champagne.

**G. Kenya - The Fairview Hotel, Nairobi**  
The Fairview Hotel is a comfortable place in Africa. It is a stop for travelers resting from safaris. Some guests decide to stay longer after seeing the gardens and rooms. The hotel is on Nairobi Hill, away from the busy city. It is a great place to watch the sunset and enjoy a good dinner.

**H. Italy - Hotel Splendido, Portofino**  
The Duke of Windsor was the first guest at Hotel Splendido. Many famous people have stayed here, like Lauren Bacall and Humphrey Bogart. Now, you might meet rich business people. The hotel was once a monastery and is still very splendid. The restaurant serves simple, delicious food.

**The Hotel Inspector**

Sue Brown works as a hotel inspector. She checks hotels to see if they are good. Christopher Middleton watched her do her job. 

When Sue visits the Globe Hotel, things start to go wrong quickly. The receptionist is talking on the phone and does not notice Sue. Sue whispers, "Very poor." This is a common mistake she has seen many times in her 11 years as an inspector. The Globe Hotel has three red stars, which means it is one of the top 130 hotels out of 4,000 in the guide Sue works for. 

Sue is not happy with the hotel entrance. She had to use a buzzer to get in and walk through a long, empty corridor. Then, the receptionist says they have no record of Sue's booking. Most of the hotel rooms are empty that night. Sue checks a room on the top floor and does not like it. It is stuffy, and there is a big hole in the wall behind the wardrobe.

Sue is known for being tough. People used to call her "The Woman in Black," even though she never wore black. The next morning, after paying her bill, Sue tells the hotel manager, Robin Greaves, who she is. He looks worried. He apologizes for a bad smell in the lounge. Sue suggests fixing the plumbing and not taking guests to that room. Greaves agrees and takes notes. He has only been at the hotel for five months. Sue tells him that her feedback will help the hotel in the long run.

Not everything is bad. Sue praises Emma, the assistant manager, and Trudy, the waitress, for their good work. The dinner was good enough to keep the hotel's two-rosette food rating. Greaves asks what they need to do to get three rosettes. Sue says, "Not serve a pudding that collapses."

Sue's job is to tell hotels what they need to improve. Sometimes people get upset with her feedback. She has to give a full written report to the hotel. Hotels pay to be in the guide, so they want to know how to improve. 

Sue tells Greaves that she will not recommend taking away the Globe's red stars. This is good news. But another inspector will come in the next two months to check if the hotel has improved. Greaves says, "Good," but he does not look happy.

**Style Merchants**

Style is important in our lives today. It affects our clothes, home decoration, and accessories. Jo Foley talks about fashion trends for this year.

**Ned Ingham: Dress Designer**

Ned Ingham makes beautiful wedding dresses. He says people should choose simple styles instead of traditional, fancy dresses. Ned started drawing and designing dresses when he was a schoolboy. At 16, he went to fashion school to learn how to make clothes. He also designs long evening dresses with new colors and fabrics. For those who like classic styles, he has a navy-blue suit that looks modern.

**Sally Quail: Jeweller**

Sally Quail used to work for an art dealer but did not study jewelry formally. She started designing jewelry when she couldn't find an engagement ring she liked. In 1990, she became a designer. Many famous people like her jewelry. She uses large stones in gold to make necklaces, bracelets, and rings. Recently, she started using diamonds because she feels it suits her age.

**Lily Grimson: Handbag Designer**

Lily Grimson started her fashion business four years ago. She only took a basic art and design course. Two of her handbags were chosen for a big design exhibition. Her bags are handmade in the UK and are very stylish. They are made from fine materials like calfskin and silk.

**Peter Little: Hairdresser**

Peter Little has been a hairdresser for over 20 years. Many famous people have had their hair styled by him. He believes women want hair that looks natural and is easy to manage. His haircuts cost £250, and there is a long waiting list. Peter also sells his own hairdryers and styling tools.

**Penny Pratt: Florist**

Penny Pratt runs a small flower shop and works as a flower consultant for supermarkets and restaurants. She used to be a teacher but changed careers 10 years ago. Her simple and modern flower arrangements have won many prizes. She also teaches at her London Flower School and gives lectures in Japan and the USA. She advises keeping flower arrangements simple and using the same type of flowers for wedding bouquets.

Text: 'Luxury and Modern Technology at the Merrion Hotel The Merrion Hotel is a new five-star hotel in Dublin. It took almost two years to change four old houses into this hotel. The hotel has the latest technology for both staff and guests. The General Manager, Peter MacCann, wants his staff to know guests by name. For other details, he uses a computer system. This system helps the hotel treat returning guests in a special way. It cost a lot of money, but MacCann believes it will be worth it. For example, if a guest likes certain music CDs, they will have them ready on their next visit. The system remembers what guests like. Many guests often complain about room temperature. The hotel has a special system to control this. Guests can change the temperature a little in their rooms. The front desk can also change it more if needed. Business guests will like the technology in the rooms. MacCann thinks many guests will be business people. Each room has three phones, two phone lines, a fax machine, and a video-conferencing tool. The hotel is ready for future technology changes. They have extra cables and rent TVs so they can easily update them. DVD players can also be upgraded. Even with all this technology, the rooms are comfortable and welcoming. The hotel has 145 large rooms, a swimming pool, gym, six conference rooms, two bars, two restaurants, and a beautiful garden. The food at the hotel is excellent. Chef Patrick Guilbaud, who has two Michelin stars, moved his restaurant to the hotel. This is good for both him and the hotel. He has a new kitchen and better parking. The hotel offers a great place to eat without financial risk. With technology and a great staff, the Merrion Hotel is set to do well.'

Susan Shepherd is an artist who paints flowers. She is famous for her flower paintings. Her house has a big garden with many flowers. She likes tulips and poppies the most. Some plants grow everywhere in the garden by themselves. The garden looks nice because of the colors and shapes of the flowers. The people who lived there before Susan loved gardening and left many plants for her. They also left a gardener named Danny. Susan says, "It was really his garden." They worked well together. At first, Danny did not like some of Susan's ideas, but when she explained she wanted to paint them, he understood.

Susan likes to paint one flower at a time. Sometimes she paints a group of flowers, but usually, she picks them and takes them to her studio. She paints one flower, which can take a few days, and then adds another. Sometimes, it takes her a couple of years to finish a painting. She is very busy in spring and early summer when tulips and poppies bloom. She finds it interesting to watch how flowers change. For example, tulips change shape when you put them in water.

Susan has always liked plants. She studied botany in school and collected wildflowers. She did not like garden flowers before because they looked fake to her. She liked wildflowers because they grew in difficult places like rocks or cliffs. Now, her garden has plants from faraway places like China and the Himalayas. She lets the garden grow naturally, like a kind aunt who lets children play freely. Susan is busy with two art shows and has less time for gardening. She hired another gardener but still likes to work in the garden to stay connected to her flowers.

Many trees in the Brackham area fell down during the big storms in March. The town lost two big lime trees from the old market square. This changed how the town center looked, and some people were not happy about it. One of these people was Chief Inspector Douglas Pelham, the head of the local police. But during the storm, Pelham was too sick to notice. He was a strong and healthy man, but he got very sick with bronchitis for the first time in his life. When he first felt a headache and tightness in his chest, his wife, Molly, told him to see a doctor. Pelham thought the police needed him, so he ignored her and kept working. This made him forget things and get angry easily. Finally, his colleague, Sergeant Lloyd, took him to the doctor. He was too weak to argue. The doctor gave him antibiotics, and Molly took him home to rest. On Thursday morning, Molly told him the walnut tree in their garden had fallen, but Pelham was too sick to understand. By Thursday evening, he asked if the house was damaged. When he heard it wasn't, he was relieved and went back to sleep. On Saturday, after the medicine worked and he felt better, he saw that the missing walnut tree changed how the living room looked. The Pelhams' house was big and had a nice garden. Pelham liked the house because the garden made it feel private. But now, without the tree, the living room was very bright, and the old furniture looked shabby. The view from the window was not nice anymore. The tall house next door, which the tree used to hide, was now visible. It had ugly purple bricks and many windows that seemed to watch the Pelhams. Pelham said to his wife, "Doesn't it look terrible?" But Molly, standing in the doorway, seemed happy. She said, "I've been telling you since we moved here. We need to buy a new sofa, no matter the cost."

Living in the Valley

We had been living in our valley for sixteen months when we first understood the dangers in the hills around us. It was the year when the storms came early, even before November ended. Before that, we felt safe in our valley, protected by the hills. Soon, snow began to fall. In one day, it was about 15 centimeters deep. It almost blocked our road and made the path by the stream slippery and dangerous. But on the hills, the snow was much deeper and stayed longer. Up there, the wind was very strong. In our valley, we only felt sudden strong winds; trees moved, but the branches stayed strong. Still, we knew we had a reason to worry. The snow and wind were a problem, but they did not worry us too much. It was the river, the Ryburn, which was usually calm, that worried us the most. It reminded us of what could happen if the water from the hills was not controlled by dams built many years ago.

Soon, the snow started to melt. Every day, we watched dark clouds gather over the hills to the west. Grey clouds spread over the valleys. They moved and rose, warning us of what was coming. We had seen enough of the sky; now we watched the river, which was getting fuller and wilder every day. The snow was washed away as more rain came from the clouds, but high in the hills, the reservoir was filling and getting close to danger. Then it happened - for the first time in years, the reservoir overflowed. Up in the hills, it was like a waterfall, as water rushed over the dam and into the stream below. The river seemed wild as the water rushed down. Just a few meters from our cottage, the stream was wild under the bridge. It was deeper than we had ever seen it near our home, hitting its banks hard. For three days, we hoped it would stay below its wall. Luckily, our hopes came true as the dam held and the water started to go down.

In the past, before the dam was built, the river often flooded the nearby villages. Now, the dam controls the river, and usually, everything is fine; the water from the hills, from snow and heavy rain, stays behind the dam with only a little overflow sometimes. Because of this protection, we can enjoy the big clouds over the valley and be amazed by the river's power. Thanks to this, we feel our home in the valley is still safe and secure.

Mark Adams is a film critic. He has worked for a newspaper called The Front Page for ten years. Writing about films for this newspaper was his first real job. Before that, he wrote reviews for novels, films, and radio. He met Tom Seaton, the first arts editor of The Front Page, who also wrote for radio and TV. Tom hired Mark, but Tom was not mainly a journalist. He wanted a team of critics to write about books, TV, theatre, film, and radio. They would have weekly lunches to choose what to write about, and there would be guests to make it fun. 

Mark felt like he was dreaming because he was part of a new newspaper. He thought it was strange that a new paper could start in a busy market. He even thought a rich person might be pretending to hire him. He was not very confident. The first time he saw someone reading his review on the London Underground, he felt shy.

Tom's idea for a team of critics did not work out. They did not meet as planned and talked on the phone instead. People liked to know a reviewer for one subject, so Mark chose films. Thanks to Tom, Mark now writes a long piece each week about one film. He likes this way of working. He would not like to review every film that comes out because it would be boring. 

Mark wonders what his role is. He thinks people choose films because of the stars, the publicity, or the director. People usually stick to the types of films they like. A review might not change their mind. Mark does not feel he has to be 'right' about a movie. He just needs to give his opinion. He is not a judge and does not want to be one.

Why would a schoolgirl want to swim 1500 meters, cycle 40 kilometers, and then run 10 kilometers? Because "it's fun." A teenager who loves endurance sports is looking for a training partner. The partner should be a sports fan, preferably female, and interested in distance running, swimming, and cycling. The triathlon is becoming a popular Olympic sport. Many people watch athletes swim, cycle, and run without stopping. But why do athletes want to push their bodies so hard? And why does a smart 17-year-old girl, with good school results, choose this difficult sport?

Melanie Sears is a young triathlete. She hasn't learned to say things like "personal satisfaction" or "mental challenge" yet. She says, "You swim 1500 meters, then get on your bike while still wet. You feel cold. After cycling 40 kilometers, you run 10 kilometers, which is hard when you're tired. But it's great fun and worth it."

Melanie did her first triathlon at 14. She won the junior section because she was the only junior. She felt confident and entered the National Championships. She was fast in swimming and running but got lost while cycling and went 20 kilometers too far. She cried during the run but didn't give up.

Steve Trew, the sport's coaching director, admires her determination. He says she worked so hard on a running machine that it threw her off. Melanie was the top junior in this year's European Triathlon Championships, finishing 13th. She is working hard to improve her cycling.

Her parents are paying for her trip to New Zealand for the World Championships. She wants a new bike to compete in more races. Her training is tough, and she doesn't have much of a social life. She says, "I'm not a party person. After swimming on Friday nights, I just want to sleep. But I talk to other girls in the team about their race times."

Melanie has tried other events, like the triathlon "sprint," which is shorter. She wants to try even harder events. She says, "The big problem is, I have no one my age to train with." It's interesting, isn't it?

**The Collectors**

Amanda Roy talks about collecting things and why many people like this hobby. I have always loved collecting, and one in three adults enjoys this hobby too. Collecting is full of passion and happiness. But remember, if you don't love an object, don't collect it.

Since ancient times, people have wanted to collect things. Early humans collected pebbles and wore them as necklaces. They liked the shapes and colors. Today, children still collect stones and seashells for their beauty.

I have collected things all my life, like flowers, pottery, and paintings. My first collection was stones from my parents' garden. When I was six, I went to a school in a remote part of England. My parents took me to a local museum full of old objects. I loved these objects.

Many people like collecting. One in three adults shares this passion. Some people collect because it gives them control. For me, it's just fun.

A famous collector was the Duc de Berry in France. He had a 'room of wonders' with coconut shell cups and Oriental china. Catherine the Great of Russia collected over 4,000 paintings. But you don't need to be rich to collect. I have collected tulip bulbs and china cups with great effort. I once got a special tulip from another collector, but it was later stolen.

I also collected 350 American rag dolls. I searched all over the USA for them. But my collection was destroyed in a house fire. I was very sad.

I am interested in how collections change hands. A silver spoon that belonged to a king or poet is valuable. As small objects become popular, their prices go up. Toys from the 1950s are now valuable if you kept the original boxes. (I threw mine away, including the toys.)

**My Job**

Four people talk about their jobs.

**Lisa - Exhibition Programmes Organiser, Science Museum**

I organize temporary exhibitions at the Science Museum. I plan and design the exhibition and tell people about it. First, I learn about the exhibition topic and talk to experts. I decide on the main ideas and choose what objects and pictures to show. I make sure visitors understand the exhibition by planning interactive displays, workshops, and theatre. I also work with engineers and electricians to keep the exhibition safe. Before it opens, I help create brochures and leaflets to inform people.

**Janet - Teacher of London Taxi Drivers**

I start work at 7.30 a.m. by checking the accounts. I prepare new maps and documents for students to learn the routes for the London taxi-driver test. By midday, about 50 students are learning how to make the journeys. They find the best route using the correct streets and turns. I help when there is a disagreement, like if a right turn is possible at a junction. Before the test, I give them a simple route and then change it to make them think of another way.

**Sarah - Marine Conservationist**

I live by the coast and work from home. I answer phone calls, create educational materials, and set up training courses. Sometimes, I go to the main office, but mostly I am by the sea. I work with schools and study centers and run courses for people who make decisions about the sea. I take them out on a boat to help them understand sea life better. I love my job because conservation is my hobby. But, I work for a charity, so we always need more money, and I can't do everything I want.

**Chris - Map and Atlas Publisher**

My job is varied. I make sure our publishing matches what people want and keep stocks of about 300 books. We have high standards for information. We get letters from readers about things like international boundaries, and I answer them carefully. I talk about future projects and sales with co-publishers. I work with a great team, which makes the job fun. The downside is there is too much paperwork, leaving less time for interesting tasks like product development and design.

We always went to Ireland in June. Since we started going on holidays together, we spent the first two weeks of June at Glencorn Lodge in County Antrim. It's a big house by the sea, near the village of Ardbeag. An English couple, the Malseeds, bought the house and made some changes, but they did it very carefully. Strafe found Glencorn for us. He saw an advertisement when the Malseeds still needed to advertise. "How about this?" he said one evening and read the details. The summer before, we went to a hotel recommended by friends, but it wasn't good because the food was terrible. The four of us, Dekko, Strafe, Cynthia, and I, have been playing cards together for a long time. They call me Milly, but my real name is Dorothy Milson. Dekko got his nickname at school. He and Strafe went to school together, so we call Strafe by his last name, like the teachers did. We are all about the same age and live near the town where the Malseeds lived before moving from England to Ireland. We think it's quite a coincidence.

"How very nice," Mrs. Malseed said, smiling to welcome us again this year. She seems to know when guests are about to arrive because she's usually waiting in the large hall that smells of flowers. "Arthur, take the luggage up," she told the old porter. "Rose, Tulip, Lily, and Geranium." These are the names of the rooms for us. Mrs. Malseed painted flowers on the doors instead of using numbers. In winter, when not many people come to Glencorn Lodge, she takes care of details like that, and her husband does repairs. "Well, well, well," Mr. Malseed said, coming into the hall from the kitchen. "A hundred thousand welcomes," he greeted us in the Irish way. He smiled with his dark brown eyes twinkling, making us feel special. Everyone smiled, and I felt that our holiday had truly begun. Nothing had changed at Glencorn; everything was good. Kitty from the dining room came out to greet us. "You look younger every year, all four of you," she said, making everyone laugh again. Arthur took our luggage to the rooms, carrying as much as he could and coming back for the rest. After dinner, we played cards for a while but not too long because we were tired from the journey. In the lounge, there was a man alone and a French couple. There were other people at dinner because in June, Glencorn Lodge is always full. From where we sat by the window, we could see some people walking on the lawns and others taking the path to the seashore. In the morning, we would do the same: walk along the sands to Ardbeag and have coffee at the hotel there, then come back in time for lunch. In the afternoon, we would drive somewhere. I knew this because over the years, we had developed this routine. Since we first came here, we all fell in love with the beautiful landscape.

Title: Keeping Holiday Guests Happy

Sarah Sutherland-Pilch is a chalet girl in Val d'Isere, France. She is 24 years old and from West Sussex. This is her second year working as a chalet girl. Sarah cooks and cleans for people who come to ski and stay in chalets, which are wooden houses. She studied French and History of Art at Oxford Brookes University. Sarah says being a chalet girl is not a career, but it is fun for a year or two before starting a serious job. She meets many successful people every week.

Sarah does not live in the chalet. She wakes up at 7 a.m. and walks to the chalet, which can have up to 18 guests each week. She eats her breakfast first, then makes breakfast for the guests. They have porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants. After breakfast, Sarah cleans up and prepares afternoon tea or cleans the rooms. She says cleaning is the hardest part of her job. By 11 a.m., she is ready to ski. She skis as much as she can, sometimes until 4:30 p.m.

Sarah goes back to the chalet to prepare dinner. She takes a shower but does not sleep because it makes her too tired. Dinner is at 8 p.m., and coffee is served by 10 p.m. After dinner, she cleans up and loads the dishwasher. Sometimes she talks with the guests, and other times they want to be alone. Good guests make the week fun, but some weeks are not as good.

Sarah meets her friends at her chalet and they go out around 11 p.m. They visit places like Bananas, G Jay's, and Dick's T-Bar. She does not stay out late on Saturday because Sunday is her busiest day. On Sunday, she starts work early. Breakfast for leaving guests is ready by 7 a.m. After they leave, she cleans everything quickly. If she did not shop on Saturday, she does it now. At 3 p.m., she prepares tea for new guests who arrive around 4:30 p.m. Sometimes they are confused and have many questions. Between tea and dinner, Sarah helps guests with ski equipment. Then she gets a ride back to the chalet. After dinner, she might have a drink or go to bed early if she is very tired.

Miss Rita Cohen was a small, pale girl who looked much younger than Seymour's daughter, Marie. But she said she was six years older. One day, she came to Seymour's factory. She wore overalls and big shoes, and her pretty face was surrounded by curly hair. She was so small and young that Seymour found it hard to believe she was studying at the University of Pennsylvania. She was doing research on the leather industry in New Jersey for her Master's degree.

A few times a year, someone would call or write to Seymour to ask if they could see his factory. Sometimes, he would help a student by answering questions on the phone or giving a short tour if they seemed serious. Rita Cohen was almost as small as the children from Marie's third-year class. Years ago, these children came from their school 50 kilometers away to see how Marie's dad made gloves. They especially liked the laying-off table, where the men shaped and pressed each glove over hot brass hands. These hands were very hot, shiny, and stood straight up from the table. Marie called them 'pancake hands' because they looked flat.

Rita asked, 'How many pieces come in a shipment?' Seymour replied, 'Between twenty and twenty-five thousand.' She kept taking notes and asked, 'Do they come directly to your shipping department?' Seymour liked that she was interested in every detail. He explained, 'They come to the tannery first. The tannery is a contractor. We buy the material, and they make it ready for us to work with. My grandfather and father worked in the tannery here in town. I did too, for six months, when I started in the business. Have you ever been inside a tannery?' Rita said, 'Not yet.' Seymour offered, 'You should visit a tannery if you're writing about leather. I can arrange that for you. They're old-fashioned places. Technology has improved things, but it's not very different from hundreds of years ago. It's hard work. Tanning is one of the oldest industries. They found 6,000-year-old tanning relics in Turkey. The first clothes were just skins tanned by smoking them. It's an interesting subject. My father knows a lot about leather; you should talk to him. He can talk about gloves for two days. Glovemen love their trade. Have you ever seen anything being made, Miss Cohen?' Rita replied, 'I can't say I have.' Seymour laughed when she said she saw her mother make a cake as a child. She made him laugh. She was eager to learn, like his daughter Marie, who was taller and fairer than Rita but had the same intelligence and curiosity.

Seymour said, 'I'll show you the whole process. We'll make you a pair of gloves, and you can watch from start to finish. What size do you wear?'

**Is it a dream job?**

Chris Arnot talks to four people with jobs that many people dream about. Are these jobs really as great as they seem?

**A. Raquel Graham**

Raquel Graham calls from a taxi on her way to the airport. She can't meet tomorrow because her boss wants her in Los Angeles. As a personal assistant to a pop star, she travels a lot. Raquel loves her job and gets along well with her boss. But she has one small problem - she doesn't like flying. "On a nine-hour flight to California, I usually take sleeping pills to calm down," she says. Her worst flight was on Concorde because it felt closed in with small windows. When not traveling, she works in offices in Manchester and London. She does paperwork, organizes the diary, attends meetings, and makes travel plans. She got the job by chance after meeting a pop group manager. She took secretarial classes at night and five years later, she became a PA.

**B. David Brown**

David Brown has been both an accountant and a golf caddy, which is someone who carries a golfer's bags. He liked being a caddy more because he loves golf. But there are downsides. Caddies get a small fee and a part of the winnings. They earn between £25,000 and £35,000, but much of it goes to travel and hotels. He started caddying for golfer Greg Norman at age 31. "You're not just carrying bags. You give advice and try to understand the golf course," he says. His accountancy skills were noticed, and now he works as a statistical data administrator. He collects and analyzes golf statistics for TV commentators, magazines, and golfers.

**C. Martin Fern**

Martin Fern is the editor of the 'Food and Drink' section of a newspaper. One of his fun tasks is trying food at top restaurants. What does he think about expensive restaurants? "If people can afford it, it's their choice," he says. "I'd rather spend £120 on a memorable meal than buy a microwave." His cooking talent got him a food column from a friend who edited a Saturday Review. At the time, Martin was a creative director at an ad agency, and the column was extra income. At 42, another newspaper offered him a full-time job. "It meant earning 50% less," he says. "But it was a chance to turn my passion into a job." He still cooks at home and stays fit by cycling to the nearest tube station.

**D. Dick Prince**

"I started writing children's stories about 20 years ago," says Dick Prince, a popular children's writer in Britain. "Before that, I loved words and wrote poems. Then I had an idea for a story. I was a farmer and knew about chickens being killed by a fox. So I wrote a story called The Fox Busters, my first published children's story." Where do his ideas come from? "It's not easy. I work on them," he says. "I usually do this in the mornings. I'm not an early riser. After lunch, I type out my morning notes with one finger on an old typewriter, not a laptop. I get 50 to 100 letters a week, and I enjoy this part of being a writer. I try to answer them all, but now I have some help."

In the lumberyard by the lake, workers cut trees into boards for building. There was an old two-story brick building there, surrounded by big piles of soft sawdust. These piles looked like golden mountains and went all the way to the blue lake. One afternoon, Michael and his friends were bored, so they climbed a ladder to the roof of the old building. They sat with their legs hanging over the edge, looking at the lake. Suddenly, Michael said, "I dare you to jump down," and he jumped off the roof onto the sawdust, laughing. "I dare you all!" he shouted. "You're all scared," he said, trying to get them to jump too. They looked down, scared, but then one by one, they jumped and felt happy. They lay on the sawdust, telling jokes in the hot sun. Then one friend said, "Let's go up and jump again." They weren't very excited, but they all went up and jumped again, except for Michael. The others were below, calling, "Come on, Mike. What's wrong?" Michael wanted to jump but stayed on the roof, feeling nervous. He tried to count to ten and jump, but he couldn't. His friends laughed and got tired of waiting. They started to leave, shouting, "Who started this? What's wrong with you?" Michael stayed on the roof, looking at the ground. He was alone for almost an hour as the sun set. His clothes were wet from sweat. Finally, he closed his eyes, slipped off the roof, and fell on the sawdust. He lay there for a long time. The workers had gone home, and it was quiet. He wondered why he couldn't jump before. Then he got up and walked home, feeling ashamed. He was late for dinner, and his stepmother said, "You're old enough to come home on time. If you can't, stay in tonight." She was a strong woman with fair skin, a little grey in her hair, and a patient smile. She spoke seriously, but Michael, feeling sad, didn't really hear her. He kept thinking about his friends laughing at him.

**Careers Advice**

Are you unhappy with your job and don't know how to change it? Kitty Doherty has some good advice. Many people who want to change jobs go to a careers adviser. You will write a short history about yourself and take some tests called 'psychometrics'. After the tests, you get a report with career suggestions and any retraining you might need.

I tried Career Analysts, a big company that gives career advice. The test felt like a science exam. I was with about ten people, answering questions quickly. It wasn't about passing or failing.
