The tests included finding mistakes in lists and matching shapes. After the test, I talked with an adviser. He gave me a report with his thoughts and advice. I agreed with most of it, but I was surprised I did poorly in science and technical tests. I was happy to hear I made the right choice with journalism.

Changing your career doesn't always mean a big change. Last March, Donna Laney, 25, lost her job as a marketing manager. Her friends told her to try Career Analysts. She wanted to look at her skills and interests again. She found out she was good at design but had to think about the cost of retraining. Other ideas included working in the Far East for a year. She decided to use her skills in a new job as a Public Relations officer. Career Analysts helped her see what she wanted to do. She recommended them to her friends.

Some people feel they couldn't have changed without help. Juliet Greene, 26, went to Career Counselling Services. She worked at a bank for six years and wanted a new challenge. The tests showed she liked sciences. After four meetings with an adviser, she decided to study geology. She plans to start a degree in it. She thinks the advice was worth the money and feels happier now.

However, careers advice doesn't work for everyone. Amanda Margetts, 24, a sales representative, didn't find it helpful. She wanted new ideas but didn't like the suggestions because they meant less money or more training. She felt she didn't learn anything new about herself. She thought a friend could have given similar advice.

Title: Fun at the Dentist's?

If you visit W. Lloyd Jerome's dental office in Glasgow, you will see bright paintings on the walls and a stylish blue couch. Patients sit on this couch while he checks their teeth. Jerome says, "Half of the people only go to the dentist when they have pain. They are scared of the dentist." To help with this, he tries to make his office a place where people are not afraid. He does not wear a white coat because it reminds people of pain. Jerome believes that going to the dentist should be relaxing and even fun.

Many people think of dental visits as painful or very serious. Jerome wants to change this. He uses virtual-reality headsets to help patients relax. His office was the first in Britain to use them. During the first check-up, patients sit on the blue couch and watch a film about underwater animals while he looks at their teeth. Then, the headset shows a camera view inside their mouth. Most patients like this part of their visit.

The office also smells nice, like a perfume shop. Today, it smells like oranges. Jerome says, "I want people to know it's not like a regular dentist's office. Smell is important. The usual dentist smell can make people nervous." The pleasant smell helps people feel calm.

Jerome is known as a fashionable dentist, but he takes his work seriously. Relaxation is important, but good treatment is the most important. He uses a special tool that sprays warm water to clean teeth instead of scraping them. It feels a bit strange at first, but it is not painful if you are relaxed.

Five years ago, Jerome went to the United States to learn about new dental techniques. He learned that making things easier for patients also makes it easier for the dentist. He wants to make British dentistry less formal. When a patient arrives, Jerome offers tea and asks what video they want to watch. The patient seems to enjoy this special treatment. The office feels more like a beauty salon than a regular dentist's office.

**Chocolate: A Sweet History**

Chocolate comes from South America and is now a big business around the world. In the UK, people spend over £230 million on chocolate at Easter. Eight percent of all chocolate is bought during this time. Only at Christmas do people eat more chocolate.

Chocolate has been made in factories since the last century, but the cacao plant was first grown by the Aztec, Toltec, and Mayan people in Central America over 3,000 years ago. The cacao tree is a tropical plant found in Africa, South and Central America, the West Indies, and South-East Asia. Its fruit is the size of a melon and has 20-40 seeds. When dried, these seeds become cacao beans, which are used to make chocolate. In English-speaking countries, they are often called cocoa beans, a name that came from a spelling mistake in the 17th century.

The Aztecs used cocoa beans as money and to make a drink called xocoatl, which means 'bitter water' in their language. They flavored the drink with spices for special events. The Spanish liked it better with cinnamon and sugar, but it took another century for the recipe to spread in Europe. In the late 17th century, chocolate houses opened in Europe's capital cities where people drank chocolate.

Until the last century, chocolate drinks were made from solid blocks of chocolate melted in hot water. In 1826, CJ van Houten from the Netherlands invented chocolate powder by removing most of the cocoa butter from the beans. The chocolate bar we know today started in 1847 when Fry and Sons in Bristol mixed cocoa butter with chocolate liquor and sugar to make a solid block. Later, a Swiss company added milk to make milk chocolate.

At the start of the 20th century, French companies led the British chocolate market. In 1879, the English company Cadbury named their factory Bournville, hoping to add some French style. But Cadbury's Dairy Milk bar, first called Dairymaid in 1905, became popular with ads linking it to healthy English milk. Now, people in Britain eat about four chocolate bars each week.

To attract more customers, chocolate makers are creating new products like chocolate ice cream, drinks, and desserts. Meanwhile, cacao farmers are still affected by a drop in cocoa bean prices in the late 1980s. Many small farmers went out of business. So, next time you eat a chocolate bar, think about the farmers who grow the cacao.

**THE SHELL ARTIST**

Peter Cooke is 83 years old and very good at his art. He wants to try new things like making paper and working with feathers. But right now, he is happy making beautiful things from shells. He has been doing this for ten years.

Peter shows me his work in his apartment. He is very excited about it, and his work is very beautiful. He shows me some shell ornaments above his fireplace. He says he doesn't mind if people don't buy them because he loves them. He never planned to sell his work, but friends told him to have an exhibition. So, he did, and many pieces were sold in London. His second exhibition just opened, and his work is expensive. Some pieces cost around £2,000.

Peter says he doesn't set the prices. He believes no one else makes art like his. The gallery owner told him that people will want his work because he won't make it forever. Peter wishes he started this art earlier in life because he could have made even more amazing things. Now, he feels a bit limited because of his age.

His work is very different from the shell items you find in seaside shops. He makes boxes with tiny shells, pictures, and flowers that look real. He uses simple materials like cardboard, glue, and washing-up liquid for his work. He says he has an idea, and the work just happens, but it looks very detailed and planned.

Peter looks for beautiful shells in many places like France, Thailand, Mexico, South Africa, and the Philippines. He only collects dead shells and does not harm living creatures. He says people walking on the beach break more shells than he collects. He believes his art makes the shells even more beautiful.

**The Schoolgirl Model**

Kira Langer is 15 years old. When she is not traveling to beautiful places and being on magazine covers, she is studying for her school exams. Jane Laidlaw learns more about her.

The receptionist at the agency told me, "Kira will be a little late." I said, "Oh, fine, no problem." I was worried because I had read bad things about models. People say they are difficult, vain, and not smart. I thought Kira might be late because she was at the hairdresser's or didn't want to talk to me. If she was late, she might be in a bad mood and not answer my questions.

But when Kira, the winner of the Looks magazine supermodel competition, arrived, she was smiling, relaxed, and said sorry for being late. She came with her mother. Kira was wearing a simple black dress and trainers, not expensive designer clothes. She was very friendly, tall, and pretty. 

All models under 16 must have an adult with them when they work. Kira's mother looked like a normal mum and was proud of her daughter. Kira seemed surprised by her fame because it was not planned. Her older sister wanted her to join the model competition. Kira said no, but her sister sent photos anyway. When Kira found out she was a finalist, she was at school. Being selected gave her confidence, and she did well in the final. She won easily, and the Select model agency in London offered her work.

Kira now has to manage her two lives: school and modeling. Her friends and teachers are proud of her, but some people at school are not nice. They say she thinks too much of herself. This is hard for Kira because she is not self-important. She says, "I am more confident now, but not in a bad way. I can stand up for myself."

As a busy model, her social life is affected. The Select agency can call anytime for a job the next day. She can't always make plans with friends, but they understand. They don't complain that she is always busy with modeling.

Kira has the looks, talent, and support for a great career. Not many people can say that before finishing school. At the end of the interview, I ask Kira what she would like to do if she wasn't a model. She thinks and says, "I'd like to do what you're doing."

Father and Son Search for Gold

Terence and Chris Madden are a father and son team. They have traveled from cold Canada to hot Africa to find gold. Terence is an explorer, and Chris is a mineral expert. They think their mine on a Welsh mountain might have up to 10,000 ounces of gold. After ten years of digging, they believe they are very close to finding a lot of gold worth five million dollars. Terence, who is 68 and from Liverpool, said, "We are finding a lot of gold as we dig. We just need to dig a few more meters."

The Maddens have spent their lives looking for gold. They started after Terence read about gold in the "Dolgellau gold belt," near a Welsh town with the same name. They read old mining journals and newspapers at the Welsh National Library in Aberystwyth to find the best place to dig. They cleared the land, found some gold in the rocks, and spent ten years getting permission to dig. They also took samples of the earth and removed old cars and rubbish. They dug out 150 tonnes of rock to make a tunnel and a 10-meter shaft. Now, they need more money. They have used their savings and need someone to give them £50,000 to dig a bit more to find the gold. Chris Madden says, "Right now, it looks difficult, but we have some people we can ask."

Last week, people in the valleys heard about the dig, and many became interested in gold. Dolgellau depends on tourists, and the people there are hopeful. Peter Woolven, who manages the Royal Ship Hotel, said, "If they find gold, more people might visit, but I hope not too many come and dig up the hillside."

The Welsh gold industry was very big in the late 1880s, with many mines and workers. But now, it has declined. One of the last mines, Clogau-St David's, which made wedding rings for the Queen and the Princess of Wales, closed a month ago. However, some people are still looking for gold. George Hall, another gold seeker, plans to dig a tunnel on the other side of the hill from the Maddens. Hall, who is 70, said, "Searching for gold is very emotional. It's exciting to find hidden treasure. Maybe I'll be lucky this time."

**IN HOT WATER**

Rachel Mills is a scientist. She spends a lot of time at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. Rachel teaches and studies marine geochemistry. This means she looks at the chemical processes in the sea. She works at the Oceanography Centre at Southampton University.

When Rachel is not teaching, she goes into a small steel vehicle. This vehicle is for exploring underwater. It is the size of a small car. She dives three kilometers down into the Atlantic Ocean to study underwater volcanoes. Inside the vehicle, there is not much space. Rachel can touch the two pilots next to her. They cannot stand up or move much. They must stay inside until someone opens the door from outside. A dive can last 16 hours. It takes three hours to reach the ocean floor, ten hours to collect rock and water samples, and three hours to come back up.

If there is a problem, they can press a panic button. This releases a small escape vessel. It goes quickly to the surface, like a ping-pong ball in water. No one has tested it yet, and Rachel thinks it might not be a nice journey.

Rachel was nervous the first time she went into the vehicle. It was on a ship's deck. She got in with an instructor. He explained what to do in emergencies, like if the pilot had a heart attack. They wanted to see how she would react in a small space. Now, Rachel has made six dives. Last year, she dived with a Russian crew. They went to a place five days' sail west of the Canary Islands. There are many underwater volcanoes there. The Russian team was putting scientific equipment there to study a volcano.

When Rachel is not at sea, she is in her office at the Oceanography Centre. She spends two-thirds of her time teaching, which she loves. But she teaches so she can do her research on "black smokers." This is another name for underwater volcanoes. Water comes out of the rock and looks like black smoke. It comes out fast and is very hot, at 350 degrees.

Rachel was scared once when she first went down with the Americans. They were towing equipment when there was a big explosion. The shock waves hit their vehicle. Rachel thought she was going to die. But nothing happened, and they were safe. The relief was incredible.

Rachel loves the adventure of diving to the deepest part of the ocean. Every time she looks out and sees the chimneys, she feels wonder. She is at the bottom of the sea, seeing things no one else has seen. She studied the black smokers for three years for her PhD. Seeing them for real was an amazing feeling.

I was dirty, smelly, hungry, and a bit suntanned. It was the end of my Inter-Rail holiday. My body was tired, and my mind was tired of foreign timetables, money, and languages. "Never again," I said when I got home. But I said the same thing the next year. And the year after that. 

I just needed to buy one train ticket, and because I was under 25 years old, I could travel anywhere in Europe for a whole month. Sleeping in a train corridor is different from sleeping in a bed. The train's movement helps you sleep deeply. Carrying everything in a backpack makes you travel simply. Sometimes, you even throw away socks that smell bad or books you have finished reading. This is the Inter-Rail spirit, where you don't need to think too much. 

This train ticket lets young people travel to many countries quickly. On my first trip, my friends and I thought it was just a cheap way to get to our campsite in southern France. But we wanted to keep traveling because there was always another country to see. And it didn't cost us extra money. 

We were not completely uninterested in culture. But this was our first holiday without parents, like many other Inter-Railers. We made our own plans and only saw the easiest sights. We wanted to escape guided tours and do something different. I was proud that sometimes I only saw the view from the train station. We just wanted to have fun. 

We were like other Inter-Railers, sharing train floors, food, water, money, and music. The excitement of travel comes from seeing a place that was just a name before. When the train arrives, you see the city for the first time. 

Seeing Europe, watching the landscapes change, and noticing different lifestyles helps you understand the continent. Everyone knows what is there, but it means more when you see it yourself. This is why other people's holiday photos can be boring. The train trip may not show you new things in the world, but it is a special personal experience. Europe is big, and Inter-Rail helps you see this, even if it takes time to realize.

Text: 'It is very disappointing to arrive at an airport in another country and find out that your baggage is not there. If this happens, you might have to wear the same clothes for hours or days until the airline finds your luggage. Sometimes, you might be in a place with a different climate and have to wear clothes that are not right for the weather. Airlines do not often say how many bags they lose, but it is common for people who travel a lot to lose their luggage sometimes. Even the best airlines make mistakes, and they cannot always promise that your checked luggage will be on the same flight as you, especially if you have to change planes. 

Airlines ask passengers to check in early to make sure there is enough time for baggage to go through the airport and onto the plane. The shortest time to change between flights is called Minimum Connecting Time (MCT), and it is also longer to help with baggage transfers. Usually, this system works well. But extra security checks and air traffic problems can delay flights and cause baggage issues. Sometimes, human mistakes or accidents, like a torn destination label, can also cause problems. These issues are worse at big airports, called 'hubs', because they handle many bags. For example, last year, London's Heathrow airport had over 41 million passengers, and nine million of them changed planes. British Airways had two million transfer passengers at Heathrow, with many moving between Terminal 1 and Terminal 4. Even good airports like Amsterdam, Copenhagen, Singapore, and Zurich have bad days. The chance of losing baggage is higher at some airports. In the United States, Miami airport is known for losing luggage when passengers connect to flights to Latin America.

To avoid losing your baggage, choose direct flights if you can and check in early. If you must change planes or if it makes your flight cheaper, try to fly with the same airline. Allow more time for connecting flights by taking an earlier flight to the transfer airport. Label your luggage inside and outside with your home and holiday addresses, and include your flight numbers. If your luggage still goes missing, talk to the airline staff in the baggage area and fill out a property irregularity report (PIR) before you leave the airport.'

Charlie James is a wildlife photographer who loves kingfishers. Kingfishers are beautiful blue-green birds that live near streams and rivers. They eat fish. The area where they live has old trees, soft green colors, and the sound of water. The kingfisher flies very fast and is bright like a light. Charlie loved kingfishers since he was young. He cannot say exactly why he loves them so much. 

There are many stories about kingfishers. In Greek myth, a kingfisher was a moon goddess who became a bird. Another story says the kingfisher flew so high that its top became blue like the sky, and its bottom was burned by the sun. This story has some truth. Kingfishers do not have blue color in their feathers. Instead, their feathers reflect light, making them look blue or green depending on the light.

Kingfishers are shy, but you can watch them from a hidden place. Charlie's first hiding place was an old blanket. He waited near a kingfisher's favorite spot, and the bird came very close. It took him four years to take a good picture of a kingfisher. He spent a lot of time by a stream with many kingfishers, but he missed school and did not do well in his studies. 

At 16, Charlie got a job as an advisor for a nature magazine. Later, he worked as a wildlife film cameraman. Now, he wants to make a film about kingfishers with no talking, just beautiful pictures. He loves the simple beauty of kingfishers and their colors. Charlie's photos show his feelings for the kingfisher, but he knows there is more to his love for the bird than he can show in his work.

**Conducting an Orchestra**

Giving directions to an orchestra is not easy. Anne Inglis talks to five new conductors about their work.

**A. Anne Manson**

Anne Manson is 30 years old. She asked to watch conductor Claudio Abbado's practice in Vienna. She ended up helping because an assistant was missing. Later, she helped with another opera. Anne was not nervous when she first led an orchestra. She works with a London opera company that focuses on modern music. She is also becoming known in other European countries. The British Arts Council helped her with money to travel. She has worked with Abbado on many projects since then.

**B. Andrew Constantine**

Andrew Constantine, 31, says the hardest part of being a conductor is getting the right opportunities. He won a big competition in 1991 after failing in two others. He thinks the timing was good because if he had won earlier, he might not have succeeded. The competition gave him many chances to perform and work with a famous conductor. But he worries about being known only for the competition. He hopes orchestras will invite him back, like the English Chamber Orchestra did. If not, his career might not last.

**C. Wasfi Kani**

Wasfi Kani started Pimlico Opera. She enjoys the long practice time needed for opera. She began conducting seriously in her late twenties. After university, she worked in London until Pimlico Opera became professional. Learning from Sian Edwards was important for her. She realized she could conduct even though she is small. She likes the complexity of opera and dealing with singers' personalities.

**D. Roger Vignoles**

Roger Vignoles, 48, was surprised to become a conductor, but he finds it interesting. He started as a musician in an opera house and worked with good conductors. Last year, he directed Handel's Agrippina from the piano at a festival. It was easier than he thought because he knew the music well. He tries to get the performance he wants and people respect his musical skills. He learns from every experience and is open to trying new things.

**E. Wayne Marshall**

In 1986, conductor Simon Rattle noticed Wayne Marshall, now 32, and told his agent about him. Marshall soon conducted a musical in London on short notice. It was a tough start, and he had to be firm with musicians who were not paying attention. He always gives a clear beat and is not afraid to say what he wants. He has not formally studied conducting, but people have been supportive. He is determined and knows what he likes.

**Theme Parks in Britain**

If you want to take children to a theme park in Britain, there are many to choose from. We asked five families to visit some of the best ones.

**Fun Island - The Burns Family**

Last year, we visited a big theme park in the US, so we thought Fun Island might not be as exciting. But we were surprised! The park is great for young children, so our three-year-old had fun too. The kids loved the Crocodile Ride and the Giant Wheel. There is a special dodgems ride for very young kids, which was a big hit. For older kids, there are scarier rides like Splash Out, where you jump into a pool! After five hours, Steve and I were tired, but the kids wanted to stay longer because they were having so much fun. The park could have better scenery, but the staff are very helpful, and it is clean and safe.

**Wonderland - The McMillan Family**

We had never been to a theme park before, so we didn't know what to expect. We thought Oscar might be too young, but he loved it. He enjoyed the Mountain Train and Little Land, which has small models of famous buildings. The older kids liked the ferris wheel and driving toy cars on a road. We stayed for six hours and liked that there were places to rest. The park is beautiful, and the staff are friendly. There is something for everyone, even adults.

**Adventure World - The Jeffree Family**

After seven hours, we still had more to see. The kids loved the Big Top Circus with its exciting trapeze act. We went on the Terror Line, and even though the girls were scared, they enjoyed it. Their favorite ride was Running River, where you think you'll get wet, but you don't. Toy Land is fun for younger kids. The new ride, Fear Factor, was too big for our kids, which was a relief! The park is well designed, so waiting in line isn't too boring. It's very clean, and the staff are great. A staff member even helped us on a ride.

**The Great Park - The Langridge Family**

We arrived at 1 p.m. and were sad that the park closed at 5 p.m. This park is great for younger kids because the rides aren't too scary. I am usually scared, but I had fun too. We all loved Exotic Travels, a boat ride that starts slow and then gets exciting. We waited 30 minutes for Lightning River, and it was over quickly! I didn't go on the Big Leap, but it looked fun for brave people. If our kids were older, they might have found it a bit boring, but they loved it.

**Fantasy World - The Break-all Family**

The park says there is 'No Limit to the Fun,' and we agree. Europe's tallest roller-coaster, the Rocket, is very scary, and Ben thought it was the scariest ride. Jennie thought the Hanger, where you hang upside-down 30 meters above the ground, was even scarier! There are about twelve main rides, and the older kids went on them many times. Sarah was too small for some rides but liked the Long Slide. The staff were sometimes nice, but not always. You need a full day to enjoy Fantasy World. We couldn't tell the kids we were leaving early!

**Running a Business in the Countryside: Five Women's Stories**

**A. Christine Hogan**  
Christine Hogan runs a computer design business. She makes over £200,000 a year and has four full-time workers. Christine and her husband moved from London to the countryside when their children were young. She wanted a job she could do from home. Christine had worked with computers before, so her husband suggested starting a computer design business. It was hard at first and needed a lot of money. Christine was careful with spending and talked to the bank if she needed more money. Working from home saves money, and she can work in the evenings. Her business is small, and local people usually come to pick up their work.

**B. Maggy Sasanow**  
Maggy Sasanow designs greeting cards from home. She studied art at university and wanted to work in a museum, but there were no such jobs in the countryside. So, she started her own business and makes 50 different greeting cards, which she sells to museums. Maggy works in a big room at home. The downside is that there are always chores to do, like mowing the lawn. She doesn't advertise; people hear about her through others. Maggy is cheaper than other artists, so people send her work from London. She misses sharing ideas with others but likes being independent.

**C. Delia Turner**  
Delia Turner makes curtains. Her business has had good and bad times. She started eight years ago, and her business grew quickly at first. She managed six full-time workers, but had to let them go when the economy got worse. Now, Delia makes curtains at home with her husband's help and other women who work from their homes. She has to be ready to lower her prices and find new opportunities.

**D. Tessa Strickland**  
Tessa Strickland runs a children's book publishing business from her farmhouse. She moved to the countryside three years ago because London was too expensive and she loves the country. Tessa likes working when she wants, but she has to take calls at odd hours because most of her business is with Australia, the Far East, and North America. It is hard to stop working sometimes. She publishes children's books from different cultures and works with authors and artists. At first, she felt lonely because all her work experience was in London.

**E. Meg Rivers**  
Meg Rivers runs a cakes-by-post business and a shop. She makes £250,000 a year and has six workers, some part-time. She started ten years ago at home, making healthy fruit cakes with good flour and eggs. Friends and family liked them, and soon she was sending cakes all over the country. Seven years ago, she rented a small building where everything is made. She has a baker, an assistant, and a professional cake decorator. Meg doesn't bake now; she manages the business side. Her biggest challenge has been the financial part because she didn't have a lot of money to start with.

**Meet the Amazing Watkins Family**

The Watkins family is special because they all love music. The sons, Paul and Huw, are musicians and composers, and their dad, John, makes musical instruments.

When Paul was ten years old, he needed a cello. But cellos were very expensive. So, John decided to learn how to make one. He went to evening classes at the Welsh School of Instrument Making for about three years. After making some violins and violas, he made his first cello for Paul. It was very good, and Paul used it for many years.

John stopped teaching and now makes violins full-time. He even sold one to a famous American musician, Jaime Laredo.

Paul and Huw started playing music when they were young. Paul first played the piano, but then he wanted to play the cello. He thought the cello player in his dad's music group was very cool. So, he started learning the cello and became very good at it. Huw also plays music but chose the piano and became a composer.

Paul won a big music competition with his dad's cello. He became the main cellist for the BBC Symphony Orchestra when he was just 20 years old. Now, he plays a very old and special cello from the Royal Academy of Music.

Paul will play this cello on TV in a show called Masterworks. But he can't watch it because he will be playing at a music festival that night. Huw will also be busy because his music will be played in London for the first time.

John and Hetty, their parents, are very proud and try to keep up with all their sons' music events.

**Looking After the Countryside: The National Trust**

The National Trust is a group that helps protect the countryside in Britain. Gill Page visits the Lleyn Peninsula in North Wales and talks to Gareth Roberts, a warden who works for the Trust. 

Gareth says a warden needs common sense and must be good with people. He talks to farmers, visitors, and builders all the time. Gareth grew up on the Lleyn Peninsula and worked on his family's farm before he got married. Many people wanted the warden job, but Gareth got it because he knows the area well and has farming experience, even though he didn't have special training.

Gareth still helps on his parents' farm, which helps him understand farmers' problems. He is also strong enough to do hard work like building fences, planting trees, and making walls. Since working with the Trust, Gareth has learned more about taking care of nature. He remembers collecting flowers and bird nests as a child and now sees how farming has changed the countryside. He believes it's not the farmers' fault because they followed government advice.

When Gareth started, farmers and conservationists (people who protect nature) did not agree. Now, they talk and understand each other better. Gareth thinks they are close to working together well.

Gareth's job includes conservation, letting people visit Trust land, planting trees, and meeting farmers who rent land from the Trust. He makes sure work is done well and cheaply. He likes finishing projects, but he also spends a lot of time on paperwork.

Gareth loves his job, even though he is always working. He enjoys talking to most visitors, but some people can be rude. They act like they own the place, which annoys him. 

If you have common sense and like working outside, you might want to be a warden like Gareth. But don't expect a job on the Lleyn Peninsula soon!

**The Netball Captain**

In our series about women in sports, Suzie Ellis met with England's netball captain. Kendra Slowinski is the captain of England's netball team. When I met her, she was having a busy day. She taught at a local school and then trained in a supermarket car park. I asked her, "Don't people look at you strangely?" She said, "I am too focused on my movements and my feet to notice. I might see cars slow down, but that's all."

Kendra says, "My whole life is about being my best for the Championships." She follows a strict plan to be very fit. This is her fourth World Championships, and it will be the biggest ever, with 27 countries. "We will have support from people at home, which is special," she says. "It's important to make netball more popular in our country. Because we are playing here, there will be more pressure. People will expect us to start with a good game."

Their first game is against Barbados, right after the opening ceremony. "As far as I know, we have always beaten them, but they are exciting to play. They have a lot of skill." The England team is ranked fourth in the world. But Kendra says the World Championships will be hard. "You have to play every day, with no rest between games. In a series, you can lose the first game and still win. But in the Championships, you only have one chance."

In the 15 years she has played at the top level, the sport has become harder and faster. Players are more aggressive on the court. "You train hard to win," says Kendra. "But after the game, we are all friendlier."

Netball now uses more science for fitness testing. "We must think and train like world-class players," says Kendra. "As captain, I need a strong mind and must lead by example. I support and encourage my team."

Kendra says, "From the start, my netball career was carefully planned. I decided this competition would be my last as a player." She might coach young players in the future, but now she is focused on her last big event. As she leads her team in the opening ceremony, she might have a tear in her eye.

**Specialist Music Schools**

What should you do if your child is very good at music? It can be hard to know how to help them. Some parents might not notice their child's talent until the child becomes upset or difficult. Most schools can help children who are good at subjects like math or science, but musically talented children need special help. Regular schools might not have this help, especially if music is not important there. 

Children who are very good at music might benefit from going to a specialist music school. In Britain, there are five such schools. These schools help children aged seven to eighteen to improve their music skills with the help of professional musicians. At these schools, children spend a lot of time on music. They have individual lessons, play in orchestras, learn singing, conducting, and music theory. They also practice a lot in special rooms. The rest of their time is for regular school subjects like English, math, science, and languages. 

These music schools are private, and classes are small. Most children live at the school, which means they spend a lot of time with other children who also love music. 

There are some problems with these schools. First, they are expensive, costing between £12,000 and £17,000 a year. But schools try to help with scholarships and financial aid. Second, not all parents want their children to live away from home, especially when they are very young. Some school directors think it might not be good for very young children to be in such a strict environment. They want to make sure children grow up to be well-rounded people.

Being in a music school can be stressful. Some children might lose interest in music as they grow older. The pressure to be the best can make them feel like they have failed. But schools watch the children closely and help them if needed. 

Many students from music schools say they learned a lot about music, but they also wish they had more regular school subjects. Some musically talented children are also very smart and want more academic challenges. 

For these reasons, it might be better to wait until the child is older and can decide for themselves if they want to go to a music school. Children who are good at both music and school subjects might do well in a regular school with a good music program. They can also take music lessons on weekends at music colleges, but this is only possible if they live near a big city like London.

Susan Shepherd is an artist who paints flowers. She is famous for her flower paintings. Her house has a big garden with many flowers. She likes tulips and poppies the most. Some plants grow everywhere in the garden by themselves. The garden looks nice because of the colors and shapes of the flowers. The people who lived there before Susan loved gardening and left many plants for her. They also left a gardener named Danny. Susan says, "It was really his garden." They worked well together. At first, Danny did not like some of Susan's ideas, but when she explained she wanted to paint them, he understood.

Susan likes to paint one flower at a time. Sometimes she paints a group of flowers, but usually, she picks them and takes them to her studio. She paints one flower, which can take a few days, and then adds another. Sometimes, it takes her a couple of years to finish a painting. She is very busy in spring and early summer when tulips and poppies bloom. She likes to watch how flowers change over time. For example, tulips change shape when you put them in water.

Susan has always liked plants. She studied botany in school and collected wildflowers. She did not like garden flowers before because they looked fake to her. She was amazed by how wildflowers grew in difficult places like rocks or cliffs. Now, her garden has plants from different countries, but they grow well there. She lets the garden grow naturally, like a kind aunt who lets children play freely. Susan is busy with two art shows and does not have much time for gardening. She hired another gardener to help, but she knows she needs to work in the garden to stay connected to her art.

Title: Keeping Holiday Guests Happy

Sarah Sutherland-Pilch is a 24-year-old from West Sussex. She works as a chalet girl in Val d'Isère, France. This is her second year doing this job. Sarah cooks and cleans for people who come to ski and stay in chalets, which are wooden houses. She graduated in French and History of Art from Oxford Brookes University last summer. Sarah says being a chalet girl is not a career, but it's a fun way to spend a year or two before starting a serious job. She meets many successful people every week.

Sarah does not live in the chalet. She wakes up at 7 a.m. and walks about a mile to the chalet, which can have up to 18 guests each week. She eats her breakfast first, then prepares breakfast for the guests. They have porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants. After breakfast, around 9:30 a.m., Sarah cleans up and either makes afternoon tea or cleans the rooms. She says cleaning is the worst part of the job. By 11 a.m., she is ready to go skiing. She skis as much as she can. On a good day, she can ski until 4:30 p.m.

Sarah returns to the chalet to prepare dinner. She takes a shower but does not sleep because it makes her too tired. Dinner is a three-course meal served at 8 p.m., and coffee is ready by 10 p.m. After dinner, Sarah cleans up and fills the dishwasher. She sometimes talks with the guests, but other times they prefer to be alone. Good guests make the week fun, but some weeks are not as good.

Sarah meets her friends at the chalet where she lives, and they go out around 11 p.m. They visit places like Bananas, G Jay's, and Dick's T-Bar. Sarah does not stay out too late on Saturday night because Sunday is her busiest day. She starts work earlier on Sunday because breakfast must be ready by 7 a.m. After the guests leave, Sarah cleans the chalet quickly. She clears breakfast, changes the beds, and gets everything ready. If she hasn't shopped on Saturday, she does it now. Around 3 p.m., she prepares tea for the new guests, who arrive around 4:30 p.m. Sometimes they are confused and have many questions. Between tea and dinner, Sarah helps guests with ski equipment and gets a ride back to the chalet. Then it's time for dinner again. Sometimes she chats with friends, but if she's very tired, she goes to bed early.

**Changing Lives with a Stranger**

Mandie Currie is a zoo-keeper. She spent a day at the magazine Marie Claire. She found it hard to choose clothes because she usually wears a uniform. First, she went to a photo studio, then to see new clothes, all before lunch. The zoo is calm and quiet, but at the magazine, she was very busy. Some people in the fashion team were stressed, but her job is not stressful. In the afternoon, she went to a fashion photo shoot. She thought it was funny because she usually cleans cages or handles rats. She likes seeing how magazines work, but she loves her job at the zoo and wants to stay there.

Alice Cutler is a fashion assistant at Marie Claire. She spent a day at London Zoo. She wore leather boots and dark blue trousers, but the zoo gave her a green shirt to wear because she got very dirty. She touched an elephant and thought Mandie was probably packing clothes. By five o'clock, she smelled bad but had a great day. She thinks she might work with elephants in Africa when she stops working in fashion.

Karen Hodson is a nurse at Hammersmith Hospital. She spent a day with the TV gardening show Ground Force. She was very excited to meet the team. Alan Titchmarsh, the presenter, was very nice. She liked being outside because sometimes she doesn't see daylight due to her work shifts. It was hard work but fun. She thought she was strong but felt weak compared to the team. Gardening was harder than she thought, so she will not leave her nursing job.

Charlie Dimmock is a landscape gardener with Ground Force. She worked a shift at Hammersmith Hospital. She made beds and gave out medicine. She thought she might faint but was surprised she didn't. The nurses were very friendly, and it felt different from her usual work with men. She feels her job is not as important as nursing. Her day at the hospital was not easy, but it was satisfying.

Lucy Harvey is a personal trainer. She spent a day with Ryanair as cabin crew. She wore a uniform and felt different because people respected her. Before the flight, she learned about safety and what to do if someone had a heart attack. On the flight to Paris, she gave out magazines. People looked at her, and she felt shy. On the way back, there were 80 schoolchildren who wouldn't sit still. She wished she was back in the gym with one adult.

Sonia McDermott is an air hostess with Ryanair. She spent a day as a personal trainer in a gym. She was worried because she doesn't exercise. She was surprised by how much attention trainers give to one person. In her job, she meets many passengers every day. At lunch, she saw that trainers don't always eat very healthily, but they drink a lot of water. She doesn't want to change her job, but she wants to join a gym and be healthier.

**On the Rails: Five Celebrities Share Their Favorite Train Memories**

**Andrea Thompson - Newsreader**  
I love the south of France and visit often. There is a train from Cannes that goes along the coast and into Italy. The views of the sea are amazing, no matter the weather or season. You can also see beautiful gardens and homes. The people on the train are interesting, with both tourists and locals enjoying the journey.

**Raj Patel - Explorer**  
I have taken many train trips, but my favorite is the Nile Valley Express in Sudan. When I was young in South Africa, I missed a family train trip to the Kruger National Park because I was too young. My first real train station was London Waterloo, and it amazed me.

**Betty Cooper - Novelist**  
The Blue Train is special to me because it took my husband and me on our honeymoon across France to Egypt. On the train, my husband gave me a pink dress, which I loved. I heard pink is good for the brain, so I wear it often. The journey through France and up the Nile was a perfect way to relax after our wedding.

**Martin Brown - Journalist**  
For a work trip, we had to cross a desert in Africa. We took the Desert Express because there was no road. The train schedule was not fixed, and the driver would wait for people. Many people climbed onto the train, even on the roof. At night, the train passed through beautiful landscapes, like a dream.

**Arisu Mezuki - Actress**  
I didn't see many trains as a child in Singapore and Cyprus. As a teenager, I made a film in Yorkshire with a railway. The old train line was kept by volunteers, and I fell in love with steam trains. We rode the train whenever we could. When I visited last year, everything was the same, even the gas lights at the station!

Text: 'Do you want to get your story published? Our expert, Margaret Stubbs, can help you. Many people ask, 'I have written a story or book. Who should I send it to?' First, you need to learn about publishers and practice your writing. Selling your writing needs knowledge about the 'writing world'. No matter what you write, you need to know about the markets you want to reach. The best way to learn is by reading a lot. Visit your local library, bookshops, and newsagents. Reading will show you what publishers want. Remember, things change often—new magazines come out, editors change jobs, and magazines change direction. Publishers always want new writers, so we must give them what they want. If you want to write short love stories, first find out which magazines publish them. Get recent copies and see what kind of stories they buy. Pay attention to who the readers are because the editor wants to please them. Writers often ask me, 'My story was rejected three times. Am I wasting my time?' As a former teacher, I never discourage anyone. But the work might not be ready to publish. Most new writers send their work too soon. If you have only written one story, it is not likely to be published. Success usually comes after years in publishing or journalism. When you send your work, keep writing more stories. Write ten or even twenty more. Each story will be better, and you will feel more like a writer. Don't throw any stories away—improve them. I suggest not showing your work to others at first. Remember, every successful writer has faced many rejections. Do everything you can to become a better writer. Look for a creative writing course near you or join a local writers' group. This will help you get ideas and confidence. Think of yourself as a writer and practice writing every day if you can.'

On the last day of a bad year, I was at the Baltimore train station. I was waiting for the 10.10 train to Philadelphia. There were more people than I thought there would be. The station didn't feel as nice and clean as usual. Older couples with matching bags sat on the benches, and many college students sat on the floor with their bags. 

A man with grey hair was talking to different people. He looked rich: he had tanned skin, a nice sweater, and a soft, beige coat. He asked a woman sitting alone a question. Then he talked to a girl near me. She had long blond hair, and I thought I might like to talk to her too. The man asked, "Are you going to Philadelphia?" She said, "I'm going north, yes." "But to Philadelphia?" he asked. "No, New York," she replied. "Thanks, anyway," he said and moved on.

I was curious now. I heard him ask an old lady, "Are you going to Philadelphia?" She said, "Wilmington," and he moved on to another couple. I stood up and moved closer, pretending to look at the train platform. I was going to Philadelphia, but he didn't ask me. Maybe he thought I looked unreliable. He just glanced at me and walked away. He looked worried now. "Please!" he said to a woman reading a book. "Tell me you're going to Philadelphia!" She was about thirty-five, older than me. "Philadelphia?" she said. "Yes, I am."

"Could I ask you a favor?" he asked. I pretended to look at my wrist as if I had a watch. The woman seemed cautious. The man said, "Nothing too difficult, I promise!" They announced my train, and people started moving to Gate E. The man continued, "My daughter is flying out this afternoon for a study year abroad, leaving from Philadelphia. She forgot her passport. She called home from the station in Philadelphia and didn't know what to do."

The woman felt sorry for him. I would have waited to see what he wanted. "I told her to stay there, and I would find someone to bring her passport," he said. I thought, why didn't he go himself if it was so important? The woman asked, "Why don't you go yourself?" He said, "I can't leave my wife alone. She's in a wheelchair." This seemed like a weak excuse to me. 

I looked at them. The man was holding a padded envelope, not a plain one. It was the size of a small book and looked stapled shut. I thought, be careful, lady.

**Gary and Me**

John Moore, a restaurant owner, talks about his son Gary, who is a famous TV chef. John believes everyone gets a chance in life. Gary's chance was cooking, and John's chance was running a restaurant. When John found the restaurant, it was in bad shape, but he thought it was perfect for his plans. 

John remembers his childhood when his mother worked in a factory, and he was sad to be alone. He wanted to have time for family life. His wife took care of the children and helped with the business accounts, while John ran the restaurant. They lived above the restaurant and always had meals together. This was good for their children, Gary and Joe, who became very confident. From a young age, they talked to the restaurant's regular customers, which helped them in life.

Gary was an active child. Once, when he was seven, he jumped into a bath like it was a swimming pool and got hurt. As he grew older, he worked for pocket money. He did small jobs and by age ten, he worked in the kitchen every weekend. He was disciplined and woke up early. It was nice to see him helping in the family business. Gary was not very good at school, but he was great in the kitchen. By age 15, he was as good as the adults working there and sometimes was in charge. He could make over a hundred meals, and John knew Gary would work in catering because he was talented.

When Gary needed work experience for school, John sent him to a friend's restaurant. Gary also started playing the drums and has his own band now. John worries about what will happen to Gary's cooking if the music becomes successful. John advises Gary to focus on one thing to succeed. He told Gary to achieve his goals by age 30, or it might be too late.

Gary went to catering college at 17. On his first day, he finished his work quickly and helped others. John is very proud of Gary's success with his TV cooking show. John always told Gary that he must work hard for what he wants because nothing is given for free. Gary took his chance and worked hard. John is happy that Gary listened to his advice and learned from it.

Finding a good flat in Dublin that you can afford is very difficult, like finding gold. The best way is to know someone who knows someone leaving a place. But if you are new, like Jo, you don't have any contacts. Jo had just arrived in Dublin, so she stayed in a hostel and searched for a flat. Dublin was a big unknown for her. She didn't think much about why she was going there; everyone at her school expected to leave their small town and see more of the world. Some of her classmates went to nearby towns, but Jo was the only one going to Dublin.

Jo's mother thought it would be safe for her to stay in the hostel run by nuns. Her father hoped it was warm because hostels are often cold. Her sisters, who worked as waitresses, thought she was crazy to stay in a hostel for a week. Jo didn't know they were all talking about her as she looked at an ad for a flat in Ringsend. It said, "Own room, own TV, share kitchen, bathroom." It was close to her work at the post office and seemed perfect. She hoped it was nice, that they would like her, and that it wasn't too expensive.

There wasn't a long line for this flat because it was more like "Third Girl Wanted" than "Flat to Let." The "own TV" part made Jo wonder if it was too fancy for her, but the house looked normal. It was a red-brick house with a basement, but the flat was upstairs. A girl with a college scarf, who didn't get the flat, was leaving and said, "Desperate place. They're both awful." Jo continued up the stairs.

A girl named Nessa, wearing a T-shirt with her name on it, greeted Jo. Nessa didn't like the girl who just left because she acted snobby. Pauline, the other girl, wore a very colorful shirt and had bright hair. Jo was surprised because Pauline was a punk, and Jo had never talked to a punk before. Jo introduced herself and said she worked at the post office. Nessa offered Jo a mug of tea. They had mugs with their names on them, and one said "Other." Nessa said they would put Jo's name on it if she stayed.

Text: 'Behind the dolphin's smile People love dolphins. We like to see them in seaside parks, movies, and TV shows. But the Whale and Dolphin Conservation Society says dolphins are in trouble. Mark Simmonds talks about how dolphins are disappearing. Dolphins are special to us. They are very smart, understand human feelings, and make us dream of freedom in the sea. TV shows like Flipper and Seaquest make us love them more. But these shows do not show the real problems dolphins face in dirty and overfished seas. The number of North Sea harbour porpoises (a type of dolphin) has gone down by up to 89,000. You might think dolphins are protected by law and live in safe places. But this is not true, and not helping them could be a big problem for wildlife. There are 40 kinds of dolphins in the world. In northern Europe, the most common are striped, common, bottlenose dolphins, and harbour porpoises. The first two live far out in the sea and are seen only in small groups. We do not know much about them. Bottlenose dolphins and harbour porpoises used to be common near European coasts. Bottlenose dolphins are very social and were found on the Channel coast and in British rivers like the Thames. Now, they are only in Moray Firth in Scotland and Cardigan Bay in Wales. The few left have skin injuries, showing they are stressed. Dolphins have complex habits, making it hard to know why their numbers are going down. Overfishing is a big problem. It reduces fish stocks and threatens dolphins because they need to find food quickly. If fish are gone, dolphins may not find food in time. They can also get caught in fishing nets, which they cannot see. Modern fishing uses big nets that float or move fast in the sea. Many dead dolphins have been found on French and Cornwall beaches. Marks and cuts show they died from getting caught in nets. Waste and chemicals in the sea can stay in dolphins' bodies. For example, pesticides dissolve in fat, so dolphins can eat them, and they build up in their bodies. Female dolphins pass these poisons to their babies through milk. There is a case of a baby dolphin dying from its mother's milk. Another big problem for dolphins is human noise. Dolphins live in groups and use sound to understand their world. In the sea, noise from ships and oil wells travels four times better than in the air. This noise may disturb dolphins in ways we do not know yet.'

**GETTING FIT**

Exercise is very important for your mind, body, and spirit. It helps you stay balanced when life feels busy and stressful. You might think, "Oh no, another article about exercise!" But there are many good reasons to exercise. Exercise is really good for you.

Exercise makes your muscles stronger and changes your body shape quickly. It helps you stand or sit correctly, which is called good posture. Good posture is important because it stops muscle problems that can cause injuries. Exercise also helps your heart, lungs, and blood circulation.

Exercise can make you feel less sad and tired. It helps you sleep better and manage stress. Exercise can even help with some health problems. 

There are many types of exercise you can try, like aerobics, jogging, or lifting weights. But be careful not to train too hard or lift too much weight, as this can cause injuries. Start slowly and carefully. If you are unsure, ask your doctor what is best for you.

Good posture is very important. It affects how you look and feel. If you slouch, imagine a balloon pulling your head up to the sky. This helps you stand tall and breathe better. It also makes your body look slimmer.

Stretching your muscles is important too. It makes you more flexible and helps prevent injuries. Stretching should be part of your exercise routine. Do it slowly and carefully, four or five times a week.

The best exercise routine includes a warm-up, stretching, an energetic workout, and a cool-down period.

**In Their Natural Habitat**

Why do film-makers Amanda Barrett and Owen Newman leave their comfortable homes for months? They want to find the perfect shot. In the jungles and plains of East Africa, it is hard to find Amanda and Owen. Right now, they are in the Ngorongoro Crater. It has rained for six months, causing problems. Owen said they bought an expensive tool to help when their car gets stuck in the mud. Amanda can then pull him out. Together, they have made some of TV's best wildlife films, like their famous film about leopards. Even when this film was on TV, they were back in Africa, looking for another shy animal, the jackal.

This is normal for TV partnerships. Film-makers travel the world to film wild animals. I talked to Owen at a safari lodge. He said they sometimes argue but solve it quickly. They do not see one person as the leader. They get along well because they see animals the same way. When they travel, they set up tents every night. But now, they have a fixed camp. They start at 5 a.m. and make tea the night before, keeping it warm in a flask. They eat pre-packed meals, heated by whoever is free. They can be away for up to eight weeks, so food can be a problem.

Living in remote areas is hard, but they like being close to animals. Once, they filmed a lion family. One lioness would leave and come back, greeting all the lions. She even greeted their car. Owen first worked with Amanda in 1988 on a film called 'The Great Rift'. Two years later, they filmed Arctic foxes together. They spend four months in one place to make enough material for a half-hour film. Before filming, they need to get a script approved. Owen says they work well together because they share the same ideas. They want to make films that show the true spirit of the place and animals and touch people's hearts. Owen believes making people feel something is better than just giving them information.

**The Netball Captain**

In our series about women in sports, Suzie Ellis met England's netball captain. Kendra Slawinski is the captain of England's netball team. When I met her, she had a busy day. She taught at a local school and then trained in a supermarket car park. I was surprised about her training place. 'Don't people look at you strangely?' I asked. 'I'm too focused on my movements and my feet to notice,' she said. 'I might see cars slow down, but that's all.'

'My whole life now is about being my best for the Championships,' says Kendra. She follows a strict plan to be very fit. Their first game is against Barbados, right after the opening ceremony. 'We have always beaten them, but they are exciting to play. They have a lot of skill.' The England team is ranked fourth in the world. But the World Championships will be hard. 'You have to play every day, with no rest between games. In a series, you can lose the first game and still win. But in the Championships, you only have one chance.'

In the fifteen years she has played at the top level, the sport has become harder and faster. On the court, players are more aggressive. 'You train hard to win,' says Kendra. 'But after the game, we are all friendlier.' Netball is also using more science for fitness testing. 'We must think and train like world-class players,' says Kendra. As captain, she believes it's important to have a strong mind and lead by example. She supports and encourages her team.

'From the start, my netball career was carefully planned,' she says. She decided that this competition would be her last as a player. She might coach young players in the future, but now she is focused on her last big event. As she leads her team in the opening ceremony, she might have a tear in her eye. Her loyal supporters will be with her every step of the way.

Rachel Mills is a scientist who studies the sea. She works at Southampton University and teaches about the ocean. Rachel also goes on special trips to the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. She uses a small submarine, about the size of a car, to go deep underwater. Inside the submarine, there is not much space. She can touch the two pilots sitting next to her. They cannot stand up or move much, and they have to stay inside until someone opens the door from outside. A trip can last 16 hours: three hours to go down, ten hours to collect rock and water samples, and three hours to come back up.

If there is an emergency, they can press a panic button. This makes a small escape pod go up quickly to the surface, like a ping-pong ball in water. No one has used it yet, but it might not be a fun ride.

Rachel remembers her first time in the submarine. She was on a ship and got in with a teacher. The teacher showed her what to do in an emergency, like if the pilot got sick. They wanted to see how she would feel in the small space. Now, Rachel has done six dives. Last year, she went with a Russian team to a place near the Canary Islands. There are many underwater volcanoes there. The Russian team was putting equipment there to study the volcanoes.

When Rachel is not at sea, she works in her office at the university. She loves teaching, but she also loves studying the "black smokers." These are underwater volcanoes that release hot water that looks like black smoke. The water comes out very fast and is very hot, about 350 degrees.

Rachel was scared once when she was with an American team. They were pulling equipment with a long rope when there was a big explosion. The noise was very loud, and she thought she might die. But nothing bad happened, and they were all okay. It was a big relief.

Rachel thinks diving to the bottom of the ocean is an adventure. She feels amazed every time she sees the underwater volcanoes. She studied them for three years for her Ph.D., and seeing them in real life was an incredible experience.

**Interview Tips**

First impressions are very important. People decide what they think about us in the first few minutes. They look at how we dress, our eye contact, our body movements, and how we speak. This includes how fast or slow we talk, our voice volume and tone, and the words we use.

Mary Pearce studied to be a teacher. She says, "I worked hard to earn my degree. When I graduated, I was very confident." She applied for a job at a primary school and got an interview with the Head Teacher. "I noticed a small hole in my jacket that morning," she remembers. "I would have changed, but I knew it would make me late, and I think it's important to be on time." Mary didn't get the job. Her friend, who also works at the school, told her the Head Teacher said, "If someone doesn't take the time to look their best at an interview, what kind of teacher will they be?"

Simon Grant, a hotel manager, says, "People who look like they care about themselves are more likely to care about their jobs. People think it's what's inside that counts, but in an interview, you should try to look your best." Many people forget how important it is to look professional. For example, Janet Goodwood worked for ten years as an assistant in a big accounting firm. When the office manager retired, she applied for the job but didn't get an interview. She asked the Director of Personnel why. He said she didn't look like an office manager and suggested she improve her wardrobe before applying again. Janet was surprised. She thought her work was good and how she dressed shouldn't matter.

How we move and use gestures also affects the interviewer's first impression. Psychologist Albert Mehrabian found that 7% of our feelings and attitudes come from words, 38% from our voice, and 55% from our facial expressions. If our facial expressions and words send different messages, the listener will believe the non-verbal message more. So, make sure your words match your body language. Mixed messages can confuse the interviewer.

It's also important not to seem too desperate for the job or too eager to please. Sheila Rice, a marketing specialist, applied for a promotion. Her interview went well, and she got the job offer right away. "I was very happy," she says. "But I showed too much excitement. When the boss saw how excited I was, he knew I wouldn't say no. So, he offered me a lower salary than I wanted. I think I could have gotten more if I had controlled my excitement."

Finally, what we say and how we say it is important for a successful interview. David Artesio, a manager at an employment agency, suggests learning about the company before the interview. "The annual report, for example, will tell you about the company. Mention something that interests you during the interview. This shows you are interested in the company." Business consultant Marian Woodall suggests having a few questions ready and speaking in short, clear sentences. She says, "Poor communicators talk in long paragraphs. Successful communicators talk in short sentences and clear points."

**A New Life**

**The Farmer**

Matt Froggatt used to work as an insurance agent in London. Now, he has a sheep farm. He worked in the city for 14 years, but it became boring and not fun anymore. He lost his job suddenly and used the money he got to start the farm. He met a chef from a famous hotel, and now he sells meat to them and also by mail. He is happy not to be in an office, but he still works long hours.

**The Painter**

Ron Ablewhite was a manager in advertising. Now, he is an artist. Painting was his hobby, and he enjoyed it more than his job. He decided to leave his job and become an artist. A career counselor helped him. Most people need to work for money, but Ron and his wife married young, and their children are grown up. They moved to the north of England, far from friends, but their friends still visit them.

**The Hat Maker**

Katherine Goodison was a lawyer for five years. Now, she makes hats in her London flat. She liked her job as a lawyer, but the hours were too long. She left because she didn’t want to work more and more hours. People thought she would get bored, but she didn’t. She likes having deadlines and being in charge of her work. She misses talking to colleagues but likes being responsible for her product.

**The Masseur**

Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years. Now, he is a masseur at the Life Centre in London. He started working in finance at 22 but didn’t find it rewarding. He almost lost his job in 1989, so he quit and traveled for a year. He wanted to work in health, so he visited gyms and talked to owners. He took massage courses and got a part-time job at the Life Centre. He is happy now and feels in control of his life.

**Dedicated to Their Sports: Four Young Sports Stars Talk About Their Lives**

**A. Darius (Runner)**  
I have always loved sports. I tried many sports, but I was best at football and running. When I was 14, I had a chance to join a professional football club, but I chose running instead. My best moment was when I ran for my country in the youth team and won a medal. Sadly, it did not get much attention from the media, and I hoped to get some sponsorship because training is expensive. I train at home in winter and then go to Florida for three weeks before the season starts. It's fun because there are great places to train and good nightlife. But I have to be disciplined. If friends ask me to go out before training, I have to say no. I want to go to the next Olympics - that would be amazing.

**B. Gabriel (Surfer)**  
The surfing community is small, so you meet the same people at competitions. Professional surfers are serious, and the best waves are often early in the morning. So, you can't go to late-night parties if you want to succeed. I don't mind that, but I love sleeping in, and I have to give that up too. It's worth it because I won the National Championships last year. After a win, I like to have a big night out, and if I win money, I go somewhere nice. Winning the championship helped me get a job on a TV surfing show. I guess I'm a bit famous now.

**C. Dieter (Yacht Racer)**  
When five guys are on a boat, we have a lot of fun. We celebrate wins in style. Some people say we act like kids, but we don't look for media attention. Reporters sometimes care more about our celebrations than our race results. I'm away for eight months a year, so it's nice to come home and hang out with friends who do different things. You can't think about the sport all the time - it's not healthy. I'm known in sailing, but I don't get recognized on the street often. I don't want to be a celebrity. I get nice letters asking for signed pictures, and I reply to all of them, even if it takes time.

**D. Tomas (Tennis Player)**  
It's great to play tennis and feel the crowd supporting you. At the last tournament, it got a bit crazy with people around me. I like being noticed by fans when I'm out shopping, but it can be hard. My last girlfriend didn't like it when I got attention from female fans. Tennis players travel a lot, and that's why we broke up. It was tough, but you have to make sacrifices in sports. You have to be serious and professional. I'm okay with focusing on my game now and doing other things after I retire, which happens early in tennis.

**Shopping with Children**

Shopping in a supermarket with children can be very difficult for parents. One mother says, "They want everything they see. If it's not a new sugary cereal, it's a Disney video or a comic. Usually, they want all three. I can't buy all this, and I feel bad if I give in and buy unhealthy things. But I also feel bad for saying no all the time, and I get upset before we even leave home. I try not to take them shopping, but then I worry they won't learn how to make choices. I can't win."

Research shows that children ask to buy something every two minutes in a supermarket. More than £150 million a year is spent on advertising to children, mostly on TV. This number is likely to grow, and supermarkets are where this advertising works best. Children often don't understand why their parents say no to buying things. They don't find reasons like "sugar is bad for your teeth" convincing when they see fun and exciting ads.

Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says, "Most parents care about what their children eat and have ideas about healthy food, but these ideas are not always right. It's good for parents and children to talk about food because if children only learn from TV ads, they get a one-sided view. Parents don't like competing with ads and having to say no to their children."

The Independent Television Commission, which controls TV ads, doesn't allow advertisers to tell children to ask their parents to buy things. But, as Dibb says, "The goal of advertising is to make people want to buy something. Even if they can't say, 'Tell your mum to buy this,' they still want that to happen."

Some parents find it stressful to decide which things to buy and which to refuse. One mother says she talks a lot with her children about food and ads. Her son is critical of ads, and they look at labels together. She says, "I've talked so much that he thinks all ads are rubbish. We don't fight in the supermarket now because the children don't ask for things I won't buy."

Parents also say they are not always fair in how they respond to their children's requests. Mike, a father of a seven-year-old son and a three-year-old daughter, says, "We say no to sweets because they're bad for him, but we buy cream and chocolate for ourselves. It's fun to buy nice things, and it's normal for children to want that too. But I still get annoyed by their demands. It depends on how I feel. If I'm happy, I'm more likely to say yes. It's hard to be fair all the time."

Supermarkets could help by not putting sweets near the checkout or by having play areas for children. Parents might spend less if their children aren't with them, but shopping without a child's demands might bring in more customers.

**Luxury and Modern Technology at the Merrion Hotel**

The Merrion Hotel is a new five-star hotel in Dublin. It took almost two years to change four old houses into this hotel. The hotel has the latest technology for both staff and guests. 

The General Manager, Peter MacCann, wants his staff to know guests by name. For other details, he uses a computer system. This system helps the hotel treat returning guests in a special way. It cost a lot of money, but MacCann believes it will be worth it. For example, if a guest likes certain music, the hotel will have it ready for their next visit.

Guests often complain about room temperature. The hotel has a system to control this. Guests can change the temperature a little, or the front desk can change it more.

Business guests will like the technology in the rooms. Each room has three phones, two phone lines, a fax machine, and video-conferencing. The hotel is ready for future technology changes. TVs and DVD players can be updated easily.

Even with all this technology, the rooms are comfortable and welcoming. The hotel has 145 large rooms, a swimming pool, gym, conference rooms, bars, restaurants, and a beautiful garden.

The food at the hotel is excellent. Chef Patrick Guilbaud, who has two Michelin stars, moved his restaurant to the hotel. This is good for both him and the hotel. He has a new kitchen and better parking. The hotel offers a great place to eat without financial risk.

With technology and a great staff, the Merrion Hotel is set to succeed.

**Where I Get My Energy**

Emma Marsden asked six women how they stay energetic and happy. Here is what they said:

**A. Jeanette Kupfermann - Journalist and Author:**  
Jeanette feels energetic when she is excited and learning new things. She loves challenges. Right now, she is learning flamenco dancing, which makes her feel full of energy. She believes that being bored can make you feel tired. Doing something useful, even if it's small, gives her energy.

**B. Linda Kelsey - Magazine Editor:**  
Linda enjoys her work, so it doesn't feel hard for her. She needs a lot of sleep to feel good. When she sleeps only six hours, she feels tired. Exercise gives her energy, but she finds it hard to start. She does yoga once a week and tries to exercise at home. Exercise makes her feel happy. She feels tired in the afternoon and thinks eating something helps.

**C. Annie Nightingale - Disc Jockey:**  
Annie gets her energy from being positive and enthusiastic. She doesn't like negative people. She believes in enjoying life and setting goals. Her job is exciting, and she loves being around young, lively people. She enjoys taking photos and writing song lyrics for fun. This helps her relax when she travels a lot.

**D. Floella Benjamin - Author and Children's TV Presenter:**  
Floella gets energy from doing things she loves. She believes in being positive and enjoys working with children. Smiling at people and getting a smile back makes her feel good. She tries to eat healthy and doesn't smoke or drink. She doesn't have an exercise plan but stays active by playing with kids.

**E. Deborah Moggach - Author and Playwright:**  
Deborah loves making gardens from empty spaces. She once turned a concrete area into a garden, which was better than any workout. Writing for people who want to read her work gives her energy. She enjoys exploring nature, even if it's private land, because it feels fun and childlike.

**F. Katherine Monblot - Therapist:**  
Katherine believes in doing things you care about. She likes taking risks and gets bored easily, which keeps her motivated. Doing things you don't like can make you tired. She used to be on committees but didn't enjoy it. She thinks it's important to use your energy on things that matter to you.

**ICE SKATING**

Ice skating has been around for thousands of years. Long ago, people used skates made from animal bones. These bone skates were used until about 200 AD when iron skates came to Scandinavia. In Scandinavia, rich people thought skating was an important skill. 

In the early 1900s, skating was calm and stylish. But in the 1924 Winter Olympics, an 11-year-old girl named Sonja Henie made skating more athletic. This made skating more popular. Today, skating is a mix of art and sport. It is beautiful and also hard work.

When you start skating, balance and control are very important. You can go faster as you get better. Your body position helps with balance. Keep your legs slightly bent and knees bent to stay balanced. Your body should lean a little forward. Relaxation is very important in skating.

To start skating, your heels should almost touch, and your feet should point outwards. Push forward with your back foot and make a small movement with the other foot. It is not too hard, right? As you practice, you can make your movements bigger.

Learning how to fall is one of the first things skaters need to know. Even the best skaters fall. To fall safely, try to stay relaxed. This helps reduce the impact when you hit the ice. To get up, use your hands to kneel, then stand up.

Once you can skate confidently, you can try different styles like figure skating, freestyle, distance, speed, and pair skating. It is best to start with figure skating and then learn basic freestyle. Most ice rinks have teachers who can help you learn the basics. Soon, you can learn turns, jumps, and spins.

Good skaters look relaxed and move easily. To be like them, you should do exercises regularly. It is dangerous to skate with a stiff body. Warm-up exercises should include legs, back, shoulders, ankles, and knees. After skating, do the same exercises to avoid stiffness.

Skating helps improve balance, coordination, relaxation, and movement. It is good for your heart and lungs and makes your body stronger. If you also swim or jog, it is a great way to stay healthy and fit.

**Trills and Medals**

Seeing a talented child win a medal can make you cry with happiness. Julia Gregson talked to three young stars and their mothers about their lives.

**A. Annika Reeder, 15**

Annika won a gold medal in gymnastics at the Commonwealth Games. She wants to be a physiotherapist and compete in the next Olympics. "The work is very hard now. I don't have time to watch TV, go out with friends, or do much besides gym and school. I try to take each training day by day. When I feel very tired, my coach sometimes gives me a day off, but usually, I keep going. You can't take too many days off because it makes you stiff."

**B. Annika's Mother**

"Annika showed great talent from a young age. Some parents push their children, but it doesn't work. To perform like Annika, you have to want it yourself.
