People say we, as parents, have given up a lot, but they don't see what the sport has given us. We love it and what it has done for Annika. Before gymnastics, she was a shy girl who sucked her thumb and hid behind me. Now, she has met people from all over the world and has the confidence of success."

**C. Sarah Stokes**

Sarah started show-jumping at ten and has won the British National Championship. "It's good my mum and dad like show-jumping because they train me and take me everywhere in the horse box. The shows last from one to five days. I never get tired of it—I love show-jumping events; they are exciting and fun. Even without Mum and Dad, I would do it because I am determined. I'm glad they are happy when I win, but I'm not doing it for them. My goal this year is to join the British young riders (under-18) team. My big dream is to win a gold medal at the Olympics."

**D. Sarah's Mother**

"Sarah loved horses from age 1. At 5, she got up early to exercise her pony. To qualify for big shows, you have to jump all over England. To save money, we sleep in the horse box. Sarah is well-organized and very happy on a horse. Watching your child succeed at something they love is wonderful."

**E. Jane McShane, 10**

Jane is Britain's Under-14 Chess Champion. "Tournaments are friendly. I know everyone, and it's fun. When I play, I don't concentrate much. I should, but I just look around and don't think too hard. I'm not worried about being too proud. I don't talk about my success at school because I don't like feeling embarrassed."

**F. Jane's Mother**

"Jane played her first chess game at 5. My father said, 'Let's see if she likes it.' He tried to teach me when I was young, but I was bored. Jane loved it from the start. By the end of that day, she knew all the moves, and by 6, she was beating adults. I'm happy when she wins, but if she wanted to stop, I wouldn't stop her. I don't want to put her down because she is special. If she has this gift, let her use it."

Chris Greener was 14 years old when he told his teacher he wanted to join the navy. The teacher joked, "Do you want to be the flagpole on a ship?" because Chris was already almost two meters tall. Now, Chris is 228 cm tall and is the tallest man in Britain. 

Every ten years, people in Europe get about one centimeter taller. More tall people are being born each year. This does not mean we are becoming a new super race. Instead, we are becoming like our ancestors from 40,000 years ago. Back then, people ate many different foods. Women collected herbs, fruits, and berries, while men hunted animals. They ate about 85 different wild plants.

About 9,000 years ago, farming started. This changed everything. Farmers grew wheat, rice, and maize, which now give us more than half of our calories. This diet was not good for our health. People became less healthy and smaller. In Ohio, scientists found that when people started farming corn, they became sick and underweight. Corn caused tooth decay and diseases.

Farming spread because it could feed more people than hunting and gathering. But many people were not well-fed. Only recently have countries like Europe, the US, and Japan started eating better again. Now, the average man in the US is 179 cm tall, in Holland 180 cm, and in Japan 177 cm.

This increase in height has some problems. Beds are still 190 cm long, and there is less legroom in planes and trains. Clothes makers have to change their sizes. We cannot keep growing forever. Scientists think we might reach an average height of 193 cm this century.

However, as a species, we are actually getting smaller. During the last ice age, people were rounder and taller to stay warm. Now, as the Earth gets warmer, we might become thinner and smaller. Global warming could make us shrink.

**Studio Audiences**

What is it like to be in the audience when a TV show is made? Cosmo Landesman found out. Studio audiences are a normal part of TV, but many people don't understand them. When we see them excited on game shows, we wonder, "Who are these people?" Some people think studio audiences are not very important. Even people who work in TV sometimes don't respect them. I thought studio audiences were just people who wanted to be on TV for a short time. But there is no typical studio audience. They come from all kinds of backgrounds and jobs. TV shows try to get different people for different shows.

Some people like to watch TV at home and don't understand why others go to a studio. Why would someone get tickets, travel far, and sit for hours in a studio to watch something they can see at home? One idea is that people want to be on TV for a moment. I didn't believe this until I talked to Angela. She said she came because she might be on TV. Another idea is that people are curious about how TV shows are made. But most people said they came because a friend gave them a ticket.

Not many of us have been in a studio audience, but we think we know what it's like. You sit with strangers, and someone shows signs that say "APPLAUD" or "LAUGH," and you clap or laugh. This might be true for some shows, but not all. A studio manager said, "We hope a show is good enough not to need these signs."

Is there a difference between watching in a studio and at home? Claire thinks sitting in a studio is "more exciting," and Charlotte liked being part of live TV. "Last year I saw my favorite comedian. At home, you miss a lot." I missed seeing live actors because I could only see the back of someone's head. The first scenes were so far away that I watched on a studio screen. Going to a studio might not be the best way to watch TV, but that's not the point. For most people, it was just fun and a free night out.

**Bruce**  
I don't like wild places without people. I like places with a human touch. When I travel, I like pretty villages with old temples, not empty deserts. When I was eight, I went to school in England. On Saturdays, I rode my bike to the village of Lastingham in a nice valley. Riding my bike helped me feel free from school. I loved exploring the high hills, quiet valleys, and old villages. I am from Scotland, so the landscape felt familiar but also different. I still visit there today. I used to write about my adventures in a private diary. That was my first try at travel writing, which later became my job.

**Sophia**  
There is a small train that goes from Hythe to Dungeness, run by people who love trains. I always travel first class because it doesn't cost much more. The scenery is not amazing. The train goes across Romney Marsh with its sheep and next to a canal. But I always look forward to one part of the journey when the train goes through back gardens. For a few moments, we can see people doing everyday things like making tea or washing dishes. I see myself as a woman in a small train, looking into other people's homes. I like the simple landscape. Just fields, sheep, and a faraway grey sea. It makes me look closely to find something special.

**Matthew**  
The Hartland Peninsula is a beautiful and quiet coast. The beaches are hard to reach and have many rocks, so not many people go there. Some brave surfers come, but most people like to think about the sea's beauty. The coast faces the Atlantic Ocean and is known for shipwrecks. There are walks along the coast and trips inland through pretty valleys with oak trees, ferns, and wildflowers. We stay in simple places with a family in the village of Southole.

**Annette**  
My favorite place in England is the Trough of Bowland, a wide-open moorland perfect for hiking. Not many people live or visit there. It's a quiet and empty place, and I like the feeling of space. I found the area by accident when I was a student. Since then, I visit every year, sometimes alone, with my boyfriend, and now with my son. It hasn't changed much since my first visit. Having a child makes these visits special. It makes me sad that he is growing up in a city.

**James**  
I bought Glenthorne, my favorite house in Britain. I wanted peace and to connect with my English roots. I grew up in Sri Lanka, but at twelve, I went to school in Devon, England. I used to ride my bike around the moors and village streets. We had a story about a place we never cycled past: if you went down the driveway, you'd never return. That place was Glenthorne. It's my dream place. It's a magical, quiet, romantic house. You can't hear anything except the sea, wind, and birds.

**HAPPY HUNTING GROUND**

We are a family that loves animals. One afternoon, my daughter called me at work. She was excited because she found a pine snake. She asked, "Can we keep him?" I said, "Yes, but only for one night." We have a special tank for animals we find, so we can look at them and read about them in our nature book.

I came home late and started cooking. Suddenly, I heard my children shouting, "Oh, Mother! Help! Do something!" I ran to their room. Our cat, Domino, had caught Bianca, a white mouse that was a Mother's Day gift for me. Domino was running around with the mouse in his mouth. The room was full of furniture and children, and everyone was trying to catch Domino.

I tried to help and fell on the floor. Then I saw the snake. It was escaping from its tank. The snake was moving across the floor. The room was full of noise with the cat, mouse, kids, and even the dog barking. I quickly turned off the boiling pot in the kitchen and came back. I caught Domino by the tail and saved the mouse. The mouse was wet but not hurt. This mouse was caught by Domino three more times but lived a long life.

After saving the mouse, I looked at the snake. It was hard to catch. I sat on the floor like a snake-charmer, moving slowly. The snake finally relaxed. I carefully picked it up and took it to the garden. I wanted the snake to live in the garden shed. But when I let go of its head, the snake climbed over my shoulders like a scarf. It seemed to like me because I was warm.

My eldest child, DJ, said, "You know what it is, Mum? You're nice and warm, and the shed isn't." We all helped the snake move to the shed. Slowly, it went up the wall and over the roof. As the snake's tail disappeared, my three-year-old, Clay, said, "Boy, that was one big snake!"

Text: 'Write me a letter! In our fast world of phones, fax machines, and computers, writing letters is disappearing. But for me, getting a letter is special. It is exciting to see who it is from and to read what it says. I have been writing letters for a long time. It started with small notes to my mother. She always made me write thank-you letters for Christmas and birthday gifts. It didn't matter if they were short or messy, as long as they were letters. When I left home at 18 to study medicine in London, I wrote a letter every week, and so did my mother. Sometimes my father wrote too, and his letters were funny and long. Most letters from home talked about everyday things. We also made phone calls, but I remember the letters more. I also got letters from boyfriends. Many of them had to work or study far away, so we wrote letters to stay in touch. Writing letters made our relationships better. I could say things in writing that were hard to say in person. I love letters that come with birthday or Christmas cards. Notes are nice, but a letter with a lot of news is better! It's even better when it comes in an airmail envelope with pretty stamps. I get letters from Mangala in Sri Lanka, a friend I trained with 20 years ago. I also have a penfriend in Australia and another in Vancouver. There is a lady from France who writes to me. We met in a restaurant on holiday. My husband took her photo, and I asked for her address. If she hadn't replied, we wouldn't have become friends. Now we write to each other often. I can practice my French because she doesn't speak English. We have visited each other's homes. My biggest letter-writing success was this summer. My family and I stayed with my American penfriend in Texas. We had been writing for 29 years but never met. Everyone was surprised that we wrote for so long. The local newspaper even wrote about it. I am happy my children are writing letters too. Like my mother, I make them write thank-you letters. My daughter writes me little letters, just like I did to my mother. She and my son have penfriends in Texas, thanks to my penfriend. I hope people keep writing letters and don't let it become a 'lost art'.'

**Careless Tourists Damage Ancient Rock Art**

In the French Alps, there are many old pictures carved into rocks at Mont Bego. These pictures are very special and important. They are about 4,000 years old and show cows, fields, and gods. But now, these pictures are being damaged by tourists. 

Jean Clottes, an expert on rock art, says that if the damage continues, the pictures might be gone in 50 years. Tourists sometimes step on the drawings or even take pieces home. Some people rub the drawings to see them better, which also harms them. Others scratch their own names or pictures into the rocks.

Experts have different ideas on how to protect the drawings. Henry de Lumley, from the Museum of Natural History in Paris, thinks the mountain should be closed to the public, except for guided tours. He believes this will save the site and help with research. But Jean Clottes disagrees because he thinks people living nearby will not like this idea.

David Lavergne, a regional architect, also wants to keep the site open. He says it is hard to stop people from damaging the area because it is very large. He suggests charging a fee to visit, but there is not enough money to hire guards.

Annie Echassoux, another researcher, is worried because tourists can now reach the site more easily. She thinks the area should be roped off and guides should be provided. She believes money must be found to protect the site because it is a historic place. If nothing is done, future generations might lose these important drawings.

**Shopping with Children**

Shopping in a supermarket with children can be very difficult for parents. One mother says, "They want everything they see. If it's not a new sugary cereal, it's a Disney video or a comic. Usually, they want all three. I can't buy all this, and I feel bad if I give in and buy unhealthy things. But I also feel bad for saying no all the time, and I get upset before we even leave home. I try not to take them shopping, but then I worry they won't learn how to make choices. I can't win."

Research shows that children ask to buy something every two minutes in a supermarket. More than £150 million a year is spent on advertising to children, mostly on TV. This number is likely to grow, and supermarkets are where this advertising works best. Children often don't understand why their parents say no to buying things. They don't find reasons like "sugar is bad for your teeth" convincing when they see fun and exciting ads.

Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says, "Most parents care about what their children eat and have ideas about healthy food, but these ideas are not always right. It's good for parents and children to talk about food because if children only learn from TV ads, they get a one-sided view. Parents don't like competing with ads and having to say no to their children."

The Independent Television Commission, which controls TV ads, does not allow advertisers to tell children to ask their parents to buy things. But, as Dibb says, "The goal of advertising is to make people want to buy something. Even if they can't say, 'Tell your mum to buy this,' they still want that result."

Some parents find it stressful to decide which things to buy and which to refuse. One mother says she talks a lot with her children about food and ads. Her son is critical of ads, and they look at labels together. She says, "I've talked so much that he thinks all ads are rubbish. We don't fight in the supermarket now because the children don't ask for things I won't buy."

Parents also say they are not always consistent. Mike, a father of two, says, "We say no to sweets because they're bad, but we buy cream and chocolate for ourselves. It's fun to buy nice things, and it's normal for children to want that too. But I still get annoyed by their demands. It depends on how I feel. If I'm happy, I'm more likely to say yes. It's hard to be consistent."

Supermarkets could help by not putting sweets near the checkout or by having play areas for children. Parents might spend less if their children are not with them, but shopping without a child's demands might bring more customers.

Title: Climbing Walls

In the past, climbers went to mountains. Now, people can climb anywhere, inside or outside. At the World Cup Climbing Championships in Birmingham, a French climber named Francois Lombard is climbing on a wall. He is hanging upside down by his fingers. This event is at the National Indoor Arena, which is also known for the TV show Gladiators. Both events have a big wall for climbing.

Before the 1960s, climbers practiced on cliffs. In winter, they climbed in cold places like Scotland. But climbers needed to stay fit all year. So, they started using brick walls to practice. This helped them keep their fingers strong.

Soon, sports centers began building special climbing walls. These walls had bricks with special edges to hold on to. Don Robinson, a teacher, made one of the first climbing walls at Leeds University in the 1960s. He used natural rock set in concrete for the wall.

In the 1970s, many climbing walls were built in sports halls. But these walls had problems. They were only straight up and down, unlike real cliffs with different shapes. Also, once built, they couldn't be changed, so climbers got bored.

In 1985, a Frenchman named Francois Savigny made a new material for climbing holds. These could be put on and taken off walls easily. French companies also started using steel frames for walls. Steel is lighter than concrete, so it was easier to make walls with different shapes. This gave climbers many new ways to climb.

Text: 'Do you want to be an actor? If you tell someone you want to be an actor, they will probably say it is 'risky.' Acting is a risky job because there are more actors than jobs. When you decide to be an actor, some friends might say you are crazy, but others might not. Everyone will give you different advice. It is your choice, and you are responsible for your dream. There are no easy ways to become an actor. There are no exams to pass, and no guarantee you will succeed after training. It takes luck and talent. But there is always a need for new actors, and acting can be exciting and glamorous. Sometimes, it can also be rewarding. People often ask what talent is. Talent is natural skill and imagination. Imagination is hard to measure. Talent also involves courage and belief in what you do. Why do people want to act? It is hard to explain. In theatre, the important thing is the connection between the actor and the audience. This connection is what makes actors want to act. If you ask actors how they succeed, they might not know. They know about their skills and others' skills, but they do not take success for granted. They know they are only as good as their current job, and fame might not last. Disappointment is a big problem for actors. Last month, you might have been out of work, selling clothes, or waitressing. Then, you get an audition, but you might not get the job. Actors do not talk about their chances. They find ways to handle the stress of auditions and rejection. Nobody likes rejection. Remember, rejection can happen from the first time you try for a part. You are saying you are available, willing, and hopefully talented. It is up to you because if you do not care, no one else will care for you.'

**Food for Everyone**

We are happy to show you our special collection of the best cookbooks available now.

**A. Delia Smith**

When people think of a famous TV cook and writer, they often think of Delia Smith. Her recipes come from many countries, and she loves exciting food. She also knows what most people can cook at home. Her book, "Delia Smith's Complete Cookery Course," is very popular. It is a great book for both basic and advanced cooking. Delia gives simple advice and shares many great recipes. The book was recently updated and is perfect for anyone who wants just one cookbook.

**B. Raymond Blanc**

Raymond Blanc became a famous chef in Britain in just 15 years. He has a TV show called "Blanc Mange," and there is a book with the same name. Raymond wants to help us become better cooks by showing how ingredients work together. He believes cooking is easy when you understand what happens in the pan. The book has over 80 great recipes and explains why some dishes might not work. It also teaches some basic food science. Raymond loves to cook for others, and this book shows he is very good at it.

**C. Le Cordon Bleu**

Le Cordon Bleu is famous for classical French cooking. For 100 years, their expert chefs have trained students to cook perfectly. To celebrate their 100th anniversary, they have a new book called "Le Cordon Bleu Classic French Cookbook." It has 100 respected recipes. The recipes are classic but still fresh. Le Cordon Bleu has changed to use fewer rich sauces and fewer calories. The book starts with basic kitchen skills and then has sections for Appetisers, Main dishes, and Desserts. The recipes have step-by-step pictures and beautiful photos of the finished dishes. Expert chefs from around the world share their famous recipes and secrets.

**D. Nigel Slater**

Nigel Slater, food editor of The Observer, believes good food doesn't have to take a long time to cook. His new book, "The 30-Minute Cook," shows that fast food can be delicious. Nigel says fast food is perfect when you come home tired and hungry. He thinks you can make something tasty in the time it takes to get a pizza delivered. This book has over 200 recipes from around the world, all ready in 30 minutes. Nigel writes in a fun and enjoyable way. If you think fast food can't be good, try his recipes—they are simply delicious.

Chris Greener was 14 years old when he told his teacher he wanted to join the navy. The teacher joked, "Do you want to be the flagpole on a ship?" because Chris was already almost two meters tall. Now, Chris is 228 cm tall and is the tallest man in Britain.

Every ten years, people in Europe get about one centimeter taller. More tall people are being born each year. This does not mean we are becoming a new super race. Instead, we are going back to how we were as cavemen. We are now eating better, which helps us grow to our full height. Professor Chris Stringer says we are becoming like Cro-Magnons, who lived 40,000 years ago.

In the past, people got food from many places. Women collected herbs, fruits, and berries, while men hunted animals. They ate about 85 different wild plants. But 9,000 years ago, farming started, which changed everything. Farmers grew wheat, rice, and maize, which now give us more than half of our calories. This diet was not good for our health. People became less healthy and smaller. In Ohio, scientists found that when people started farming corn, they became sick and underweight. Corn caused more tooth decay and diseases.

Farming spread because it could feed more people than hunting and gathering. But many people were not well-fed and stayed small. Only recently have richer countries like Europe, the US, and Japan started eating better again. Now, the average man in the US is 179 cm tall, in Holland 180 cm, and in Japan 177 cm.

This is good, but it also causes problems. Beds are still 190 cm long, and there is less legroom in planes and trains. Clothes makers have to change their sizes. We cannot keep growing forever. Robert Fogel from the University says we might grow to 193 cm this century.

However, scientists say that while individuals are getting taller, as a species, we are actually getting smaller. During the last ice age, 10,000 years ago, people were rounder and taller to stay warm. Now, as the climate gets warmer, we are getting thinner and smaller. If the planet keeps getting hotter, we might shrink even more.

**A New Life**

**The Farmer**

Matt Froggatt used to work as an insurance agent in London. Now, he has a sheep farm. He worked in the city for 14 years, but it became boring and not fun anymore. He lost his job suddenly and used the money he got to start the farm. He met a chef from a famous hotel, and now he sells meat to them and also by mail. He is happy not to be in an office, but he still works long hours.

**The Painter**

Ron Ablewhite was a manager in advertising. Now, he is an artist. Painting was his hobby, and he enjoyed it more than his job. He decided to leave his job and become an artist. A career counselor helped him. Most people need to work for money, but Ron and his wife married young, and their children are grown up. They moved to the north of England, far from friends, but their friends still visit them.

**The Hat Maker**

Katherine Goodison was a lawyer for five years. Now, she makes hats in her London flat. She liked her job as a lawyer, but the hours were too long. She left because she didn’t want to work more and more hours. People thought she would get bored, but she didn’t. She likes having deadlines and being in charge of her work. She misses talking to colleagues but enjoys being responsible for her product.

**The Masseur**

Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years. Now, he is a masseur at the Life Centre in London. He liked the excitement of finance but didn’t find it rewarding. He almost lost his job in 1989, so he quit and traveled for a year. He wanted to work in health, so he visited gyms and learned about starting a business. He took massage courses and got a part-time job at the Life Centre. He is happy now and feels in control of his life.

**Two Brothers and Their Game**

Dave and Norm Lagasse are two brothers in their forties with big beards. They live in a simple house in Santa Fe, New Mexico, USA. They are playing a game from their childhood called pichenotte. Their grandfather, Lucien Rajotte, brought the game from Quebec, Canada, to the USA. The family played it often on weekends and holidays. When they moved to New Mexico, they kept playing the game. Visitors were curious because the game was not known in the southern USA.

Three years ago, Dave saw that their old pichenotte board was broken. He decided to make a new one. It was very nice, and soon family and friends wanted one too. The brothers took a board to a sports bar in Santa Fe. At first, people thought the game looked silly, but once they started playing, they loved it.

Dave learned that the game might have started in India as 'carroms'. It changed into 'squails' in Britain and then became pichenotte in Quebec, Canada. Pichenotte is a game for two to four people. Each player has 12 pieces called 'pucks'. You flick the pucks with your finger across a board. If you get a puck into a small hole, you score 20 points. There are also rings worth 15, 10, and 5 points. The game lasts about two minutes.

The game became popular in Santa Fe. The brothers made more boards and sold them at markets and craft fairs. They even started a championship with a trophy called the 'Lord Pichenotte Cup'. The boards sold quickly, so the brothers decided to make pichenotte boards full-time. They set up a workshop in their garage and have made over 450 boards. Each board is made of birchwood and mahogany, weighs 12kg, and is 1cm thick. They sell for $595 on the brothers' website.

There are no professional pichenotte players or TV shows yet, but the brothers hope the game will make them rich. For now, they enjoy playing the game they love.

**WELCOME TO THE MODEL VILLAGE**

When you come to the Model Village, it is hard to believe that a few years ago, this place was just empty land with lots of wild plants. People thought it was useless land. But one man, with help from his wife, worked very hard to make it beautiful. They moved a lot of soil and clay to change the flat land into the nice shapes you see today. Machines helped, but there was also a lot of hard work by hand. They brought in about 1,000 tonnes of good soil to make the grass, flower beds, and rock gardens.

Many trees and bushes were planted. They had to choose plants that could live near the sea and in strong winter winds. Most plants came from local garden shops, but some came from far places like Canada and New Zealand.

Colin Sims thought of the Model Village. He made over 100 models by himself over nine years, starting in 1972. The models are made from stone, concrete, special wood, and plastic to last in all weather. At first, Colin needed help from experts to learn about materials, but soon he became an expert too.

You will see that all models are made to the same size scale, with lots of detail. This took a lot of patience and special building methods. The Model Village is very popular because of its high quality. The building methods are now used in other model villages in England and are taught in some schools.

The model buildings show traditional British styles. One of the best is the Manor House, a 13th-century stone building with a brick tower. It looks like manor houses in the West Country. You will also see a Castle, St Mary's Church, a zoo, and a mini golf course, which is new.

Please stay on the paths and do not touch the models. If you fall, it can take us a long time to fix the models. You can take photos from the paths. Dogs are welcome if they are on a short lead.

To enjoy your visit more, you can press buttons in front of some models to make them move. At the end of your visit, we would like to hear your thoughts. We are always planning new models, and your ideas can help us. Tell us if you think any models are not as good as the others. We keep updating the models and need to know which ones need fixing.

We hope you enjoy your visit and come back again. Please tell your friends about the Model Village.

Week after week, British tabloid newspapers show pictures that invade people's privacy. These pictures often break the rules that newspaper editors should follow. Sometimes pop stars pose for photographers, but this is not common. Usually, these pictures hurt famous people because they show private moments on the front page. However, not many people ask the Press Complaints Commission (PCC) for help. The PCC is an organization that deals with these problems. These pictures are rarely important for the public. For example, do private photos of pop stars help solve a crime? How did a picture of a famous actress on a hotel balcony protect public health and safety? The actress was upset about these pictures before. She was in a hotel, a place where she should expect privacy, so she had a good reason to complain, but she didn't. The PCC did not investigate, which is surprising. They should also look into a recent story about a pop star's love life. The pop star, like the actress, did not make a formal complaint. Shouldn't the PCC do something about these attacks? At first, this seems like a good idea. It would lead to many decisions against newspapers. Other newspapers and TV would report these decisions. The public would not support the newspapers, and editors would stop publishing such material. Even photographers would stop taking these pictures because it would not be worth it. If the PCC acted like a 'police officer', there would be problems. How would it decide to start an investigation? Should it ask the victim to complain? And if the person still refused, should it continue? Also, famous people might expect every story about them to be investigated and be upset if it wasn't. The role is too big. How could the PCC watch all British newspapers and magazines? There is also the embarrassment factor. Even if someone's privacy is invaded, would they want more embarrassment from an investigation? Most people probably want to forget about it and move on. Some might have other reasons to stay quiet. They might have a worse story they want to keep secret, and they fear it might come out if they complain. In this way, even the PCC might seem like the enemy. A British comedian also had problems with the press. He and his wife were secretly photographed on their honeymoon. He didn't complain then or later when his family was photographed on holiday. He was afraid the newspaper would publish the pictures again with a new story about his anger. They might say it was just a joke and that, as a comedian, he should have a sense of humor. This fear is understandable. People think they will be targeted again if they challenge the tabloids. It is hard to find an easy solution to this serious problem.

Many people give advice to students who finish college and are looking for their first job. This article talks about moving to a second job. We are not talking about people looking for a temporary job while searching for a permanent one. We are also not talking about people leaving a bad job after a few weeks. We are talking about people who are ready to take a real step in their career. You have learned some skills and have an idea of what you want to do. What kind of job should you look for? It depends on your long-term goals. Do you want to focus on one area, move up to higher positions, or change to a different field? Whatever you choose, pick your second job carefully. You should plan to stay in it for two to three years. This job will be important when you apply for your next job. It should show that you are serious about your career. It should help you grow and give you more responsibility. If you want to travel, now is a good time. You can do temporary work when you come back and then find your second job. Future employers will be happy to see that you have traveled and are ready to focus on work. 

Juliette Davidson worked for three lawyers after leaving St. Aldate's College. It was a great first job because the people were supportive. She learned about office work and improved her computer skills. But there was no chance to move up. So, she quit, bought a plane ticket, and traveled for a year. Now, Juliette is a Personal Assistant to Brenda Cleverdon, the Chief Executive of Business in the Community. 'In two and a half years, I have learned a lot and my job has grown,' she says. 'My boss wanted to help me develop from the start. My job title is the same, but my duties have changed. I used to do mostly typing and phone work. Now, I handle most of the letters and budgets. I also answer questions from company leaders and people who want to start their own business. Brenda includes me in all her work and gives me special projects and events to organize.'

**Confident People: What's Their Secret?**

Confident people might seem like they were always confident, but many learned it over time. Nina Hathway talks to five people about how they became confident.

**A. Jenny**

When I finished school, I was very shy. I thought I would always be shy. At 25, I helped at my daughter's school. I was nervous but did well. Someone suggested I take a university course. I was scared on my first day, but my confidence grew. Working at the school changed my life.

**B. Michaela**

Four years ago, my father got sick, and I had to run the family business. I was scared and acted too aggressive. I learned that to be confident, you must believe in yourself. If work is too hard, I don't feel bad about leaving some tasks for the next day. When things are difficult, I remind myself I have nothing to lose. Fear makes you less confident, so I talk to myself to calm down.

**C. Lisa**

People think I'm confident, but when I look calm, I'm actually scared. In TV, looking confident is important. Interviewing people showed me that everyone gets nervous. My mom once told me, "Who's looking at you? Everyone is worried about themselves." This helps me. You gain confidence by doing things that scare you. I was nervous for my driving test, but I passed. After that, I felt less scared.

**D. Barbara**

I enjoy my work, which makes me confident. I've built confidence over the years. If you learn from mistakes, you become more confident. I work hard and am liked at the restaurant, but not everyone likes me. I don't let that bother me. You should like yourself for who you are. My company offers training courses, which help my confidence. Setting small goals helps me see my progress.

**E. Kim**

After college, I worked as a secretary. In meetings, I was too scared to speak up. I finally got the confidence to share my ideas. In politics, I was nervous speaking in public. I told myself, "People do this every day, so you can too." Writing notes helped me feel better. Everyone gets nervous speaking in public. The secret to confidence is telling yourself, "Nothing is impossible."

Text: 'Visit to Malaysia Paul Forster goes to a kite-flying festival and spends a night in the forest. Adnan Ali smiled when I gave him his broken kite. 'You should keep it,' he said, 'it's a tradition - if the line breaks, the finder keeps it ... and I have many more.' He showed me a pile of beautifully decorated kites at his feet. All were 120cm wide and long, made of tissue paper and bamboo. We sat next to them under the trees behind the Beach of the Seven Lagoons in Kelantan, and watched Malaysia's biggest kite festival. In the middle of the beach were 10 platforms, where helpers held the kites, and a line of competitors waited for the start. When the whistle blew, the crowd cheered and the kites flew up like rockets. More than 500 men and boys joined the competition, which lasts five days every year. Each person entered four different kites, judged on decoration, stability, and flying skill. 'Flying kites isn't hard,' said Adnan, 'but making them needs real skill. Visit me at home and I'll show you how.' I accepted his invitation. At his house, I drank cold milky tea and ate fish crackers. As it got dark, he asked me to come back the next day to help fix his kite, but I couldn't. Instead, I explored the southern part of the state, driving towards Kuala Lumpur, into mountains with thick rainforest. I took a wrong turn, and the road ended at a river. A boat was there to take people across. Nearby, a sign pointed up a path into the forest: 'Jelawang Jungle 3 km.' I didn't know the path was steep and slippery. When I got there, a man with a flask of tea was waiting. This was Baba, who took care of a kitchen and bamboo huts. I decided to stay, trying not to think about insects under my mattress. The night was very dark and full of sounds. A waterfall roared nearby, and many animals moved and made noises. In the morning, I saw a great view of green mountains. In the afternoon, it rained. First, the wind blew, then lightning hit the treetops. I got very wet. Going downhill, I wondered how the big butterflies avoided the rain. I also worried about my car being washed away. Luckily, my car was still there, covered in mud, at the bottom of the path. In Kota Bahru, Kelantan's capital, people asked me questions: 'Where are you from?' 'How old are you?' They were very friendly. Kelantan is famous for its kites, but I remember it for the kindness of its people.'

**What kind of shopper are you?**

Everyone goes shopping, but we all shop differently. Do you know what kind of shopper you are? Abby Edwards asked some people about their shopping habits.

**A. Melanie, 22, dancer**  
I love shopping! I spend a lot of money when I can. I can't walk past sale signs without buying something. My boyfriend is the same, so we shop together a lot. We are both addicted to shopping!

**B. Brenda, 40, office manager**  
I don't like shopping much. My husband does most of the food shopping because he cooks. I take my kids shopping for clothes, but I don't enjoy it because we all like different things. I don't buy things for myself often, and when I do, I feel guilty. I don't tell my husband the real price because it sounds too high.

**C. Juliet, 28, personnel manager**  
I only shop for things I really need. I don't like shopping and only go when I must. I know what I want and won't buy anything else. Shopping makes me tired, and I prefer doing other things.

**D. Anita, 35, TV producer**  
I like to look around sometimes, but I know what I want and where to find it. I shop quickly. I do make mistakes sometimes and buy things I don't need, but I try to be careful.

**E. Lizzie, 41, secretary**  
I don't like shopping at all. I can't find what I want, and the shops are too noisy and messy. I don't shop for clothes often because people give me clothes. I do food shopping once a week and finish it quickly.

**F. Lisa, 22, actress**  
I am a happy shopper. I like to look around shops with my friends, and we often buy things. I don't plan to buy anything specific, but if I see something nice, I get it.

**G. Suki, 26, art gallery assistant**  
I am a careful shopper. I like shopping but don't buy much. I know what I want and don't spend too much. Sometimes I shop to feel better, but I feel worse if I spend too much.

**H. Ann-Marie, 29, nursery worker**  
I love shopping, but not on busy days like Saturday. I am careful and know what I want before I go. I look in different shops to find the best price, so I take a long time.

**I. Linda, 32, restaurant manager**  
I don't like shopping. I work in the city, so shops are not exciting for me. When I shop, I don't try clothes on because it's too much work. Sometimes clothes don't fit, but I don't mind. I prefer making a few mistakes to spending a lot of time shopping.

Text: 'NEW OPPORTUNITIES WITH AN OPEN UNIVERSITY DEGREE The Open University can give you a degree, just like other universities. But you don't need to stop working to study. It can help you find new interests. If you have never studied before, you will enjoy learning new things. You will also make many new friends. Your degree might help you get a new job. You don't go to the Open University for classes. You study at home using TV, radio, and computer programs. You can go to one class a month at an Open University center if you want. There are exams to take, just like in any university. If you want to know more, fill out the form below. It could be the start of a great new time in your life.'

**Gallery News**

**Easter Quiz for Children**

During the Easter holidays, children can join a quiz about "Surprises." You can get the free quiz sheets at the Orange Street entrance. Children will look at 14 surprising paintings and answer questions about them. The quiz is available from 25 March to 9 April during normal gallery hours.

**New Picture**

The Gallery has a new still life painting by Dutch artist Jan van Os from the 18th century. The painting shows flowers and fruit in bright colors on wood. It is 89.1 cm by 71 cm in size. The painting is signed and dated 1777 and 1778 because the artist painted flowers from different seasons. Miss Violet Churchman gave this picture to the Gallery in memory of her sister Ida Nancy. You can see it in Room 25.

**Special Exhibition**

The exhibition "Painting in Spain during the late 18th century" started on 15 March in the Sunley Room. The Gallery has new works by three Spanish painters: Paret, Melendez, and Francisco Bayeu. The exhibition also includes works by Francisco's brother Ramon, Antonio Gonzalez, and two Italian artists, Corrado Giaquinto and Giovanni Battista Tiepolo. The exhibition is open until 31 May.

**Lecture News**

There are lectures every Wednesday about the special exhibition. On 5 April, Lizzie Barker will talk about Melendez. On 12 April, Sarah Symmons will discuss Luis Paret. On 19 and 26 April, Juliet Wilson will talk about Francisco Bayeu. On Tuesdays in April, Erika Langmuir will explain how artists tell stories through their pictures.

**Gallery Restaurant Improvements**

The Gallery restaurant now has better and more food options. With new kitchens, the restaurant offers many hot and cold dishes at good prices.

**Information for Visitors**

Free guided tours of the Gallery happen every day at 11.00 am and 3.00 pm, except Sundays. These tours show some of the Gallery's best pictures and important European paintings from the 13th to the early 20th centuries.

Text: 'Little Chefs

For a group of children aged between ten and fifteen, Saturdays are for learning how to cook. Their cooking classes are very popular, and 30 children are waiting to join. Parents pay £280 for the course where children can have fun and learn to make good food. Bill, who is ten years old, says, 'I love my mum's cooking, and now I can cook better than her. The teachers make us laugh, especially when we eat the food we made together.' Flora, who is twelve, has some trouble with onions. 'I love cooking. I made a meal for ten friends, and they liked it. My mum said I should have a hobby instead of doing nothing on weekends. I liked staying at home, so I wasn't sure at first. But now I'm happy I came.' Their teacher, Philippe, says, 'It's great fun. Children pay attention and remember things better than adults, but the kitchen isn't always tidy when they cook! As adults, we keep learning about food. If parents get their children interested in cooking when they are young, they will know how to cook for themselves when they leave home.''

The Outdoor Centre Fees are for a car with four people. If there are more people, each extra person costs 50p. You pay the fees at the main office. The centre is not a private club. It is a place for everyone to enjoy outdoor sports and fun activities. If you are visiting with a group, please tell the centre before you come.

Windsurfing - One-day course Beginner windsurfing courses are on Saturdays and Sundays if the weather is nice. Learning to windsurf is very fun. You will remember the first time you sail on the water. Beginners can use boards with small sails. Course fee: £32.50 (this includes all equipment)

One-day adventure course This is a chance you have been waiting for. Try sailing, climbing, surfing, and archery. This course is for adults to enjoy outdoor activities in a fun and easy way. You do not need to be very fit or have done these activities before. You just need to be interested. Course fee: £22.50

Play Park The Play Park is for children from two to ten years old. It is one of the best in the country. It has sand and water play, slides, a big ball pool, a play castle, and more. Next year, the centre will open a new Play Palace and Play Ship.

Group day and residential courses We also have day and long weekend courses for groups. Schools, colleges, and youth groups visit us often. There are three big rooms with twelve beds each. You can book these rooms for groups of up to 36 people (minimum 12).

Summer adventure holidays (for 8-14 years old) Sailing Climbing Windsurfing Fun Games Safety is very important at the Outdoor Centre. All staff know First Aid and are trained to teach the activities. We make sure all children do activities that are right for their age and abilities. For this programme, children must be able to swim 25 metres and be in good health.

**STAMP COLLECTING - A HOBBY THAT CAN GROW**

Many people, young and old, enjoy stamp collecting. It is a fun and interesting hobby. Every year, more people start their own stamp collections. This hobby can last a lifetime.

Starting a stamp collection is easy because stamps are everywhere. You can find stamps on holiday postcards, birthday cards, and letters from friends. These stamps can come from all over the world.

If you want to collect stamps seriously, you can join the Stamp Collectors' Club. This club helps you get new British stamps. As a member, you can order special sets of new stamps. You can receive these stamps in three ways:

1. We can send you a complete set of stamps on an envelope.
2. We can send you the same stamps in a colorful pack with interesting facts.
3. We can send you individual stamps to put in your own special book.

The Stamp Collectors' Club has about 70,000 members. You can join too. A two-year membership costs just £5. If a group of you join together, you can get a discount. This is great value for money.

When you join, the Club gives you a Starter Pack for free. This pack has 100 stamps to start your collection and a nice box to keep them in. You also get a helpful guide with tips on collecting and addresses of shops that sell stamps.

Every two months, you will receive the club magazine. It has competitions, quizzes, and lets you exchange stamps with people around the world.

Why not start this fun adventure? You will enjoy looking at the different stamps in your collection and finding new ones. Join the Stamp Collectors' Club today and enjoy stamp collecting.

To join, fill out the application form and send your membership fee. Your Starter Pack will arrive within 28 days.

Text: 'MONEY What is money? Money, like the pound, the dollar, or the euro, is similar to a gram or a kilometre. The difference is that you can use money to buy things. For example, a five-pound note can buy a book, a big bag of sweets, or two cinema tickets. But the note is just a piece of paper that is cheap to make. 

A long time ago, people did not have money like we do now. There were no banks or shops. Back then, Mr. Green, who was a farmer, would trade the corn he grew for Mr. Hive's honey. This was a trade between two people, each having something the other wanted. 

Over time, most societies created their own 'currencies' so people could trade more easily. These different currencies started to connect, which is why today everyone uses a national currency.'

Text: 'Write a winning story! You could win £1,000 in this year's Fiction Prize and have your story printed in Keep Writing magazine. Ten other lucky people will win a cheque for £100. We are looking for people who can write good stories. The judges are Mary Littlejohn, a novelist, Michael Brown, a TV reporter, and Susan Hitchins, the editor of Keep Writing. They want interesting and original stories. Last year, detective stories were popular, but the winner wrote a love story. You can write about anything you like. Here is some advice to help you: Write about what you know This is important advice for every writer. Last year, many people wrote about love, family, and problems with friends. You need to make ordinary situations interesting so people want to read them. Write about ordinary things in a new and surprising way. Get your facts right If you describe a town or explain how something works, make sure it is correct. Do not write about things you are not sure about. Hold the reader's attention Make the beginning interesting and the ending a surprise. A bad ending is not good. Develop the story carefully and think of something unusual for the end. Think about the characters Make the people in your story seem real by using good words. Your story must be your own work, between 2,000 and 2,500 words, and typed, double-spaced, on one side of each sheet of paper. We cannot accept stories by fax or email, even if you are late. You must include the application form with your story. We cannot return your story or discuss our decisions. You should not have had any fiction printed in any magazine or book in this country. The story must not have appeared in print or on radio or TV anywhere in the world. Your £5 fee will go to the Writers' Association. Make your cheque payable to Keep Writing and send it with the application form and your story to us. The closing date is 30 July, and we will tell the winner within one month. If you win, you must agree to have your story printed in our magazine.'

Text: 'THE FIRST WOMAN SCIENTIST Hypatia was born in Alexandria, Egypt, in 370 A.D. For many years, she was the only woman scientist in history books. Hypatia's father was the director of Alexandria University. He made sure his daughter got the best education. This was special because most women at that time could not study much. Hypatia studied in Athens and Rome. Then she went back to Alexandria to teach mathematics. She became famous for her new ideas. We do not have her books now, but we know she wrote important math works. Hypatia also liked technology and made some scientific tools. At that time, many rulers were afraid of science, and people connected to it were in danger. In March 415, Hypatia was attacked in the street and killed.'

**NENE VALLEY RAILWAY**

**About the Railway**  
The Nene Valley Railway is 12 kilometers long. It goes through the beautiful Nene Park. The train starts in Peterborough and goes to Wansford, which is next to a main road. There is a 2-kilometer extension that takes passengers through Wansford Tunnel to Yarwell, the quiet end of the line. Ticket prices are £10.00 for adults, £5.00 for children, and £25.00 for a family (up to 2 adults and 3 children). Prices may change on public holidays.

**Nene Park**  
Nene Park has golf courses and a large Caravan Club site. You can have a fun day with your family here. There are many hectares of parkland with lakes for boating, picnic areas, a nature reserve, and a small railway.

**Wansford**  
Wansford Station has a special collection of old trains from Europe. You can see famous trains like the De Glen Compound from France and the German Class 52 Kriegslok, the largest working steam engine in Britain. You can visit these trains all year, even if the Nene Valley Railway is not running. The buffet, bar, and souvenir shop are open only when the train is running. There is an entrance fee of £2.00 for adults and £1.00 for children at Wansford.

**A Famous Railway**  
Nene Valley Railway is popular with filmmakers because it can look like a railway from any part of Europe. The James Bond movie "Octopussy" was filmed here. Come and see where it was made.

**Services for Schools**  
From May to July, the Railway has special services for school groups. Teachers can bring students to visit and do projects. There is an educational pack for £1.50 plus postage. At other times, schools can hire a train called 'Teddy Bear' with up to 3 carriages. Schools need to book one month in advance. There are special low prices for groups of 60 or more students. Call 01780 784444 for more information.

**Private Hire of Trains**  
You can hire the Railway for special family events or company visits. It can be a fun afternoon or evening. You can arrange for a buffet, bar, entertainment, discos, and more. For more information, contact the General Manager at Wansford Station.

Grass

Grass is one of the most successful plants in the world. There are more than 9,000 different kinds of grass, and you can find them everywhere on Earth. Grass is the only flowering plant that can live in the very cold places like the Arctic and the Antarctic. Grasslands are home to many animals, from small insects and birds to big animals like cows and lions. All these animals need grass in some way. Grass grows back quickly after it is cut or hurt. Unlike other plants, new grass leaves grow from below the ground, not from the top. This is why many animals can live together in one place. When they eat all the grass, new grass starts to grow again, so there is always food.

Kal Kaur Rai is very interested in fashion. She just won the Young Achiever of the Year award at the Asian Business Awards. Since she was a child, she liked drawing clothes and making patterns. Her parents own a supermarket, and she never told them she wanted to make fashion her job. She thought they wanted her to work in a more traditional business, so she studied management at university. After university, she moved to London and worked in an advertising agency. She had to go to events but couldn't buy expensive designer clothes. So, she started making her own skirts and tops. Her friends liked her clothes and asked her to make some for them too. A small shop in London agreed to sell her designs. Her clothes sold well, and nothing was returned. This success made her leave her job in advertising. She took a loan of PS20,000 and started her own women's clothing brand. Kal's parents were not upset about her new career and said they would support her, which made her happy. Now, her clothes are sold in over 70 stores, and her business earns more than PS500,000. Her designs are in fashion magazines, and she makes clothes for pop stars. Winning the award gave her public recognition. Kal feels very lucky and says, "What I do is my hobby - and I get paid for it! But remember, I've worked hard for this."

SUNNINGDALE HOTEL

The Sunningdale Hotel was built in 1913 and opened by Princess Louise. It has given great service to people from all over the world. More than 50,000 guests from 174 different countries have stayed here in the last 80 years.

The hotel is on a main road that goes to the town center. It takes about 20 minutes by bus to get to the center. Buses to many parts of the town stop outside the hotel. Be careful not to take buses with the blue sign "Express" because they do not stop near the hotel. There is an underground station less than 100 meters away.

The main building has 200 single rooms. Each room has hot and cold water. Showers, baths, and toilets are at the end of the corridors. The hotel has a shop, sitting rooms, four TV rooms, a table tennis room, a library, and a laundry. There are also eight pianos for guests to use. You can park your car at the hotel. Free newspapers are available, and you can buy stamps at the office.

Guests staying for a long time must pay weekly in advance and give one week's notice before leaving. Both short and long-term guests are welcome, but long-term guests get rooms first. Meal times are: breakfast from 7 am to 9.30 am; lunch from 1 pm to 2 pm; dinner from 5.30 pm to 7 pm. On weekdays, if you study or work late, you can ask for dinner until 11 pm by writing your name on the late list or calling before 7 pm. There are 10 menu choices for breakfast and dinner.

No animals or fires are allowed. Please keep noise down, especially between 11 pm and 8 am. If you arrive by train, it is best to take a taxi to the hotel because it is far from the main railway station.

Tom Cruise is a very famous actor. But his life was not always easy. When he was a young boy, Tom was shy and had trouble making friends. He liked acting in school plays. After he finished high school, Tom moved to New York to find a job. He worked as a porter and also went to drama classes. In 1980, a film director named Franco Zeffirelli gave Tom his first role in a movie. Ten years later, Tom was very successful and became one of the highest-paid actors in Hollywood. He earned millions of dollars for each movie. Today, Tom still acts in movies and has many fans all over the world.

Title: "Little Cat, Little Cat, Where Have You Been?"

Bo the cat wanted to explore a furniture van. She had a bigger adventure than she thought. The driver found her after driving more than 500 kilometers. It was a long day, and both the driver and Bo were hungry! He gave her some milk and started asking questions. He called his last customers, but no one had lost a cat. It was late, so he took Bo home for the night. The next morning, he took her to an animal hospital.

Bo's owner was also looking for her. After searching everywhere, he remembered the furniture van that came to a neighbor's house. Luckily, he remembered the company's name. He called their office, and soon Bo was safely back home.

Text: 'The Ghan Train Mark Ottaway traveled by train from Darwin, in the north of Australia, to Adelaide, in the south. The Ghan train goes across Australia, from the warm north coast through a big desert to the colder Southern Ocean. It is often called the 'famous Ghan', but it is known for being late. People wanted a train from Darwin to Adelaide for a long time. In the 1920s, they built a line from Adelaide to Alice Springs, but there was often flooding, making it hard for trains to pass. A new line was finished a few months before my trip. The railway was built for speeds up to 115 kph, but the Ghan is not a fast train. There are few stops, and most passengers are on holiday. The Ghan does not offer luxury like the Orient Express, but the food on the train is very good. The railway was first built to carry goods, not people. It was thought that sending goods from Europe to Australia's south through Darwin and the train, instead of by ship, would save time and money. It is not every day a big railway is finished, and the Ghan says it is the world's first north-south one. As I waited to get on the Ghan, I saw that everyone was excited about the trip. Most of the travelers were older Australians, and they were eager to board. Our first stop was at Katherine, where the Ghan waited for four hours. Some passengers got off and took a boat trip up the gorge. I stayed on the train until Alice Springs, where I went on a two-day trip to Uluru (Ayers Rock) with a small group and a guide. Climbing the rock is not encouraged now, and few people do it. Our group just walked around the rock and watched the beautiful sunset. From Alice Springs, there are two trains a week going south, so many passengers stop their journey here. The view from the train after Alice Springs is not very interesting. There is a lot of flat land, with only cattle to see. But at dawn on the third day, we reached the hills near the Southern Ocean. My journey was over, and even though the train might not have given everything the ads promised, it took me to some of the most amazing sights in Australia.'

Climbing to the Top of Britain

Every year, many people climb Ben Nevis in Scotland. Because it is in the north, the weather can be very cold. Climber Keith Hewitt talks about his first time on Ben Nevis. It was February, and it was my first big winter climb. We went up the north side of the mountain to Tower Ridge. It is 600 meters high and is probably the longest climb in Britain. We planned to camp for three days in the 'Carries', which are like big bowls in the mountain walls halfway up. We carried tents, sleeping bags, and metal spikes for our boots. You need these spikes because the snow is very hard, like ice. Even though some people in our group were very experienced, we took a lot of safety equipment, like lights to get attention, hard hats, and extra clothes. The weather forecast was good, with no strong winds, but we still felt nervous when we started. Climbing Ben Nevis in winter is always difficult. The path soon went up, and my legs felt tired. I was the weakest in the group, so I had to rest more often. The others sometimes stopped to let me catch up, but when I reached them, they started again. I promised myself that next time I would train better before a climb. After 200 meters, we reached the start of Tower Ridge, the path to the top of Ben Nevis. It is only one and a half meters wide, and the mountain drops down hundreds of meters on each side. We knew we had to stay calm and focus on each step as we moved slowly. After seven hours of climbing, we got to the top. On a clear day, you can see the sea and the island of Skye, 48 kilometers away. But we were not lucky because there was mist. On Ben Nevis, going back down to camp can be as hard as going up. You need to read a map well because a wrong turn could lead to dangerous slopes in winter. I was happy we took turns reading the map. That first time, I only felt happy when I was safe in the tent. But at least I made it to the top.

Anna's New School

This week has been very exciting because we moved to our new school building! It is a wonderful place. The builders used wood for the whole building, just like our old school. But this new school is special because it is very good for the environment. It took many months to build, and we watched it happen. It was exciting to see the builders clear the land, but it was sad to lose some nice open space. The building machines were very noisy, and sometimes the builders had to stop because of heavy rain. We thought the building might never be finished.

Now, we have five very big classrooms, much bigger than in our old school, which was very old. We share one room with people from the town for meetings. There is also a nursery, a nice dining room, and big changing rooms. We can't wait to use them when our new sports field is ready.

When you enter the school, you will see there are no heaters! The heat comes from us - the children, the teachers, and the computers. The building keeps all the heat inside, and it also keeps the sound inside. When we sing, it feels like we are in a concert hall!

Another interesting thing is the tree on the roof! The builders put it there because it is a tradition in Austria, where the roof was made. The electricity for lights and computers comes from a wind turbine on a hill behind the school. We visited it with our teacher yesterday. It spins very fast and is so big that you can see it from far away! We took pictures to put on our website.

Even though we are using the new school, some parts are not finished yet. For example, we are doing a play for our parents, but we have to go back to our old school hall for it. The new hall will be ready next year. We are very happy with our new school, and our teachers say we will learn much faster here!

**International Book Club**

Have you ever thought about joining a book club and buying new books by mail? At the International Book Club, many people already buy books from us this way.

**To join:**
You just need to send us your first order from our book list.

**Immediate benefits:**
As a special offer, you can choose any books at a lower price from our new members' book list, up to a total of £6 (plus postage and packing). This way, you will save money on the usual prices. Tick the box on your form to order a free watch. If you reply within seven days, we will send you another free gift from our book list, chosen by our staff. You can also order a DVD from our list at half the normal price.

**When you've joined:**
As a member, you will save 30% to 50% off the usual price on every book you buy, and they will come straight to your door. You will get a free club magazine once a month, which tells you about the latest best-sellers. Every year, we offer over 1,000 books to choose from. On the Internet, you can see all our books for the year on our special members' website.

**Being a member:**
While you are a member, you need to choose four books in your first year. After that, you can choose how many books you want. In each monthly club magazine, our staff picks a Club Choice book, which is a special book at a special price. If you do not want this book, just say so on the form. We will send the book if we do not hear from you.

So, send your application form today, but hurry - we do not make offers like this every day. To become a member, fill in the form and return it in the envelope we give you. Soon, your books will be with you. Please do not send any money now; we will send you the bill with the books. Remember, you have two weeks to decide if you want to keep the books you ordered. Then, you should either return the books or send your payment.

Text: 'No Title A month ago, I never thought I would be 30 meters above the ground on a Saturday afternoon in November and enjoying it. Now, I looked down at the river far below and understood why people love rock climbing. My friend Matt and I arrived at the Activity Centre on Friday evening. The place to stay wasn't great, but we had everything we needed: beds, blankets, and food. We were happy to be out of the city and in the fresh air. On Saturday morning, we met the other ten people in our group. Cameron came with two friends, Kevin and Simon, and sisters Carole and Lynn came with Amanda. We all came from different places, and none of us knew the area. We knew we would spend the weekend outside, but we didn't know exactly what we would do. Half of us went caving in the morning while the others went rock climbing, and then we switched at lunchtime. Matt and I went to the caves first. Climbing out was harder than going in, but after a lot of effort, we finally got out. We were covered in mud but happy and excited about what we did.'

Text: 'Letter to the Newport Evening News On Saturday afternoon, I left my handbag on the bus. Inside it, I had my cheque book, address book, and my purse with about £50 in cash and some credit cards. When I realized I forgot it, it was too late. I didn't know what to do. I am 72 years old, far from home, and I was very worried. I stood by the road and cried. A young man asked me what was wrong, and I told him what happened. He gave me some money for the bus fare home. When I told the bus driver, he said I should keep the fare. I got home safely, and soon the phone rang. It was the manager of CityBus, the company that owned the bus. He said they found my handbag and offered to bring it back to me. I got my handbag back with everything still inside. I want to say how wonderful everyone was who helped me that day and how much I appreciate their kindness and honesty. Mrs. B. James, Newport'

Text: 'Sharks Sharks are some of the scariest animals in the ocean. They are very good at finding food because they can see well and feel movement with special lines on their bodies. This makes sharks dangerous for smaller sea animals that they eat. Sharks are like other fish in some ways, but their bodies are different. For example, most sharks need to swim all the time to breathe and stay alive, so they almost never sleep. Also, if you turn a shark over on its back, it can stop moving. This helps scientists study sharks and learn more about them.'

Text: 'AUSTRALIA for only £1985 OUR PRICE INCLUDES Flights with Australia's national airline, Qantas, from London or Manchester to Perth, and back from Melbourne. After arriving in Perth, flights with Air Australia between Perth, Alice Springs, Cairns, and Sydney. A coach from Sydney to Melbourne, stopping in Canberra and Albury. All airport transfers in Australia. Nineteen nights in hotels with breakfast. A day trip to Ayers Rock, a full day boat trip to the Barrier Reef, a visit to an Australian sheep farm, and city tours in Perth, Alice Springs, Sydney, Canberra, and Melbourne. All taxes. Hotel baggage handling. An experienced Globewise Tour Manager for the whole trip. PERTH Beautiful long beaches, great restaurants, green parks, and the lovely Swan River. City tour included. ALICE SPRINGS Fly over the outback to Alice Springs in Aboriginal country. Full tour included. See the Flying Doctor base and 'School of the Air'. AYERS ROCK Drive to Yulara National Park. Visit the Olgas and Ayers Rock with its caves and Aboriginal paintings. Fly to Cairns and relax by the sea. GREAT BARRIER REEF A full day's boat trip on the famous reef to see colorful fish and sea creatures. SYDNEY Enjoy the excitement and beauty of Australia's biggest city. A city tour and a visit to the Opera House included. You can also book a day trip to the Blue Mountains. MELBOURNE A city tour included, or you can visit the Penguin Parade. We promise you will want to come back after the trip!'

Text: 'Joining the Kirov Ballet

I'm Nathalie. Last year, I joined the Kirov's ballet school in St Petersburg, Russia. I was one of the youngest foreign students. At my first ballet class, I was nervous because I didn't know anyone. Everyone asked me questions in Russian. I tried to speak Russian, and then they spoke English, so we could talk. Now, six months later, everyone is very nice to me. My Russian is much better, and I understand my teachers. 

For the first two weeks, my mum stayed with me. When she left, I felt a bit sad. One night, I called home because I felt lonely. The classes in Russia are harder than in England, and I eat a lot to have enough energy. This helps me perform well. In the evenings, I watch my favorite films on my computer, but sometimes I fall asleep before the film ends. Now, I feel at home here. I like walking around the city and visiting shops, even in December when it was very cold. I bought a fur hat because it was minus 10°C, but the Russians said it was not very cold for that time of year! At least my room was warm and cozy.

Right now, we are getting ready for a new show, and there is a competition for young dancers. I am going to enter it. I feel very lucky to be here.'

The ICEHOTEL

For many years, people liked to visit the Arctic in the summer to see the midnight sun. But in winter, only a few people lived there with the snow and ice. In the late 1980s, people thought the cold winter could be a good thing. In the winter of 1990, a French artist named Jannot Derit had an art show in a special igloo (a building made of snow) in a small town called Jukkasjarvi on the frozen Torne River. This place, called Arctic Hall, brought many visitors. One night, some guests decided to sleep in the Arctic Hall. They enjoyed it, and this gave the idea for an ice hotel. Today, the ICEHOTEL is famous around the world.

When winter starts, snow builders, architects, and artists from all over the world come to Jukkasjarvi to build the hotel for that year. As soon as one part is ready, it opens to visitors and guests, while other parts are still being built. The first part is ready in December, and new parts open each week until January 7th, when the hotel is finished. The hotel is built outside with natural winter materials, so the finish date can change because of the weather. In spring, when it gets warmer, the hotel melts.

Inside the hotel, the temperature is always between -5°C and -8°C, even if it is colder outside. Warm clothes like overalls, hats, and gloves are included in the price for guests. It is also a good idea for guests to bring sweaters, a scarf, and many wool socks. Shoes should be bigger than normal to fit thick socks. If you plan to visit the hotel, you can buy warm clothes and socks on the ICEHOTEL website. You can order these when you book your visit, and they will be in your room when you arrive.

The hotel is in the village of Jukkasjarvi, 200 km above the Arctic Circle, but only 15 km from Kiruna airport and 17 km from Kiruna train station. You can take a bus from the airport or train station to the ICEHOTEL.

Text: 'Shopping for furniture A report by Dave Worthington Homestyle is a new furniture shop. It had to close soon after it opened at midnight last Thursday. About 6,000 people came to the shop. There were many special offers, like a leather sofa for £45 (only until 3 am) and a bed for £30 (only between 3 am and 8 am). The shop's normal hours will be 9 am to 9 pm every day. But Homestyle said it would stay open for 24 hours on the first day. However, it had to close in just half an hour. A police officer said: 'We knew many people would come, but they were not patient. The shop was full, so the managers closed the doors. People outside got angry because they thought everything would be sold before they could go in. They did not want to wait quietly. Also, there was a long line of cars trying to get to the car park. Many people left their cars in the road and walked to the shop. This blocked the road.' One customer, Jenny Smith, got into the shop. She said: 'I waited for three hours and didn't have time to buy what I wanted. But the staff were calm and explained the situation. It wasn't safe, so they had to close. I will come back when they open again, but I don't want to wait in line again.'

**Membership**

The Short Story Society helps writers in Britain. It started in 1899 and is very active today.

**Society Magazines**

We make great magazines. One is the Short Story Review, which has stories by famous British writers and new writers. Another is Short Story News, with interviews and information about events and competitions. You can read some articles on our website.

**National Short Story Competition**

We have a big competition called the National Short Story Competition. Anyone 18 or older can join. Stories can be about anything and should be 1,000 to 1,500 words long. Members enter for free; non-members pay £5. The competition is from April to October. The ten best stories are in our annual book. The winner gets a contract to publish their own book of stories.

**Education**

For almost 30 years, we have helped writers in schools. We give new ideas to children and teachers. We have a project called Young Writer of the Year for ages 11-18. Winners get book prizes and can join a five-day course with professional writers.

**The Writers' Cafe**

The Writers' Cafe is where members can relax. It has vegetarian food, coffee, and drinks. You can read our magazines there. The Cafe also has exhibitions, short courses, and readings. It is in the center of London and is open from 11.00 am to 10.00 pm Monday to Friday and 11.00 am to 8.00 pm on Saturday. Members get discounts on some products and events.

**Becoming a Member**

We have members all over the world. Anyone 18 or older can join. If you want to join The Short Story Society, click here and fill out a form.

Text: 'Free-diving in the Caribbean Tanya Streeter is very good at free-diving. Free-diving is a sport where people dive deep into the ocean with just one breath. Tanya holds four world records in this sport. In 2003, she became the first person to dive 120 meters deep and come back up without help. Before that, she used a balloon to help her come back up. This time, she held her breath for over three and a half minutes. She was the first woman to break a man's world record in any sport. Fourteen safety divers watched her dive to make sure she was safe. Some people think free-diving is too dangerous because of accidents, but Tanya says safety and training are very important. Tanya trains a lot. She spends most of her time training on land in the gym. She also trains in the pool and the ocean. She uses an exercise bike to make her heart strong. She does not run because she wants to protect her knees. Instead, she walks fast to stay fit. When she practices diving, she usually goes away from home. She does fourteen dives in four weeks, with a rest day after each dive. Rest is important so she does not get too tired. When Tanya is not training, she talks to people about sports products and helps environmental groups. She grew up on the Caribbean island of Grand Cayman and loved swimming and exploring rock pools as a child. Tanya says her life now is like her childhood dreams. She is famous in some countries, so people listen to her about the environment. Tanya is in her thirties and wants to keep breaking her own records. She started free-diving at twenty-five and plans to continue for many years.'

CARTOON FILMS

Cartoon films can do many things. If you can draw something, you can make it move on the movie screen. New ideas and computer programs make cartoons fun again for everyone. In the late 1970s, people thought cartoons were only for kids. But then, some directors had new ideas. They showed that both adults and kids could enjoy cartoons together. Not all cartoon films were good. For example, The Black Cauldron did not do well. It was too scary for kids and too simple for adults. Directors learned from this mistake, and film companies started making a lot of money again.

Title: New TV Star Caroline Benson Talks About Her First TV Role

Caroline Benson is a new TV star. She talks about her first TV role. She says, "I never thought I would spend my first year at university filming The Finnegans. I only acted in school plays before, but I loved the book since I was eleven. My grandmother always said I was like Polly Finnegan, and I imagined playing her.
